content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												I'm not really practiced in the art of writing reviews and other such things,hence I can be quite hectic with my writing's quality,as a matter of fact,most of the time,my writing is all over the place,digressing and sidetracking a lot from the original point. So,with that in mind,I hope you can bear with me here,as I attempt to form a coherent review of sorts for Red Orchestra 2 ,my favourite multiplayer/fps/WWII game to date.The game was released in September,2011 and takes place in the Second World War,specifically,the Eastern-Front,even more specifically,the battle of Stalingrad. [This event comes off as a bit personal for me,because my ancestors fought there,alongside with the germans,italians,spaniards,romanians,and croatians. I hasten to add that I have nothing but the utmost respect for both sides of the war.]With that out of the way,let's look at the game,how it manages to recreate this hellish environment.When the game came out,it was really buggy,it had performance issues,it was prone to crashing,and there was barely enough content to quell the gamers needs. Since then,the game saw a dramatic improvement both performance and content wise (even though the content is still a bit lackluster,but it can be expanded,more on that later).The gameplay itself is a perfect mix between casual fps shooters and mild milsims. It's got a cover system,squads,chain of command,one shot killing mechanics. It can be either infantry only,or combined arms,meaing that there is vehicle and tank based combat in the game present. So I'd say it is a fusion of Battlefield and Insurgency/ArmA. It is hardcore enough that you feel a bit more involved and tactical,and it is casual enough to not get frustrated. You can either choose to LARP as a soviet/russian in the Red Army or a national socialist/german in the Wehrmacht. The game has native voices,meaning both sides speak their native language,respectively. I highly recommend turning this feature on,not only it increases immersion,but it helps you identify your opponent.Speaking of immersion,this game delivers in every department: the sound design is stellar,as is the soundtrack,the graphics are realistic,animations and gore are sufficient enough so that you get your daily dose of PTSD.Now onto the content: the game has a respectable amount of maps (although some of them are played over 9k times a day,I'm looking at you Bridges),a good amount of weapons and classes to choose from,there is a leveling system (separate for weapons,classes and overall level,eventually reaching Hero status lvl 99) ,some veterans find this to be superficial and needless,but I have no grudges against this gameplay mechanic. Other than the vanilla maps,you can download custom maps,mods,and complete overhauls through the steam workshop,which is a huge plus. A few years back,the devs held a map competition,so the best custom maps could become a part of the vanilla game,and the content creators were rewarded greatly. After that,they did not abandon their game,but further improved upon it,adding a few more maps,a territory based campaign (which is the most popular game mode as of now),new weapons for both sides,and some new vehicles.One simply cannot afford not talking about the community in a game where the main pulling force is multiplayer. It is quite small (2000-3000 tops),but all the more dedicated. You will find all kinds of people from all walks of life. There is an abundance of memers,trolls,casuals,hardcore elitists,friendly veterans,LARPers,commies,nazis,so on and so forth. I can say with confidence,that I have mostly positive experiences with the guys playing the game. Some server admins can be total ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s,abusing their powers,but other than that,you will definitely find your place and your role you are comfortable with.Some thoughts about the downsides: minor bugs,glitches,sometimes clunky movement,rare occasions of wonky cover mechanics,the load times can be a bit long,vehicle physics are not the most polished,and the sorts. Nothing game breaking but aggrovating little things nonetheless. The devs have a small studio with limited funds (hopefully that will change with Killing Floor 2 and Rising Storm 2 : Vietnam),so it is understandable to an extent.All in all,if you want an authentic WWII experience with a friendly and welcoming community,good amount of content,and you are tired of all the other popular fps franchises with the same carbon copies every year,and can look over a few bugs,and minor annoyances,I can definitely recommend this game. Thank you for reading,I hope this wall of text was helpful.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2016
												Let's start with the “Meh”: the game's singleplayer mode is the biggest, if not only, weakness of this title. They try to make a story around it, but it feels and plays identical to the Multiplayer. In that respect, the SP part feels more like "training with bots" than anything else. But that's because it is.The real meat and bones of this juicy, juicy bean stew is in the multiplayer and I dare say that RO2 is the only title that has been able to display accurately the feel and struggle of the Second World War. Besides the maps and weapons and guts flying in all directions when a grenade lands, and all the bolt-action weapons, RO2 capture the essence of World War II by genuinely not giving a flying f*ck about the player.No, really. Everything in this game is created with the precise reason of making your life hard and it works on so many levels. The movement is rough, with any sprint taking from your stamina bar, making it harder to aim. Entering or exiting crouch or prone will make you lose control of your weapon for a few seconds. Gone are the days of the Battlefield 3+ super soldier who could run, jump, sprint and crouch quicker than you can say “I wish they didn’t close the BF2142 servers”. Nearby artillery or enemy gunfire will also make your stamina deplete faster. When it gets to zero, your screen turns black and white and you can no longer zoom in while aiming; making shooting a more difficult endeavour. And a difficult one it is nonetheless; aiming is done in the usual modern manner, but with an extra twist. You can do a slight zoom while aiming down the sight, vital for the large fields that fill the RO2 maps (players of Operation Flashpoint 1 / Arma will know this feature). Trust me, you will need this slight zoom. On many maps, discerning a distant player from friend or foe is a challenge within itself and at first you will find yourself shooting friendlies in this game (remember to say “sorry”), but that is part of war, for war is gruesome. But perhaps the most authentic feature that strives to the game’s reality is it’s class system. In RO2, classes are restricted. Each map has x snipers, y gunners, z heavy gunners and so forth. These numbers are always small (less than 5), with the bulk of the players filling the most used class, Rifleman. This means that most players in a server will be using bolt-action rifles, while the more complex ones will have access to better weapons or tools/traits. This also highlights one of the game’s weaker points, since, without a pretty strong machine and gaming rig, your map will load slowly, lessening your chances of choosing the desired class.Even so, I cannot recommend RO2 enough. It is a gem among 64-player FPS games and should be experienced by anyone who is interested in massive multiplayer shooters. The core game, along side with the Rising Storm expansion and the free maps created by the community give you a game that is still played thoroughly, for good reason.

content:
Posted: January 19
Welcome to the meat grinderIf there is a game that can tell that you are nothing but meat in a war is this one.No game has ever given me the sense of morale, chills and terror as RO2.When you join a 64 player server and a new map starts all you can hear is all your teammates charging to the objective, when you hear that you know that match needs to be won.In here you don't play for the kills, you play for the motherland/fatherland and your comrades that fight and die with you by your side.You can command your own Tank/Half-track (on certain maps that allow it) with different players occupying each role inside the vehicles, Yes you heard that right, no ridiculous 1 man inside tank that does-everything-at-same-time♥♥♥♥♥♥here. Your tank driver gets shot? Too bad, you have to move yourself to the driver seat and use the vehicle with a less than adequate crew count.Being a machine gunner in this game is really fun, specially when you can use MG's like MG42 that shred any Yuri on its path and the pure terror of the gun firing so many rounds is incredible. The game has a very nice mechanic where your gun barrel can get extremely hot and break the gun if you fire too much, too fast, requiring you to switch out the barrels.You don't find your usuall CSGO/COD kid here. The rambo gameplay that works on other games will never work here. That's a bonus right there.It is a blast playing with good Team Leaders. They use their brain to strategically order heavy artillery on a fortified area via radio & relay orders to squad leaders to go attack/defend certain locations via voice chat.The game has actual suppresion mechanics. If you fire at a sandbag cover for example where 2 enemies reside, their vision will become extremely blurry/hazed/fuzzy and gray. This allows you to cover fire your teammates just by firing enemies cover while they move up.With all this you got an authentic WW2 simulator.If there was a version of this game with official developed VR support, you could probably get PTSD from play this in just a couple hours.Game is worth every $. (Also note that every dlc has been free)Only thing this game has that is bad is the AI. The soldier AI is bad, but since everyone just plays multiplayer and the devs knew this, there isnt much point to AIYou should know that you are going to die a lot. I mean a lot, in the start the game will make you die so much that you don't even know where the enemy is. With time, that gets better as you get to know the game better and position yourself better in the battlefield.Things I recommend when playing this game for the first time:Enable native voice-overs, this way you don't hear Russians and Germans talking English. Much more immersive.Play on realistic game mode servers (campaign or not)Play rifleman until lvl 20, or at least until you can get a good understanding of the game basics

number of helpful: 23 of 26 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												This is my first foray into hardcore/realistic MMO shooters.Being used to playing CS, my first few games were utter confusion. I couldn't distinguish friends from enemies, I just can't aim fire and run at the same time. Run into an enemy face to face  when you turn a corner? Good luck getting that shot in while your mind just blanks out.My first ever thought when playing the game was "Why is everyone running?".  Where are they going? It was just utter confusion.But after a few hours, I was hooked. I've learned to flank the enemy. Fire a rifle when it counts. And minimize shooting at my own team mates.  But all that pales in comparison to the experience. You get to feel the confusion a battle brings, the paranoia, and the panic when you find out your commander just ordered an artillery attack on the very place you are standing on and running back to safer ground while your teammates mistake you for an attacking enemy.It's just spastic. One time, I accidentally shot a teammate while he was about to throw a grenade. Needless to say, everyone in the room died. Yes, I am that kind of a noob.That said, the community is  great. I mean, better than others if I may say. I would like to describe it, for a lack of a better word, more mature. I guess because the game demands a lot more patience and understanding than a standard run and gun. It's not for everybody. CS players would find this a bit taxing. And you do have to invest a bit of time to understand the mechanics. But for overall gameplay and enjoyment, for me at least,  this one is on the top of my list.And yeah, my teammates forgave me for that grenade drop.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												Hi, Billy Mays hereAre you looking for a realistic, gritty, brutal and immersive world war II multiplayer fps? Have you always wondered what it felt like to have your skin melt off your bones as a stream of fire roasts your body? Do you wish to feel the satisfaction of hitting a running target - 300 meters away - right in the head? Have you always wanted to hold a katana in your hands and charge with your team at an unsuspecting American battalion?Well look no further, because this game answers your call!Rising storm is a very realistic multiplayer fps, with battles up to 64 people. The game is set in World war II, in the Pacific theatre, involving the United states and the Japanese. Battles are extremely intense, and teamwork and tactics play as a key contributor in winning battles. Most battles in rising storm involve the opposing team starting off at one end of the map and capturing or destorying key points, trying to advance forward, while you hold them back and defend them or vice versa. Teams are normally fixed in these scenarios (meaning one team is always going to be the attacker and the other defender).  The balancing in this game is very different from those in other games. Asymmetrical is the term. The Japanese, while having inferior weapons, have much more higher supression resistance and higher morale Aka balls made of titanum or some♥♥♥♥♥♥ compared to the Americans, who have frequent panic attacks. Sly little booby traps can be layed by the Japanese, also and you can get all of your mates to do a banzai charge (good times). However what the Americans DO have is the bigger guns, more load, heavy firepower and Macca's meaning they can use their superior technology to their advantage. Moving onto maps - Their designed almost perfectly. The maps are large and spacious without having loads of empty space and everything is placed in the right spot without being obvious. Every map is played differently too, for example 'Hanto' which is a dense jungle type area makes it very difficult for the Americans to spot the heavily camouflaged Japanese. Another map called Iwo Jima has an uphill slant with many concealed bunkers to defend from, which can ridden with booby traps. All in all the maps in this game is what balances the teams out the most.Rising storm has some really decent graphics. The gun models are astounding and realistic, and textures for character models are very good, too. Environments look gritty and worn out without being too dark and unrealistic. Overall its actually very, very decent. Audio in this game is great as well. It really does add suspense and fully immerses. No silly background sound effects, everything is being produced real time. The music is suprisingly very well done, and doesnt get in the way or break the immersion of a battle.The game may be very, very difficult to get used to for most people. Controls, character movement and coordination may feel clunky for some people as the weapon is not fixed to the center of the screen and the character gains speed instead of instantly moving. Many beginners will also find it difficult to tell the difference between their own fellow team members and the enemy and will shoot without confirming. It takes a while to get to know how each map works out and what the objectives are. In the end though, once you do get used to it you'll be satisfied.Lastly, communication is key in this game. Although a team may be able to capture a point or even win the round without communicating, it will most likely be very difficult as people will be scattered, unsure of when to attack and generally go off and do their own thing. So whoop out your mic and help out the team or if not, atleast take the time to learn which button you press to chat. If you're looking for a more casual experience, use a general role instead of a special class. You get 2 games for the  price of 19 bucks (USD), which is Rising storm and Red orchestra 2: Heroes of Stalingrad bundled together. I probably shouldnt tell you about the download size. Happy Friday.

Posted: January 3
												Look, this isn't Call of DooDoo or BF. This is a definitive FPS that requires teamwork and tactical movement.The fact that it is so long lived is a good indicator that it is of the highest quality. It certainly isn't as pretty as other FPS shooters, but then again it isn't your kiddies arcade game either. If you are looking for something that catches the reality of tactical combat over the computer, a place where the little screaming kids don't go and a game that you can play about WW2 (I'm sick of all the modern day shooters), one that requires good teamwork, tactical movement and doesn't make you superman just for the arcady experience, then this is the game. I have been FPS gaming since the early days of MOH:AA and seen all the iterations of the FPS, right up through the first CoDs and the first BFs to present day. This is still the game that I would call the best and most deserving of the genre for all time, thus far.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												A pants-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ly immersive multiplayer experience. Nothing will ever top the feeling of:- Creeping through a bombed-out apartment block in Stalingrad with a fellow soldier, only to hastily dive to cover as he gets sniped through the throat and spends several seconds bleeding to death, twitching and gurgling on the floor in front of you.- The clumsy, slow process of manning a position inside a tank; adjusting the cannon for range, angling your tank's position towards incoming fire for maximum chance of deflecting rounds, supporting friendly infantry, staying alert for enemy anti-tank soldiers or pioneers laying ambushes, and much more.- Picking off an opposing soldier at 150+ meters with a regular bolt-action rifle.- Sneaking up to a fortified building, methodically crawling and sprinting from cover to cover until you can finally blow a hole in the wall with a satchel charge, allowing friendly assault troops to storm it.- Cowering alone in the basement of a building as you hear gunfire, footsteps, and angry enemy voices directly above you.- When the clip in your bolt-action rifle runs dry at the exact same second an enemy soldier appears a few meters in front of you, leaving you with no option but to scream and charge him, sticking your bayonet between his ribs.- Rubber grenade physics that get you blown up more often than the enemy you're throwing it at.- Stinking fascists.- Bolshevik swine.- So, so much more.This is one of my all-time favorite FPS games. It's very difficult if you're playing against competent humans due to unforgivingly realistic damage (one rifle shot to center mass is all it takes, or even a pistol shot to the heart), movement (enjoy your winded soldier's arms shaking as you try to line up that 100m shot), and ballistics (better zero in those sights), but that just makes it so much more rewarding when you do kill that machine gunner or capture that strategic point to win the round. If you enjoy a dose of realistic masochism with your shooter action, I'd recommend this 100%.As for Rising Storm, I haven't played it at all so I can't comment there.

												I was in a 64/64 player server....My squad was tasked with capturing objective Bravo....We were all rookies,and eager to destroy the bolsheviks.Suddenly,this piano song called "Fallen Heroes" starts playing.(I found the song name later of course)I liked it then.Then we just hear some russian words,and DP28 bullets flying all around us.I lied down next to a pile of dirt,and I looked around.That damn song was still playing and I seen my squad leader's body.Next to it,about 5 more.The last remains of the squad was pinned down about 10 meters away.I noticed the dead SL's smoke grenade.I ran towards to take it.Suddenly,a bullet hits.But where?I looked around,no one was hit.I looked at myself,and as soon as I realised I was the one who got shot everything was going dark.As a last effort I take the smoke grenade and throw it in the crossroads.The piano song ends all of a sudden,and my screen was completely dark.All I could hear was screams,russian or german,I don't know.My screen goes to the respawn menu...I heard a Rifleman from my squad named "Moldplayer" screaming "♥♥♥♥♥♥it's a trap!get back!"It was too late,however.The T34 had butchered my whole squad.Mold tried falling back but he got exploded to gibs by a grenade.Then we respawned.I swear,no other game haunted me so much.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												One of the few First Person Shooter (FPS) games that I have played that have a steep enough learning curve for it to remain challenging, but not overly steep that anyone can't play and have fun. I have put 56 hours into the game at the time of writing this review, and even I am still the 'newbie', I feel like I have lots to still learn about the way everything works in this game, but that is part of the fun.Red Orchestra 2/ Rising Storm is extremely tactical, you cannot just go running blindly around the map without expecting a bullet to the chest. You need to inspect the map, hide behind the cover of smoke as you make your progression towards the objective.I had never had as much fun in a WW2 shooter since my Medal of Honor Allied Assualt multiplayer days, the music is extremely atmospheric and I love running in a zig-zag in open towards some cover and bullet spring off the dirt around you making your vision go blurry.If you are looking for a game with a great community, great atmosphere and challenging but rewarding gameplay. Get this.See you on the battlefield, soldier.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
												This game is just great. Its the most tactical shooter I've ever played, with the same kind of hardcore features as Insurgency (another awesome tactical shooter), but generally slower paced and larger scale, with big maps and bolt action rifles. You'll be laying in craters for half a game, but the intensity of battle makes that experience just incredible. Bullets whiz past, you watch a comrade get shredded by an MG as you manage to dive for cover not a foot from his body. If you get shot, you might get this instace where your screen starts to fade and you have a few seconds to say "♥♥♥♥ YOU!!!" and put a bullet into an enemy, firing from the hip. There's a lot of the little things about this game I could spend pages talking about. and they all come together to make a gaming experience I will never forget.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2013
												Red Orchestra 2 is simply one of the finest if not the greatest WW2 game that has hit the market to date, and there are numerous features that make this game sine in almost every aspect to back this statement up.  First of all the graphics.When maxed out on the ultra graphics i dare say this game looks as realistic as a game can look and can compete even with the graphics of games such as Battlefield.In addition all the maps are geniously desinged so as both team work and tactical thinking are needed in order for a team to progress while at the same time maintening a balance between the 2 sides.  This also brings me to the next key aspect of the game that makes it so appealing to me ,which is TEAMWORK and i simply can not strech this enough.Forget about all your call of duties and battlefields and such where all you need for the victory is one effective player.In this game if teamwork is not utilized defeat is inevitable.Even the slightest hindering in a teams teamwork such as for example a gunner that doesnt know where to place his mg to provide supressing fire can mean the deference between a point captured and a point lost.And to back this importance of teamwork a finite amount of classes are being introduced ,each one utilizing different guns and equipment for different purposes.In addition each gun comes with up to 3 REALISTIC attachments that can be obtained through the extensive use of the gun.These attachments can vary and are all historically accurate in contrast to the ones in game such as call of duty (for example there's no apperture sight for the mp40,an attachment clearly completly fictional).  Moreover the games realistic feel is further increased by certain aspects that the HUD and the gun mechanics have.For the first time in the history of gaming there is no bullet counter and instead the player can have a rough guess of how many bullets he has left by quicly releasing and weighting his mag or by extracting his bolt half way to have a look at the clip if he is using a rifle.Most guns are also usually 1 shot kill if a player lands a headshot,a heartshot,a nutshot or an upertorso shot.If the player doesnt land one of these shots the player he hit will become wounded and will have to bandge immediatly if he wishes not to bleed out.Therefore the chances that you will hit and enemy and he will either kill you or run away are very few ,as they should in my opinion.The game also uses a realistic ballistic system accounting for gravity and such,and it is for that reason that the ability is given to the player to ajust his sights for the proper range.Actions availiable to the player such as changing barrels of an overheated mg,aiming through the iron sights of a snipe rifle and changing through the rate of certain machineguns also add to the realism.  Tank combat is furthermore a feature that sines in this game.Never before has the intirior of a tank looked so realistic in a game and never before have the correct seats within a tank been utilized correctly.In order for the tank to be used to its full potential, the gunner, the driver,the tank commander and the mg gunner will have to work together.  Last but not least a feature that i just love and think every game should have is that when the server is not full of players ,bots take the empty slots.In this way even if only 2 players are palying on a server the game wont feel empty and dead.I must however in account of fairness admit that the AI for the bots is nothing to be really proud of as they will often stay in the spawn running back and forth,stuck in various places or wont advance as the match progresses.I have met this bugs however only a handfull of times and i also have to say that they are not so game breaking as they sound,plus when the server has 56 bots 2 or 3 stuck or glitched isnt really a big deal.I have faith that Tripwire Interactive will adress this issue in a future patch however and so i do not count it as minus for this review.  To conclude Red Orchestra Heroes of Stalingrad is game that can be charectarized as realistic,graphicly immersive and thought provoking as it requires the player to strategically work with his teammates to achieve victory.It has only 1 minor issue that can be easily adressed in a later patch and is made by a company that is known to maintain its games freshness through patches,updates ,contests etc.It is a game with a staggering amount of inovative features and is sure not to disapoint you ,as long as you are not a casul 13 year old cod-loving tryhard.If I were to rate it I would definetly give it a 11/10.I hope this review has helped you and that i will see you online playing this marvel of a game.

Posted: June 16, 2015
												So I buy this game, and after learning some basic stuff in training I decide to hop into a battle with a friend. We both make the incredibly easy choice of fighting for the Fatherland, and hence I fire up this to fight to:


YouTube™ Video: Es Ist So Schon,Soldat Zu Sein. 

			Views: 11,086		

			Die Alter Kameraden.		

We fight long and hard, across streets, room to room, from an arm's length away to a good 150m out. The bullets fly about us, and as we're moving through a building, getting close to an objective, a bullet flies into my Kamerad's chest. His cries of pain echo through the entire complex. And with his last few breaths he tells me, "Komm Kamerad, und reich mir deine Hand! Und nimm diesen Ring von meinem Finger, und schenk ihn meiner Liebst' als Abschiedspfand!"Heartbroken and sorrowing, I change the tune to something a little more fitting:


YouTube™ Video: Ich hatt' einen Kameraden (English Subtitle) 

			Views: 153,107		

			Video verwendet (Video used in making): Unsere Mütter, unsere Väter 1941 German Airmen Funeral Nominiert/Nominate: LowCake DawnVanquisher		

On and on I fight, the thought of his young life still all too fresh in my mind, before a similar bullet strikes into my own head.It was not a long while later that we respawned and tried again.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												Today I will be reviewing a video game called Red Orchestra 2. The game was developed by Treyarch (The same people responsible for such classics as : The Great Gatsby, A Clockwork Orange and Super Mario Brothers) and published by Ubisoft.Let's talk a bit about the game :The game takes place in a post apocalyptic Paris in the year 2250. When the game begins, you can see society rebuilding itself all around you. Society has been split into 2 sides : The neo-nazis and the capitalists. The neo-nazis are a group led by Adolf Hitler's brain which was recovered by the Illuminati from the very same bunker where Hitler commited suicide. The second group is led by Rndrew Ayan. He is a curious Lovecraft inspired repairman, whose seeking to bring Paris back to it's former glory through any means necessary. The game offers you two ways to play, join the nazis in their quest to take over Paris for the Führer or join the capitalists to restore things to the way they were. The story is amazing. One minute I found myself laughing at the obscure situations that the capitalist soldiers found themselves in, the next I was crying when they lost the Eiffel tower because Sgt. Johnson (Who is a key character in the Capitalist campaign) wanted to send a telegram to his wife back in Austria who was missing him dearly.Let's talk about the game's mechanics next :The game is presented in a 2D Bird's Eye perspective, at first I thought this was odd, however it becomes apparent that this was the directors vision and the game is perfect as is. One of they key mechanics of the game is the point'n'click-esque interface, featuring options such as : "Insult", "Batter", "Shoot" and "Heil". Characters in the game react to your every move, from simply moving around to doing key story changing events such as demolishing the Eiffel tower ( which is entirely optional ). The game blends the 2D, Run and gun, Romance, Adventure and Puzzle game elements within it seamlessly to create a unique experience the likes of which will probably never be bested.Move over Call of Duty Ghosts, Medal of Honor Warfighter and Battlefield 4. There's a new king in town and his name is Red Orchestra 2.10/10

number of helpful: 31 of 46 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
												I'd like to start off by saying that I did not enjoy this game, however I don't intend to discourage people from playing it simply because I wasn't entertained, especially now when you can get the game for free. Red Orchestra 2 is a fickle monster. On the one hand, the innovative gameplay and close attention to realism and detail give this release tons of potential. Unfortunately, the amount old-fashioned quirks coupled with the most clueless AI I've seen in a while takes away a lot from what this game has to offer.If you strip the game's uninspired visuals and interface and manage to come past its bugs and glitches, Red Orchestra 2 takes no prisoners with its realistic mechanics and physics. It is a game for a hardcore PC audience who thrive on this type of games with its relatively slow-paced tempo yet high intensity.An immensely ambitious game, and in some ways, it's even a groundbreaking one. However, its focus on realism will turn off fans of arcade shooters. If you think both Battlefield and Call of Duty are too exaggerated and unrealistic, and feel Counter-Strike is too soft, Red Orchestra 2 might be the game for you. It doesn't appeal to me, though.

number of helpful: 12 of 12 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												I've never played a tactical team play game that grants the flexibility, the complexity, and the amount of realism that Red Orchestra 2 brings. I can't think of any parallel that comes close. That alone should say a lot if you're looking to buy the game. In short, it's worth every dollar even at regular price, but for any game, I still say wait for the sale. This game hits sale price a lot.Now, I'm not saying this game is perfect. It has a few negatives which I'll cover but take the negatives with a grain of salt. The positives within this game far outweigh the negatives.I'll start with the negatives, the integrated "Cover system" is broken in some ways. It doesn't entirely keep you in cover. I find, players who use the Cover system easier to kill behind cover. This is because, the animation your character goes into when using integrated covering leaves your character's head and back exposed to fire at modest angles. And by modest, I mean an enemy won't have to move much to kill you in the integrated cover system. I turned my auto-cover button off by unbinding the key associated with it under Game Options. If I want to use cover, I do it myself without the integrated system.That's honestly the only negative I give this game. The rest is good news in terms of how much I enjoyed this game for challenge and reward. You'll find after several hours or several dozen hours that this game has very extensive experience system. Guns gather experience, classes gather experience, and your character level gathers experience. The experience system is not just a number, higher levels grants suppression resistances, stamina buffs, and accuracy buffs. These buffs become quite helpful at higher levels. Guns that gather experience will gain tiers, each gun has a maximum level of 50 and there are 3 tiers associated with it. Each gun gets tier 1 by default, tier 2 is unlocked at level 25 and tier 3 is unlocked at level 50. Depending on what gun you have, tier 2 and tier 3 will have unlocked attachments for the gun like long-range sights and bayonets or extended magazines. This system is very grindy however, since there are so many guns to level. If you're a completionist like me, getting every gun to level 50 will take a very long time.There are a wide variety of historical guns for all four nations. Each gun has better uses than others, it's up to the user to decide which gun you like most. Majority of players will say PPSH-41 is the weapon of choice, while others will counter that the MG42 and Mkb 42 are better. It's a constant daily argument. I personally like all the guns, even the bolt action rifles. In a full 64-player game, I was able to get MVP using only a rifleman class with a bolt action rifle. It depends on how well you want to perform.There are vehicles, there are medium tanks, light tanks and troop transports. Medium tanks and light tanks get their own classes and are effective but not over-powered. An experienced tank driver can cause a lot of headache, but in contrast, an experienced anti-tank gunner can take out a tank with a single well placed shot at the tank's ammo rack.Being Commander is a lot of fun but also actually requires a lot of hands-on command skills. Commander's job is basically to sit at the radio and call in artillery or recon. Commander can also force-respawn players waiting to respawn. Giving orders is important, not only are you telling your team where to go. Players within the area of your order get +1 points for each kill and capturing objectives as a result of your order. Additionally, AI actually follow Commander orders. Sending 30 or so AI into a single base is quite funny.The AI is not the smartest nor the worst... It's difficult to describe the AI, they're amazing and terrible at the same time. Sometimes you can stand in front of an AI and it won't shoot you or it will miss you a dozen times. And on the other hand, AI are known to do 180 no-scope headshots. It's up to you to decide on this one.It's almost nearly impossible to notice for new players so I will point it out now. There is bullet drop. But bullet drop is not noticeable until you are about 200m away from your target. But that is rare, majority of the time you will be shooting within 170m on average and a lot of close quarters right down to melee combat. In all my hours of playing this game, I have only had to change my sight range to 200m for only one kill.Pros:Wide variety of maps and gamemodes. (Best gamemode imo is Campaign)Large selection of weapons.Extensive experience system that rewards at new levels.A lot of active communities and it's easy to find a full 64-man server. (I find full servers daily as of this review.)Realistic combat. (Realism-mode adds to this and it's the only mode I play. It's kind of this game's 'hardcore mode.')Tanks and transports are not OP.User-friendly command system.Artillery adds zest to an already pleasant experience.Workshop is available for custom maps and mods.Single-player AI battles in Workshop. (I still prefer playing against players.)Cons:Can be unforgiving for new players. You will die a lot.Broken "Cover System."Tanks are easy to get stuck.Neutral:Mkb 42 and MG42 gunshot sound effects are too loud. (my own opinion, however.)AI is both amazing and terrible.Stamina is low and gun handling is terrible for new players. (all fixed via gaining levels)Overall, I highly recommend this game. It took me away from Battlefield 4, haven't gone back since.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												Forget about being a hero:War is about survival, following orders. Red Orchestra 2: Heroes of Stalingrad (Rising Storm too btw) captures this very same feeling to the perfection. Forget about running on the field and firing two machine guns akimbo like Rambo. You're a soldier, russian or german, american or japanese. The fight will always seem unfair and it is: get over it. Then how can you win and enjoy you may ask? Keep your head down, take cover, watch out for your teammates, follow your commander's orders, go for the objectives: be a soldier. The slightest misstep can kill you and your teammates. And if you win the battle, always remember that you would never have made it without your team, your squad leader and your commander.Footmen win wars, but don't get credit:More often then you'd want, you will have the role of a lousy footman, a bolt action rifle and 2 grenades. That is it, but you must make the best out of it. And if you do well enough, you'll have the opportunity to get promoted: sniper, automatic rifle, anti-tank or even tank crewmember. Don't worry, this game is hard at first, but always try your best, take time, don't rush things.A pearl is always difficult to acquire:This game is hard because it is different. It requires patience and strategy. It may seem hard and it can be frustrating. But trust me, if you want to see what war really is, i think Red Orchestra 2 gives a decent vision of that.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												Combat Report for HQCodename: Operation Stalemate IIVeteran class Squad leader #2, DidHeDiedTime of operation: 8:32am, September 15th, 1944Clear weather, humidity and temperature both high.Our commander (Dr. Steve Brule) has tasked squad #2 with taking objective Bravo on the airbase beach island of Peleliu.Near unacceptable casualties expected.8:45am, we land and begin our assault on the airfield. I smack hotkey 6 for my binoculars, and get an artillery mark for Commander Brule.But our Commander was not at the radio... He was solo charging the enemy line (smoke grenade in hand) and singing backstreet boys are back on public voice comms; with overwhelming gusto.I later found out this is called “psychological warfare”At first the enemy couldn’t believe what this American was doing and were hesitant to shoot, Commander brule then ran back to the battalion radio after laying down a smoke screen for squad #2.He then gave his orders “Wait for the first 3 salvos of artillery, then we ♥♥♥♥ them like a warm cherry pie boys!”I count the salvos and keep my squad in check, on the start of the 4th salvo I let out a piercing battle cry over team voice comms; and we begin our charge over no man's land.9:15am, squad #2 advanced into and took the enemy trenches of objective Bravo.During our assault we took 3 casualties to type 99 MG's: LulzBoy69, Drunkenballsack and MustyGooch, may their souls rest in peace (for the next 8 seconds, 7 seconds, 6 seconds, FORCE RESPAWN BY DR. STEVE BRULE).Squad #2 fought valiantly for the next few points, we had a brave flamer lead the charge, and riflemen follow, with our MG’s dishing out relentless amounts of lead suppression on the enemy positions. I am only allowed 10 minutes of computer. Now I have to put on the jacket that stops my arms from moving and go back to my room.My room has soft walls, it is nice, but it gets a bit lonely sometimes.You’ll probably get to join me here if you buy the game, yay I can’t wait to see you!

												As I make my way through the ruins of apartments, the sound of silence is broken as I hear the frantic footsteps of a fascist approach from behind me. I turn to see the German appear at the doorway and shoot him in the heart. My 7.62x54R bullet shoves him against the frame of the door as his life is robbed from him. He slowly slides to the floor, clenching his chest, gasping for his sad life. As he gazed right into my eyes I witnessed his very damned soul depart from this twisted world. As his fight to strive on ends I hear these words come from my mouth, "I will never get these faces out of my mind". Then, I continue on as if nothing happened other than a slight interruption.This is just a sample of the level of detail in this game. Hopefully this "review" will be enough to convince you to get this game. One thing is for certain, I'm gonna take these fascists to hell with me.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												It is August 31st, 1942. Me and my comrades in the 124th Rifle Brigade move to a village on the outskirts of Spartanokva, just north of the Tractor Factory. We are untrained and inexperienced, but equiped and ready to defend our motherland to the last man. Stories from the 62nd Army state that a Soviet soldier will only withdraw once his ammunition is spent, the building is in ruins, and their clothes are on fire. We enter a the church of the village and pray to the God my country denies. The artillery bombardment begins, the floor begins shaking. Suddenly, our machine gunner spots germans and begins opening fire. He dies 5 seconds after. Some attempt to fire back at the Fascist invader, but they are gunned down as quick as the peek out. Smoke begins to cover the windows, the German infantry move in to take the church.A Fascist scum jumps through the breach in the wall, and I quickly fire a shot off into his chest. He hits the ground before he could get on the other side. Another meets the same fate. The 3rd does it, I miss the shot, he hits me in the left arm, but I bolt the rifle quick enough to use my 4th shot before he can finish me off. I proceed to bandage my wound, and when the task is completed, 10 germans have entered the church. I lay on the ground, 1 bullet in my magazine, 10 germans, and they havn't noticed me. I couldn't fire or they would know. I reached for my grenade and considered what I could do for my brothers who died killing the Fascist menace. I pulled the pin, and threw one at the far end of the church, and then pulled the pin on the second one before they could shoot me down. The church was cleared for now, but more Germans instantly reinforced and captured the church. I have died taking out 10 fascists with me, but my story will never be known, my sacrifice forgetten the moment after it happened. All witnesses will not make it out of the battlefield alive, and I had no family to mourn my death, as they have all been killed at the hands of the Germans.10/10, Will turn you into a zealous nationalistic jihadist.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
Lobster with mango is often found on French menus and is served here with a citrusy salad and butter sauce.IngredientsFor the orange zest salad        ½ orange, zest removed and cut into very fine strips, flesh segmented        250g/9oz mixed salad leaves (such as rocket, frissée, watercress, nasturtium or dandelion)        2 tbsp sugar        1 tbsp Moscatel vinegar        2 tbsp rapeseed oilFor the lobster and mango        1x 550g/1lb 4oz precooked lobster        100g/3½oz butter        salt        1 lemon, juice only        1 mango, peeled, stoned and sliced        mustard cress, to garnishPreparation method    For the orange zest salad, blanch the strips of zest in boiling water three times to remove the bitterness. Drain the zest thoroughly and set aside on kitchen paper.    Mix the salad leaves with the orange segments. Set aside.    For the lobster and mango, blanch the lobster in boiling salted water, two minutes for the tails and three minutes for the claws.    Remove the lobster meat from the shells, cut the tail in half and remove the claws.    In a pan, warm the butter until foaming, drop in the lobster and heat through, basting all the time. Season, to taste, with salt and lemon juice.    Remove the lobster from the pan and add the mango slices to the butter. Cook until the mango is soft and warm. Reserve the butter.    For the orange zest salad, place the zest in a small frying pan with the sugar. Heat until the sugar is caramelised and coats the zest. Set aside to cool slightly, them mix with the vinegar and oil. Pour over the salad leaves and toss to coat.    Place the dressed salad in the centre of serving plates with the lobster around the side and mango on top. Drizzle the butter over and garnish with mustard cress.

content:
Posted: April 20
												Reviewing only Red Orchestra 2: Heroes of Stalingrad  - i did not own Rising Storm. RO2 is the dream of any hardcore WW2 fan. The game features battles from World War 2 between germans and the russians in Stalingrad. But why is it so great? That's simple: Because of the way they created it. You will fight in small troups as either normal soldier (only equipped with a Rifle and a Grenade) or as a special class, equipped with extra equipement. Mg's, Sniper, Tank destroyers, elite soldiers [..] There are various classes to choose from. But all of them are limtied, just like it was back then. The majority of players will always end up in the Rifleman Class. And that's good!This is none of you usual run and gun games. It's a hardcore, challenging and very realistic team shooter. One shot to your chest? Likely dead. A shot to your arm? Well, yo can bandage that. A sniper bullet in your bottom? R.i.p. Gunplay is incredibly well made, reloading single bullets or clips is totally sufficient! The lack of an HUD just adds to the experience. The graphics are good! Not the best compared to today standards, but fitting to this kind of game. Dark atmosphere, dirty snow, dirty houses [...] Stalingrad lives again... The sound is one of the best i have ever experienced in an online shooter. While the normal shots are just your average sounds, its the overall package that makes it so great. Beeing shot at by an mg, jumping into cover, just to hear the player next to your dying slowly because he was hit by the bullets - you feel sad, angry and frightend. You don't want to peak out of cover when there is a sharpshooter ahead. You don't want to run through mg fire. You are afraid for your life. You are happy when you can get to the next trenches - it means there won't be anyoone able to snipe your head off. You will start to really feel like you are there, not just playing a game. The community is mostly very good! Roleplaying is not uncommon, neither is having great team leaders and commanders. Communication is proceeding smoothly, making it not only an fps, but also a strategical game. I could go on like this for hours, but let's just say: If you want a highly realistc, challenging world war 2 shooter, and don'tmind the high initial learning curve, this is for you! Buy it!

content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
												(English isn't my first language...you've been warned! ;)I've been planing to do a RO2 review for quite some time now, but never really got around to do it...until now! This review might not be perfect or complete. But these are my thoughts about the game and yeah...here we go. As you might have guessed from the game's title, this fps takes place during WW2. There are two parts of it: vanilla RO2 on the european eastern front, where you fight as either Germany or the Soviet Union(goodies: tanks/vehicles, OOORAAAH!), and the pacific theatre of war expansion Rising Storm (goodies: flamethrowers/katanas, Baaanzaaaii!).Beware though: as RO2 is primarily a multiplayer title, the AI in both SP and MP is rather...sub optimal. It sucks. Therefore, instead of buying Heroes of Stalingrad for the SP content like a friggin moron (like me...), I HIGHLY recommend buying the Rsising Storm expansion, as it also happens to have ALL Heroes of Stalingrad MP maps so...yeah. No brainer :)But now! Enough with the theoretical nonsense and onto the ACTION! Huuza!


Rising Storm/Red Orchestra 2 Multiplayer 
A Screenshot of Rising Storm/Red Orchestra 2 Multiplayer
By: [Volk]SpixTalon




RO2 imo fills a very interesting niche between games like CoD (fast paced, very arcady FPS) and games like Arma 3 (veeery slow paced, big focus on realismn).Keep in mind: I realise there are more games out there than just these two, I only picked them as represantatives of two very different game design philosophies.So RO2 might be the perfect game for people who find CoD to be too much of the arcady bull**** it is (please excuse my Frensh here, but I really fu***** hate CoD) and Arma 3 to be too much...well, just too much. RO2 is still fast paced...you rarely ever have to walk more then 30 seconds to come within enemy contact, but one bullet can still drop you.Other features for example are a suppresion system which makes your aim go all over the place if somebody shoots you a lot as well as weapon unlocks/improvements for all classes/weapons.But what is it really all about? Well, there are several different game modes of which the most popular is "Territory". Ever played a round Battlefield Rush mode? Yeah, it's pretty much like that. Capture one Point (sometimes 2 or even 3 at the same time) after another and win the map! But keep an eye on both tickets and time! Both are limited, so the attacker needs to hurry! And the defender has to play it smart, otherwise the defending team might end up stalling the attack but ultimately running out of tickets(=lives/respawns), which creates a very interesting dynamic.I believe there are some other modes as well, but truth be told...I have never played anything else in over 400h RO2. There are also two different types of servers: campaing or rotation. On a campaing server the victorious team gets to choose if it wants to attack or defend and which territory / map to attack. On a rotation server...well...there is a fixed map rotation :DIf you still want to know about those modes--> http://lmgtfy.com/?q=Red+Orchestra+2+Game+Modes Germany and Russia are fairly well balanced. Some might say the Russians have the upper hand in CQC, but that's not really the case. At least in my opinion. There is no real imbalance. However, some people keep saying that the fight between USA and Japan is soo unfair because US=OP. And on first glance it does seem that the US have better weapons, higher firepower etc. Example: the US rifleman gets a M1 Garand. That's a semi automatic rifle. The Japanese Rifleman however, only gets to play with either the Arisaka Type 99 or the Type 38, both are BOLT ACTION RIFLES. I could go into details of stoping power, range, accuracy yadda yadda. There are guides for this if you are really interested in stats like this(remember the 1 Bullet=Death rule?^^) . To sorta balance things out, most maps are designed for the US to be the attackers, so the Japanese have the advantage of being in the defense.I still recommend for new players to start as the US(maybe even on a campaign server) because their weapons are far more forgiving. Trust me. A quick guide on what makes the Japanese so uber awesome was made by WilliamTheTard-san:


Banzai Charge: An In-depth Look [Video Guide] 
A Guide for Rising Storm/Red Orchestra 2 Multiplayer
By: WilliamTheTard

			An advanced and in-depth look at the Banzai charge. Its in-game effects on your own character (damage resistance and speed), but also on that of nearby enemy characters (suppression).		


Thank you, Will! When you follow his advice you "will"(get it? :D ) end up like this:


Rising Storm/Red Orchestra 2 Multiplayer 
A Screenshot of Rising Storm/Red Orchestra 2 Multiplayer
By: [Volk]SpixTalon




Kicking♥♥♥♥♥and chewing sushi.yummy...Once you are ingame you will notice that there is a class system. The classes are ranging from the ordinary rifleman to extremly deadly flamethrowers.(oh, and tanks in stalingrad^^) There is a slot limit though with the majority of soldiers being said riflemen, so better be quick to grab that lovely MP40/Thompson!There is also a squad system and a team leader, but I won't go into any details here. Suffice to say: While squadleaders are mobile spawn points for their squads and therefore are IMMENSELY important in both offense and defense, the teamleader can call in recon planes (that shows enemy locations on the map even if it's not pin point accuracy) and can drop big fu***** artillery strikes on those poor souls of the enemy team who happen to find themselfes under an arty marker. Both SL (=squadleader) and TL (....exactly! Teamleader) get to choose from a lot of shiny weapons too. They are NOT however for storming the damn beaches of Iwo Jima on ur own, but for protecting urself from single enemy soldiers who want to kill you! SL and TL are very important for a team's success and a match's outcome is often not determined by individual skill, but by the coordination between TL and SLs. Oh, they also get smoke grenades(1 for SLs, 2 for TL) to screen the own team's advance.For the ordinary grunt, RO2 playes a lot like any other FPS. The controls are fluid and intuitive (WASD...), the cover system is total garbage though...don't you dare to use it. Once you get used to the increase of range (you'll find yourself shooting at guys 150m+ in the distance a LOT) and to the fact that you die every minute or so ;) there is really nothing to prevent you from having a BLAST. Except maybe teamkills...which DO happen a lot. Because, well...you fight over large distances, you have an itchy trigger finger and you DROP PEOPLE WITH ONE SHOT^^. But it's part of the game, it happens and it kinda is part of the fun too. Here is a little tip that will safe you A LOT of frustration: Allies (Russians, Americans) sprint with their weapons in front of their chest. In BOTH hands. Axis (Germans, Japanese) sprint with their weapons in their right hands only! Oh, did I mention RO2 has an ingame voice chat which people actually use to talk tactics and don't abuse the sh*t out of and try to be the most annoying little f**** there are?(except on Russian servers...I mean, I don't speak Russian but I recognise recordings of speeches/parades on the Red Square when I here 'em^^)  Yeah, the RO2 community is pretty awesome.If you are still with me after this DAMN wall of text and you survived my horrible English, there is really nothing that should prevent you from buying this game.Like right now.I mean it...it's awesome :)In case you want to see some ingame scenes first I picked a completly random LP from YT ( seriously...idk this guy), where you can see a defense on IWO JIMA on the Japanese side.http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1TPWR9qyM2EEDIT: He seems to be playing on an action server. Danger indicators, crosshair (only iron sights on realism) and "killed from location" are usually not in the game when you play RO2 these days.My final verdict: 9/10With that said, I wish you a lovely day. Much Fun. So skillz.

number of helpful: 11 of 12 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2016
												Red Orchestra 2 is a game created by Tripwire that was released in 2011 on UE3. The game is set in WW2 on the eastern front, hence the name Red Orchestra.To put it simply, it's a hardcore version of Battlefield. It's possible to kill anyone with a shot to the head or torso. Other than that the game is 32v32, features a ticket system from battlefield and most maps have a "rush" like game mode. That said, the games are very different, and that's mostly due to the fact how easy it is to die in Red Orchestra. This game forces you to think differently.In this game, you never run in the open in full height for example. You always go from cover to cover, preferably crouched. When you find a shooting position, you should try to have as much of your body behind cover. Really, in a lot of ways the game makes you feel as if you are in a real war, cause everybody will be acting as if they are in one.Why should you buy it?I suppose your first question is whether it is fun? It is in it's own right. It's quite a unique experience.Usually most maps are played with Attacker/Defender style. Defenders are given a few points on the map at a time, and must hold them. If they lose them, they get pushed back, and would have to defend a new set of points. Sort of like rush, except that you have flags instead.Unlike battlefield, the capture points are very big. Let's say the attackers need to take point, which happens to be a house - the capture point is the whole house. Why am i bringing it up? Cause i want to talk about camping. It's a tactic that will be commonly seen among defenders, but it's not your typical camping. You do not just sit in the corner. You have to correctly disperse your forces to fend off the attackers, and usually you are also given 2 points to defend at once.Attackers have it much harder on them, since they actually have to advance to win, but they also get more tickets.The game also has a very minimal UI. It's practically only your eyes and ears - no minimaps, no names over targets. In fact, friendly fire is turned on all servers, so one of the first things a beginner must do, is learn the difference between russians/germans and americans/japanese (their uniform).Red Orchestra 2 rolesRO2 does some things much better than Battlefield, for example classes. Each team has 1 commander, and multiple squads made of 10 players. A squad has squad leader and he acts as a mobile spawn point to his squad mates. Usually a team is given 4 squads. Yes, that's 40+ slots for 32 players - it was done on purpose. A team gets 1 team leader, 4 squad leaders, 4 machine gunners, 6 assault (automatic weapons), 1 sniper, a few more elite assault and elite riflemen, and the rest are normal riflemen. You cannot make everyone in your game medics, engineers, snipers etc. Instead there are roles, that increase in complexity.Normal riflemen have bolt action rifles, which are inferior to everything else in the game due to their fire rate, and pretty much 75% of the players will be playing as them.Elite riflemen have semi-auto weapons. Assault and elite assault have automatics. Each has their own role in the game that they must fulfill. These guys are there to fight in close quarters on the objective.Machine gunners are another class with automatic weapons, but they cannot aim with their machine gun until they station it - making them very inaccurate for close quarters, but good for defense. Their greatest strength is that they can shoot 50-200 rounds before having to reload.Usually a team gets 1-4 snipers max (depends on the map), and these are used to take out important roles such as team leaders, squad leaders and machine gunners. Unlike other roles, they can't spawn on the squad leader, so if they die, they will have to make it all the way from the base to the frontline.Squad leaders are a mobile spawn point for the 9 players in his team. It's very important for them to survive. Other than that they are the only role that has smoke grenades, which are commonly used in this game to block vision for the enemy and allow your men to charge in. They also have binoculars, which they can use to mark points on the map for artillery.Team leader is the one that is calling in artillery basically. He actually has the same gear as the squad leader - a sub machine gun, smoke grenades, he can mark with his binoculars as well, but he requires to be next to radios to do his job, like for calling artillery. The radios themselves are located on certain point on the map, and usually they are not where the action is.Some maps also feature tanks, and with them they bring engineers and AT gunners. Engineers are basically allowed to choose the gear that elite riflemen or assault use, and they get anti tank grenades. But their main job is to destroy obstructions, like tank barriers. AT gunners on other hand get a big anti material rifle, but just like machine gunners they have to station it.ImmersionLike i said, it also gives you great immersion, but it's more than what i described. There are a lot of things in the game that improve immersion even more. Stuff like this for example.


YouTube™ Video: Red Orchestra 2: Heroes of Stalingrad | Axis Campaign | Training Mission 4 | Tank 

			Views: 38,067		

			This training mission 4 of the axis campaign of Red Orchestra 2. Thanks for watching!		

They modeled the whole interior of the tank, and even added animations for the crew members.A bit about tanks themselves. This is no battlefield - the tank can fit 2-4 crew members depending on the tank. Unlike battlefield again, the driver only does the driving for example. He has a very limited view by the way, as you can see over here.https://youtu.be/Lyrl49hCmqY?t=89Usually there is a tank commander, a turret gunner and an MG gunner. There is also a loader who is played by AI, but you can replace him if he dies. Not all tanks are the same though. They are like 4 currently - Panzer IV and T-34 were available on release, but Panzer III and a 2 seated T-70 were added later on.That said, unlike red orchestra 1, there is a lack of tank battles. There are only 3 maps for huge tank battles. Most of the time the tank is used to support the infantry.UI is very minimal as well. There is no indicators of how much ammo you have in your rifle for example. But you can check that by holding R, and your character will physically unbolt the rifle and check it. Little things like that make it very immersive.Rising StormIn 2013, Rising Storm was released - an expansion to RO2. It's set in the pacific and features american and japanese. It's basically the same game, except without tanks and it's asymmetric. Meaning one side is better than the other - americans get auto and semi auto weapons, while most of the japanese roles have bolt action rifles. Americans also get flamethrowers.It's a nice challenge for more experienced players and it's a great place to start learning the game. You also don't have to own the expansion to join the servers - the game allows people to play as a normal rifleman if they don't own it.Content and PlayerbaseJust gonna leave these 2 spreadsheets i made.https://imgur.com/mCI9XCjhttps://imgur.com/3OPxhdAJudge for yourself.The playerbase is rather weak 5 years after release unfortunately. Sometimes you find all servers empty and other times 3 full servers. People that play it are very mature though.ConclusionWell, i told you all i had to tell, the choice is up to you. It's a very hardcore game, but you never know, maybe you would like it.Also, do not that this game is entirely multiplayer. There is a campaign, but it's basically the multiplayer with bots. Same maps, same modes, but very dumb bots.If you do, please turn on "bolt rifles manually" and "native languages" for extra immersion.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
												So I'll avoid another review and instead offer advice for noobs where they're likely to read it.The community is generally welcoming but providing you follow two easy rules.1. Do NOT take the Team Leader position.2. Do NOT take a Squad Leader position.OK, 4 rules.3. Do NOT play this like COD. 4. Shout out that you're new and ask for advice. Many of us like to show off our experience so will gladly help when asked. Red Orchestra is a team game, played over a number of battles in a campaign (usually). A TEAM game. As an example, if you're a points ♥♥♥♥♥, the top of the leader board is the person with the most TEAM points. NOT highest number of kills. Team points can win games.The issue with those two roles, TL and SL, is they have to be played properly if the team is to win. And TL, and preferably SL's, need a microphone and experience. So thats it. Do not got TL or SL  until you have a lot of experience OR .. you're willing to tell the team you are new and want advice. Then listen and follow. Also be aware of the role you pick or are allocated. MG's usually move to the flanks and provide cross covering fire. Keeping the enemies heads low. Accuracy and kills is actually less important than scaring the enemy. Make them keep their heads down. When you get low on Ammo shout out using your command keys .. ask for ammo and riflemen should bring it to you.Snipers .. your job is to take out enemy MG's and Squad Leaders. Anyone else is just going to give your position away for little benefit.Tanks ... always operate best with a crew who communicate with microphones. Use the 6 key to swap between shell types. AP for armour, HE for everything else. Remember that you have 2 mgs. One in the hull, one parrallel with the main gun. commander, stay inside the tank. You are an easy target.  Driver, hatch closed.SL's, including Tank SL. You have 5 jobs. Do them and your team might win.1. Stay alive. DO NOT DIE. DO NOT BE A HERO. If you want points, do your job. You can get to the top of the leader board without firing a round. 2. Mark artillery targets. If attacking, locate it just past a cap, preventing the enemy from entering. If defending, in a position in the cap furthest away from you .. ie where they enter the cap.  There are many variations of this on the different maps. Learn them. Always be thinking ahead to the next cap point and try to get your marks in early so your TL isn't waiting. You get team points for any enemy killed by artillery.3. You are a mobile spawn point for your squad. Get close to the cap and stay down. Stay alive. Your squad can spawn next to you rather than all the way back at the previous spawn. this enable syou to quickly cap and advance. 4. Smoke.  You start with one smoke and can pick a second at the nearest ammo point. Use it to keep your squad alive. Position it to alllow them to get into caps safely. Not too far away so as to be of little use. You are their surrogate father. Look after them. Keep them safe. Its possible to use smoke in defence but it has to be done VERY carefully so as not to block your line of fire or benefit the enemy. 5. Talk to your squad. (Press T to find out who they are, Press I to chat to just them). Encourage them, instruct them. Tell them where to expect arty, when you're popping smoke etc. Organise them so you can mount a strong attack. TL .. you need to be talking to your team constantly. Letting us know when and where arty will drop. Which area to attack and when NOT to attack. You need to call in recon at the appropriate time, instructing your SL's to check their maps and provide new updated marks if required. You HAVE TO STAY next to the radio while the recon plane is up other wise enemies are not shown on th emap. If you need to support an attack in a certain way then tell you SL's where you want their marks. Keep a constant eye on the chat and relay any important infor to the team (thats why you need a microphone). Anti Tankers .. clue is in the name. You keep the team safe from tanks. If you don't do your job and instead decide to go sniping, your team will get slaughtered. DESTROY TANKS.Engineers ..  you destroy tanks and tank barricades. When attacking you make a path for YOUR tank with the satchel. Blow fortifications to cripple defenders or alow ingress. When defending you destroy enemy tanks but your're also tasked with defending baricades etc. from enemy engineers.  It's your job to STOP them from being blown up.Assault .. as it says .. when attacking your are the main thrust of the attack. Auto Riflemen .. you are essentially an assault with greater range. Riflemen .. You provide cover for the assault squads .. forcing the enemy to hide.  You then follow the assault into the cap and help consolidate. You then hold and defend the cap while the assaulters move onto the next cap, again providing them with cover and preparing to move on again once the assaulters have nearly secured the cap.You can also resupply MG's. Walk, run or crawl up to them and press USE. This is an essential job since if an MG has to run back for ammo they're both at isk and leaving you without vital support.Always use transports when provided. They allow you to follow up an attack much faster and to concentrate forces where needed. Therefor, never drive off in a transport on your own. Always wait until its mostly full. Enemy recon planes can be shot down. Russian is a bi-plane, German mono. It loses them team points and recon info.Team Kills, TK's, happen. they just do. If you TK, say sorry. If you're TK'd and the person says sorry, type np  (no problem), the TK will be forgiven, the person won't be kicked and your team will get a point .. because you were nice. Always forgive, np, TK's by arty .. it's usually your fault.I could waffle for hours but I'll leave it at that.  It's a fantastic game once you get into it and understand how to play it to it's best.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												When I first read the reviews for this game, I was shocked to find that some people were horrified by the results of this games purchase. I needed to find out for myself how realistic this games really is. As I opened up the game I was greeted by a simple and effective main menu. I figured I would play the training to see if I was walking into something complicated. I was happy to see that the game wasn't too crazy. I jumped into my first match to find myself accidentally walking into the middle of a massive fire fight only to be massacared by the enemy team. I figured I should change to a marksman to avoid the frontline fire. As I mounted up in an apartment window, I found myself doing much better as I was starting to fix my k/d and actually started supporting my team. I realized the horrible killing machine I had become as I had looked over myself after the match. I first got my PTSD from a event that will never leave my mind, it gave me nightmares. I was sniping from a window when I spotted two people acting as if they had never seen each other in years. I trained my scope in on the man on the right and pulled the trigger, sending a piece of sharp, refined metal from my barrel right into the man's right temple. As the blood flew from the man's head into his friends mouth and face, I felt no emotion as I saw the man on the right freak out into burst of emotion that would send him to his knee's beside his friends lifeless body. I shot the man in the knee sending him into imense pain. I walked over to this man and as he begged for mercy and as stood there I pulled out my mauser and shot him in the forehead. The blood flew from his head like a watermelon, sledge hammer collision. Even though I have only played this game for 0.7 hours, I already have PTSD and am shaking while writing this. This game is a must buy.10/10 Would get PTSD again.

But you had to carry on. The rest is.... is up to you - either you die easily, or you become a truly hero of this horrifying war. :)

content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												--------The Following Narrative Actually Happen in Red Orchestra 2-----------------------------Bridges of Druzhina - 1942--------------Russians...Russians are everywhere. They took objective A, B, and C so quickly that our fellow soliders began to panic. My Honor Rank is 73 and a squad leader for Squad Two. I ordered my men to fall back to Objective G, the outskirts of Druzhina, and command them to fortify the position. Squad One fought valiantly against the Russians on Objective D, but most of them were wiped out. The dense forest that cover Objective D and E favor the Russians than our German forces. The Bolsheviks were clever to use smoke grenades to advance their position while our men fired wildly into the thick, white smoke. What are they shooting at? Who knows. As Objective E was spammed with Russians, the commander order the squad leaders, including me, to send in artillery coordinates. Unfortunately, there were too many artillery requests sent to the commander. The first coordinate is at the Russians on Objective E, the second coordinate is pointed directly at the Russian T-34, and the third coordinate was sent in close to Objective G. I was the one who sent in the third coordinate. I debated with my commander that the third coordinate is the best because the Russians would most likely be sending 2/3 of their forces to take G. The commander didn't listen and called the artillery at the first coordinate. As the artillery roars the sky and slams into the ground, the Russians were clever to run away from Objective E. Some of them died while the rest who were at Objective E rush to Objective G in a frontal assault. The machine gunner in my squad, whose Honor Rank is 58, fired his MG-34 in a control burst, but was killed by a sniper from 148 meters. I watch the machine gunner got shot and his body slump into the fragile, wooden floor. I was traumatized by this and order my men to not be exposed by the window. The rest of my squad consist of newer members, ranging the Honor Rank from 12 - 36 didn't listen to my command. The second squad member (Honor Rank - 26) was killed by the same sniper. Two squad members killed and the Russians are swarming in front of the sandbags near Objective G...and I have to make a choice. I ordered my squad to suppress fire at the Russians while waiting for additional reinforcements to come and defend Objective G. Unfortunately, the Bolsheviks pulled a hard, right flank at Objective F, wiping out Squad Three in under 20 seconds. Even though my squad was able to pluck a few kills around Objective G, the Russians purposely made this frontal assault as a distraction so that their comrades can take Objective F. Knowing that Objective G would be overrun from the right side, I ordered my lower ranking members to retreat back to the apartments in Objective I. Strangely, there were signs of courage and fury in my men's eyes. One of the squad members (Honor Rank - 21, Anti-Tank class) demanded me to let him risk his own life as the T-34 rushes to the main road that leads to Druzhina. I refused in his request and ordered him to tactically withdraw, but he didn't listen. Before I was about to demand an order to him, he pulls out the Hafthohlladung anti-tank grenade and runs directly in front of the T-34. He starts to scream and was about to swing the grenade, but was mowed down in a hail of machine gun fire from the Russians. However, I heard an explosion and I took a slight peak in the window. The T-34's main gun was pointing in front of me and the last I said to my men is: Run! This is Red Orchestra 2. ------------------------------Review----------------------------Red Orchestra 2 is the ultimate first-person tactical shooter that advocate very strong team coodination and communication, complex cover system, and each life (or ticket) is precious. When playing as the Russian, German, American, or Japanese, each solider fight just to survive. There will be instances in the game that discourage reckless assaults or exposure to the enemy. You will learn the game by experience and not repeating the same mistakes twice. There are weapons, class, and character rankings that encourages replay value. The best experience you will get in Red Orchestra 2 is playing on a full server. You will hear the best team coordination, the best varieties of newer and veteran players, and the greatest responsibility for your own life and theirs. Red Orchestra 2 does not shy away from the actuality of war as you will hear meeps, horrific groans, and the development of post-traumatic stress disorder. There is no "I" in war; there is brother and comrade. Red Orchestra 2 is simply, the best tactical first-person shooter to ever develop.

												I ABSOLUTELY LOVE THIS GAME AND THE COMMUNITY!-Constantly New Maps and Mods rolling out - ALL FREE! which dramatically increases scope and gameplay. -INTENSE COMBAT! He dropped, and I returned to my position in the dark, his buddy hearing his comrads last squeek quickly ran into the house and ran past me searching for who ever killed his friend. He quickly found out.. but only for a split second. This earned me a KILL BILL achivement- 10/10 will KILL BILL again.
