content:
Posted: July 14, 2016
												Best $5 that I ever spent on steam, have played many more hours than the 140 I have on steam on a disc copy.  This game, to sum it up frankly, is the greatest shooter game I've played in my entire life.  It blends together perfectly; from the firefights, to the the crawling in the muddy trenches, to ''HURRAH'' charging as the Soviets towards certain death in the form of a MG34 machine gun, to watching your buddies get shot in the stomach and bleed out all the while screaming in agony, to sprinting from broken tree to shell crater dodging fire.  This game has it all, a perfect blend of hardcore and tactical shooterBUTI have yet to reveal this games most outstanding quality.  This game does something that very few other games can do (I can count on my hand the number of other games that compete with this game in this aspect), and that is to create teh atmosphere of war.  Red Orchestra 2 does this better than any game in my opinion.  DISCLAIMERThis game will give you PTSD, no doubt.  I remember the first time that I played it and jumped into a game and selected the Rifleman class.  I (foolishly) charged around towards the river on Bridges and saw my friend get hit directly by an Anti-tank rifle, removing his legs.  I was in shock and continued running only to be hit by a mortar shell and be dismembered.  I took a second and realized that this game was nothing like any other game that I had played; I legitemately felt fear.  I was terrified to poke my head out of the trench, only to get killed by a rifleman.  I was scared to run from crater shell to crater shell, with bullets whizzing all around me. I was horrified to find that grenades inside houses do not bode well for the occupants.  #bestPTSDsimulator2k16This game... what else can be said about this game.  It is fantastic in every element, although being a few years dated (2013).  I will continue to play this game until the next one comes out, Rising Storm 2 Vietnam, but even then I'm sure that I will keep coming back to this one.  In closing, I give this game a perfect score of 10.0/10.0.  Two thumbs up, absolutley perfect.  I wouldn't change anyting in this game and for the love of God, buy this game. :)

content:
Posted: September 21, 2011
												Red Orchestra 2 is wonderful.The "psudo-realism" setting that most Modern-era FPS have taken is vexing.  A gaming experience shouldn't require much suspension of disbelief.Team Fortress 2 is a great game for its cartoon fantasy setting, allowing us to imerse ourselves in the gameplay world.Call of Duty on the other hand takes a "realistic graphic/settings" approuch, but keeps gameplay highly casual (i.e. health regen, invincible humans, no recoil, unbelievable events, ect.) and fails utterly!RO2: Heroes of Stalingrad on the other hand upholds a deep commitment to realistic gameplay to match its unique real-world setting, the bloodest and most interesting infantry conflict of all time, the Battle of Stalingrad.The game was pushed out early which means lots of bugs and critic reviews that are less prasing than it deserves, but Tripwire has proved itself to be a company commited to ongoing development with loads of free content and performance improvements down the line.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												One of my favourite ever shooters. I bought this game for about £3 - the price of a pint of beer. What a buy it was. It has provided me with hundreds of hours of gritty, immersive and extremely atmospheric gameplay. I love this game because it rewards noble gameplay: Patience, perseverance, precision, wit - compared to the homogenised, soft - edged generic excuses for FPSs that we are now spoon fed. Yes, at first you will get shot from 150m countless times by someone you think must be invisible or hacking. Yes you will be frustrated at constantly being blown in to disgusting flesh lumps by artillery. Yes you will be annoyed that you can't be a sniper every match and are forced to use a boring bolt action rifle with iron sights. However once you master the rifleman class the whole game starts to fall into place and you will realise that this is one of the best and most "different" tactical experiences you have ever had.9.5/10 I love this game and would absolutely recommend it if you are an experienced FPS player looking for more depth. However if you are a 14 year old with no patience, don't even bother.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2014
												After searching and searching, i have finally found a WWII game that is nearly perfect. In my opinion, it's my most favorite fps up to date. I rate it above Battlefield 4 and CoD 4 and put it next to BF:BC2. The only thing that they need to do now is come out with a Red Orchestra game for Vietnam with vehicles and everything and my life would be complete. The combat in this is spot on and much more dynamic and responsive than other FPS games I've played. Unlike BF4, you can actually play at 150 ping on a server and have no lag. I've had no problems with hit detection at all. On a scale of 1 to 10, I'd give this game a 9.7. The only thing it's missing is more vehicle accessible maps and airplane combat. That would make this a full WWII experience. I'll probably play this game more than I have played other FPS's. It's definitely worth picking up for 20 dollars. It's an amazing WWII game.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2016
												I was a fresh recruit, it was September 21 1944. It was six days into the assault on Peleliu.  I arrived with my best friend Daniel Krane. I've known him since grade school. We were devil dogs, 1st division. We were set on sentry duty, I heard a rustling in the trees I called out. No one answered, so we got this skinny fella, named Tony? Told him to light it up with the 30. In the mornin we took a look. It was our own guys. They were just taking a♥♥♥♥♥♥ my first instance of death and blood shed. We went on patrol a few days later. Our radio operator, some kid from a Philadelphia. He took a shot from a sniper in the trees. We got the poor Jap. We came upon a bunker our Sarg ordered to burn em out.  So we lit em up with flame throwers. Dan and I were ordered to clear out any survivors. The smell of burning flesh stung my nose. The thought these guys I have family's and now their charred remains couldn't be identified. As I went to leave I heard screaming in the tunnel. I sprinted towards the sound, I break into the corridor. I see Dan on the ground with a katana in him. I froze up the officer looked at me. "Tenno Heika Banazi!" He yelled. I came to my senses raised my M1 Garand and shot him. Right in the bridge of his nose, filled with rage I unloaded the rest of the clip into him. Even after it ejected I kept pulling the trigger. At night I always see Dan's face filled with fear.10/10 would get shell shock again.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												1)       It was 1943. My friend and I were holding the Russian front against the invading Nazi forces. They had us pinned down to our last territory. We held off the Germans and prepared a counter attack. Our counter attack was so strong we brought the war to the pacific front and we turned into Americans. TL;DR: Fought so hard we switched campaigns.2)      The Germans were invading one of our cities, so I led my squad in the defense. There were two adjacent courtyards they were heavily open to enemy fire. I led my squad into a trench bordering the courtyards, and lost many in the process. My remaining friend and I go prone in the trenches dreading the inevitable German attack. Outside, about 20 yards from us, we heard a Panzer rolling across the ground. My remaining friend pulled out a satchel charge, and looked at me, and in that look we both knew what had to be done. I threw a smoke at the Panzer, and under the cover of the smoke my friend ran up to the tank and placed the charge, destroying the tank. However, before he could return to our position, he got ripped apart by enemy snipers. Shoutout to Karl XII for being a true war hero and ultimately winning the campaign for the Russian army. He will not be forgotten.                                           Best war game ever, hyper realistic, 1943/10

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
												Red Orchestra 2, or RO2, is an amazing game. It is, by far, my favourite shooter, because of its stunning grahpics, amazing visual effects, and great audio. It also stays true to the historical events of WW2, and is set around 1941, during Operation Barbarossa, with Soviet Soldiers clashing with the German invaders. The game also features vehical combat, which is a nice touch. There is a large ammount of weapons in the game, too, which are, for the most part, well-balanced. The majority of the maps in the game are quite vast and open, save for a few close-quarters combat maps. Red Orchestra 2 is all about tactics. The Team Leader is a key asset to every team, as he can call in artillery strikes and recon planes. Squad Leaders are important because they are a mobile spawn point for any player of the team. Riflemen and submachine gunners are the main fighting force for either side. Marksmen usually hide in bushes like the cykas they are and pick off enemies from a distance. And engineers can stop a tank in its tracks. But every class plays a key role in leading their team to victory.In summary, Red Orchestra 2 is a phenomenal game with a few minor flaws that are made up for by the amazing gameplay, visuals, audio effects, and realism. It's a great game, and anyone who hasn't played it should give it a try.PS, if you're a rookie player, be sure to have a keen eye, or you'll get shot by some unnatural force that you cannot see.PS again, Soviets have the best rifle in the game and Germans have the best SMG.

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												PROS:- A lot of WW2 weapons and using them feels nice- Pretty authentic WW2 experience with four sides to choose from (Japanese vs Americans, Russians vs Germans)- No spray patterns :), but you must take the distance and recoil into account- Class/role based and, as you gain XP, you improve your stats for weapons and classes- The game is not limited to shooting only (rifleman, elite rifleman, assault, elite assault, marksman, anti-tank, machine-gunner), but you can also lead and command a squad (squad leader), operate a tank (tank commander, tank crewman), disable tank traps (engineer) or even command all the battlefield for your team (multiple tactical support options for a commander). Not all roles are available for all game types.- Several gametypes (objective based or just shooting) and three rulesets (realism, classical and action). Action is the casual mode (crosshair, reduced damage, run and shoot pace) and realism is the "real mode" (one shot kills, bleeding damage, no crosshair, no ammo counter). Classical is similar to realism, but without zoom on iron sights and bleeding out. But I can comment on the classical mode only from what I've read on the forums, as it seems that classical mode servers are dead.- Very detailed and interesting maps, offering different approaches to engage the combat.- Cover system, grenade cooking and blind firing makes the gameplay options more variable- Even if you are not a very good player, you have your chances to excel. This game is not punishing for inexperienced players, as, for example, Insurgency or Counter-Strike. However, the skills still matter and the more you learn, the better you become.CONS:- Limited number of active players (1000-1500) and usable servers- Annoying bot behaviour (circling on the spot, blocking the sight for team members, not adjusting to the team)- Unadjusted respawns - spawning in front of enemies or behind the enemy line is common- It feels rather chaotic. Although the large number of players + bots allow to score many kills and accelerates the gameplay, the team members do not coordinate their actions very well.- Some maps offer exploits for sniping and its noticeable that some players prefer certain maps for that reason during map voting- Rather clumsy transitions between entering cover, exiting cover, crouching and proning- Quite a few glitches (seeing through objects/players; getting stuck until you press ESC, problems with proning or taking cover, not being able to use chat, etc.)This game is rather complicated and it has a rather steap learning curve, but from the four multiplayer shooters that I've recently played (CS:GO, Insurgency, America's Army: Proving Grounds and this one), Rising Storm feels the most balanced. It's like a middle ground between "casual shooters" and "hardcore shooters" and I like it that way.It suits well enough both for weekend action and hardcore skill building.My overall rating: 7/10.

I do 100% recommend this game to anyone who is looking for a hardcore and realistic FPS game.And my last word is, I wish more people get attracted to this game.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												The most entertaining multiplayer fps so far that has just the right amount of realism (this review is based on 'Realism' -mode of the game). Getting shot gets you killed (or disabled which is the same as killed in game terms) most of the time, depending on the weapon you get shot with: higher caliber weapons drop you with more certainty while pistols require more accuracy. Getting shot in the head or the heart (yes, the game lets you know where you were hit) kills anyone instantly. If you get lucky enough to survive a shot, you must spend a few seconds bandaging the wound or you will bleed out and die (yeah, not very realistic but very entertaining and exciting gamewise!). Also, sometimes you survive being shot for the few moments it takes you to bleed out from a serious wound that you cannot bandage: your screen starts to go black and you can no longer move, aim, reload or switch weapons. You can empty your current weapon in the general direction of the enemy sometimes getting lucky enough to hit them. Heroic effort, that! Nothing can save you from dying in this state, however. The game simulates suppression by turning the screen gradually black and white while a loud thumping of your own heart can be heard. This indicates your soldier panicking in the midst of an artillery barrage (which causes the most suppression in the shortest amount of time), getting shot at (bullets hitting near you gradually make you panic) and finally fellow soldiers getting hit and dying near you. In game terms, you aim is lowered by the additional weapon sway and the screen effects make it harder (not impossible, just more difficult) to aim accurately. The two sides (US and Imperial Japanese) are balanced in a way that - despite their numerous differences - offer a different experience in gameplay. Both sides have a set of limited roles ranging from the single team leader, several squad leaders, machine gunners, assault troops, snipers and an indefinite amount of riflemen up to the team size of 32 players. In addition the US get flamethrowers, and engineers carrying trench guns, while the Imperial Japanese have 'Knee-mortar' -soldiers. Also the technology of the time is - to my knowledge - displayed accurately: the US soldiers are equipped with semi-automatic weapons (M1) most of the time while the Imperial japanese troops have to make do with their bolt action rifles (Type 38, Type 99). In some maps, like Guadalcanal, the US troops have bolt-action rifles (Springfield) as well since the M1-Garands had not yet been delivered to them (as is historically accurate). All in all, the US have more firepower at their disposal at any given time.In return, the Imperial Japanese troops have bayonets from the beginning (which the US soldiers lack until upgraded) and they can banzai charge - resulting in higher suppression resistance - causing suppression in the enemy the more soldiers are joined in the charge - and the ability to withstand more hits than usual (headshots and shots through the heart kill instantly, as normally). The US troops suffer from suppression more easily than the Imperial Japanese troops. Japanese officers also get katanas, which are a cool way of disposing opponents. In terms of weaponry, the Imperial Japanese soldiers can use their grenades as booby traps: 2 can be in place at the most by a single soldier at any given time. If you plant a third, the first one disappears. Yeah, again not very realistic but it balances the game. The booby traps can be seen plainly if placed on an open terrain with no vegetation and they can be detonated by shots, grenades or artillery fire. US soldiers walking over or very near one detonate it and most often die instantly while the Imperial Japanese soldiers can walk over them without triggering them. An US soldeir can, however shoot at a booby trap to detonate it in the face of any enemy soldiers (there's actually an achievement for this!).  The knee-mortar (as inaccurately named by US troops of the time; some poor ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s actually tried firing it from their knee, often  breaking their thighbone as a result) is basically a grenade launcher which must be setup prior firing. It can be deadly in accurate hands but is often a cause of accidental team kills among new players trying it, don't get discouraged if this happens and remember to apologize for team kills! A knee-mortar soldier gets 5 grenades to shoot at respawn, which can be replenished once at a single supply point like any other ammunition. The flamethrower that the US  have, is a weapon feared by many Imperial Japanese players. A mere touch of its flames will kill you almost instantly and the flames fill a bunker quickly and completely leaving nothing alive inside. In contrast, the fuel runs out rather quickly, the range is limited,  and the US soldier carrying it is perhaps the most targeted soldier among enemy troops. Both sides' team leaders must coordinate with their squad leaders to bring down artillery fire on, or near the enemy. This mostly acts as an area denial behind capture points so that the defending or attacking players are denied access to secure it. Soldiers finding themselves inside a barrage must get out of there quickly or get killed by the blasts: the game mechanic of artillery kills anyone inside the area over time. If you're very lucky, you can survive for a few seconds to run into safety. The game has a honor system with ranks starting from 0 (new players) and ending in 100 - the highest rank available. The honor rank is account based and it is shown on a 'kill list' rotating on the upper right corner of the display (who killed who, how and where the shot it if a vulnerable spot) whenever you die or kill an opponent. You never know where the shot came from (unless you actually saw it your field of vision) as the camera locks instanly as you are killed so you can not look around to spot the enemy while dead. The individual roles on a side (rifleman, machinegunner, squad leader etc.) get experience (team points) points based on performance in battle: staying near you squad leader or team leader grants you extra team points whenever you kill someone or help capture an objective (which in itself grants several points). Also extra points are awarded for killing someone FROM the object zone and even more if the TARGET was in the object zone as well. Normally, you get 2 ream points from a kill and -2 for a team kill. A team kill can be forgiven by a player by saying 'np' in the public chat (the 'np' is not shown in actual chat) which removes the penalty from the player who caused it. It is generally polite to apologize for team kills and forgive them if the player causing it apologized. Sometimes you can guess with almost certainty that a team kill was an accident. Sometimes you just make the mistake of running into an area where someone just said they'd throw a grenade at or the team leader announced that the artillery barrage would strike in: in these cases you should own your mistake and 'np' immediately, especially in the case of team leader's artillery barrage which could result in numerous team kill penalties quickly. If you get enough team kills, whether accidental or not, you get kicked from the match and can't rejoin until the map changes. Respawns in the game are periodic (a rotation of 16 seconds, I think) simulating waves of reinforcements arriving. The team leader has a limited ability (with a cooldown period) to instantly respawn all dead players. Both teams have a set number of tickets which dwindle as players keep dying. If the tickets reach zero, spawn protection is disabled and no more respawns can take place. Maps are also time limited and failure by the attacking team to capture an objective will eventually result in a lockdown period of 3 minutes during which they must capture the point or lose despite the time left on the map's time counter.

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												     Red Orchestra 2 is a World War 2 FPS which focuses on the eastern front. It mainly revolves around the bitter street fighting in the streets of Stalingrad and contrasts it with the openess of the surrounding steppes. RO2 scratches a multiplayer itch that no other competitive multiplayer game can quite get. It mixes small unit tactics and teamwork with high intensity and very authentic gunplay. The man who runs and guns in this is the man who gets shot first. Along with the authentic gameplay comes a steep learning curve. To those who tough it out RO2 is a multiplayer favorite and is an undeniably excellent game. Starting off with the core gameplay mechanics, RO2 attempts to; and arguably suceeds at; creating a tactical and authentic multiplayer experience that forces players to confer with their team in, at least a basic manner. The team with better communication generally comes out on top. Communication is especially crucial to the commander, who can call in off-map suppourts such as recon and artillery suppourt. These suppourts rely on coordiantes supplied by squad leaders and the platoon commander, thusly making teamwork a nessesity to win. Classes also play an improtant role. Given that M4 carbines are not the norm in World War 2, every weapon is more specialized. Riflemen are your typical grunts equipped with a bolt action rifle. These rifles are incredibly lethal and accurate making the rifleman key to providing suppourt to the other classes. Maachine gunners shut down kill zones and provide an alley for others to advance. Squad leaders assist the commander in providing coordinates and can use somke to conceal movement. Assaults get down and dirty in the ternches and go head on with the enemy with a sub machine guns. AT riflemen and Engineers provide a way to counter enemy armour at long and short range respectivley. These classes create a dynamic of cooperation between teammates, not one class dominates the battle. Gunplay is deliberate and lethal, One shot from any weapon has the potential to kill freind or foe. This gunplay makes short range combat flurried and confusing, while having long range engagments become a test of finesse and awareness. all of this gameplay is nicley wrapped in an atmospheric and compelling presentation. You crawl in dirty trenches to avoid rifle fire and artillery, knowing one well placed shot will end your life. The soundtrack potrays the mood of the battle, spurring you to action or spiraling into self loathing for losing to your opponent. Soldiers around you vocalize showing distain for their sub-human enemies, cowering in fear after coming under fire or writhing in pain while bleeding out after taking a round to the chest. The only real complaints regarding RO2 are it's steep learning curve, useless single player and some map glitches. The learning curve may turn some people off though once you get past it, RO2 is an experience that no other FPS can offer.

Posted: December 14, 2013
												I don't play many shooters anymore, I found that they had started to feel pretty identical, and the gameplay was too shallow, and most posssessed horrid communities (I'd really rather not have some kid yelling "♥♥♥♥♥♥" into the mic, not cool dude). Red Orchestra is different. The gameplay actually requires you to think, take cover, and play intelligently, and the assault/defense gameplay encourages close co-operation and teamwork. A match on a full server is one of the most intense shooter experiences out there. Bullets whiz by your head, artillery explodes around you and you're desperately clinging to a little piece of cover firing shots off at advancing Germans/Russians, you watch as the guy in your squad next to you gets shot in the face as he moves to advance, but then that friendly tank moves into view blasting away the infantry ahead allowing you to charge forward with a hurrah. Capturing a well defended point feels like an actual accomplishment. Plus, the community is friendly and I've yet to have someone yell ♥♥♥♥♥♥ at me over the mic.

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												RO2 (along with the Rising Storm expansion) is one of the most brutal first person shooters available.  This is one of the few shooters I have in my library that does not feel like an arcade experience.  Here are the following reasons I keep coming back to this game: suppressing fire and artillery cause your character to panic, affecting your aim and movement.  There are not countless weapons and upgrades to choose from; weapons are limited to squad availability, which forces teams to work together unlike other modern shooters.  You are easily killed, which forces you to move and attack carefully.  Finally, and most importantly, this game is hard...VERY hard.  It takes a while to get used to the play style and to properly explore the importance of the different squad roles.  This is one of those games where the first time you play it you will get killed very quickly and very often, not because there's some level 99 player with all of the weapons and upgrades unlocked kicking everyone's♥♥♥♥♥ but because you haven't learned how to properly play the game.  This game is gritty, brutal, realistic, maddening, and a hell of a good time.

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												Artillery rains down on the streets as a small group of Russians hold an apartment block. "HOLD THE POINT!" Our commander yells in chat as we continue to fight a losing battle, hoping to at least dwindle their numbers so they can't push through to other towns. I'm here with my bolt action, taking ineffective shots at the growing number of Axis soldiers moving into the point. My character curses his gun as he hides in cover to reload.A teammate walks past me as I'm reloading, gun down, holding his stomach, and my character starts fumbling the magazine as I see him bleed to death. I peek from cover and take out a soldier. "I'll never get these faces out of my head" is my character's last spoken words before the Axis take their victory. You are infeebled as a player, and forced to rethink your strategy. As a rifleman, you're stuck on the back lines, firing at what you hope is not your own teammembers, trying to capture points with your horrible firearms. It's the only military shooter I've seen that features a sanity meter as it should, making the battle more intense and the characters more human. For the first hour, I never even saw an enemy, so be prepared to study your teams and discern green brown from brown green. This game does its job in creating desperation, and requires real courage to try to conquer this depressing shooter.

												I was sitting alone in a house overlooking a train yard with my PPsh clutched in my hands. I heard MP40 shots go off behind me and a comrade scream in agony. I waited patiently in the house until I saw the bratwurst eating culprit whiz past the frame of the door I was covering, and watched him take position overlooking the train station. I siezed my chance, came up behind him and put about 4 or 5 rounds in him. Thing is, I didn't kill him though. He lay on the ground and let out a blood curling scream of absolute terror and suffering as he slowly bled to death on the dirt. There was no time to survey his wounds though, as immediately, 2 foot soldiers overheard the commotion and advanced on me from 12 oclock. Getting into a prone position right next to the bleeding, writhing enemy I had just shot, I quickly dispatched the two with a couple more short bursts of gunfire as his deafening last screams pounded at my right eardrum.TL;DR: ♥♥♥♥ed up a German, laid in his blood next to him, popped two more of his buddies as he quite loudly let me know what horrible pain I had inflicted upon him.Some of the best voice acting I've ever come across in a game. Never playing COD again!

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												I've had this game for over a year now, but was never able to really play it until now (I had horrible framerate issues back then).It's a realistic World War II FPS game. -Weapons never stay centered on the screen-You die in 1 to 2 hits (or you bleed out from non fatal injuries)-Magazines are actually preserved (you don't regain unspent bullets from a changed mag; instead, the partially used mag is saved for later)-There is no ammo counter. You check the number of bullets by feeling the weight of the magazine, or by pulling back the bolt of a rifle to count the bullets inside (done by holding the reload button). Even then, you won't know the exact number. It'll tell you if it's empty/near-empty/half-full/more than half/full.-Suppression is a thing. If there's too much gunfire around you, your screen will turn black and white. Your character will start shaking, and you can't steady your aim down your iron sights.-Bullet drop is a thing. When aiming down your sights, you can compensate for bullet drop by adjusting your view down the iron sights (done by scrolling up/down with the mouse scroll). The further a target, the more you'll have to lower your sights to get an accurate shot.-There's a cover system. I don't use it much, but it's still there. You can also lean left/right.-Roles are limited so as to prevent the Battlefield problem. Depending on the number of players, there can only be 1-2 snipers, 1-4 machinegunners, 1-2 elite assaults, 1-5 squad leaders, etc. -There is a commander role. The commander is responsible for calling in aerial recon (to reveal enemy locations), force respawning (to support a large push against a capture point), and various types of artillery. Artillery coordinates must be requested from squad leaders, which further illustrates the team aspect of this game.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2015
												This game is hands down my favorite FPS game of all time. Granted customization isnt entirely great you have a few different weapons for each class and unlock the weapons for the other factions as you level each class (as well as stat improvement and attachments) but outside of that there is'nt anything. The combat and graphics make up for that by leaps and bounds.    The combat is very immersive and gets your blood pumping in intense situations. Storming a house/trench system, trying to defend and keep enemies out from your position, heart pumping close quarters combat not knowing who is around the corner or in the next room, the statisfaction you get when you pick some one off from over 100 meters away, how effective teamwork is and the impact it will make on how a round goes while trying to secure objectives or coordinate atry strikes.    Now the game can get very annoying and frustrating when your team is utter crap (like in every other game) since you can get locked down in the same spot and not be able to move or get any where without dying or your enemy just steam rolls through objectives. It is also a little difficult to tell the teams apart sometime but if you know the uniforms of the different nations its not bad. If you're new probably going to team kill often and really♥♥♥♥♥♥people off but its a learning curve.    The community is normally very helpful but also can be a little bit of eliteist sometimes. Its real easy to become a die hard fan of this game once you start getting decent and familarized with the game. So dont let some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s scare you off for TKing or not going for the right objective. TL;DR+great immersive combat/gameplay and graphics+a lot of realism and historicly accurate weapons/battles+huge battles and maps as well as small ones+chain of command from commanders to squad leaders with differing perks-very frustrating at first vs vet players-possible elitists getting angry at you for being new-low customization

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												The most hardcore of hardcore shooters. Steep learning curve. If you have the patience to stomach these particulars, you will definitely enjoy yourself immensely, once you are through with the first part of your learning phase, where you will die. And die. And... D-I-E.Up to 64 players per map, including a commander and squad leaders. Squads are made up of set numbers of each class, and are large, up to... I think 10 players a squad, counting the squad leader? The graphics are good, the sound is OK and the gameplay is where this ultra-realistic shooter shines. Where ArmA is a military simulation, this is a realistic shooter GAME.This is a very team-oriented game, the antithesis of COD and its rambo-style, 1-man-army gameplay.  Highly recommended, especially with the Rising Storm expansion, 8.5/10.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2016
												This is probably the best multiplayer shooter up to date. The game is semi-realistic, which means it tries to be both realistic and fast at the same time. A single bullet means death if it hits head, heart or lungs (in case of lungs it's not an immediate death though as you can still shoot while dying), but a bullet to less vital parts of a body will only cause a wound. A bullet shot into enemy's weapon will effectively disarm him. Granades are very deadly as they should be, which is important to mention, because in many games their effectiveness is downplayed. Wounded legs will slow you down, wounded arms will negatively affect your accuracy. The game is very fast as there are "tickets" that let players respawn until they run out, hence there usually isn't too much turtling and the game heavily discourages such tactics anyway due to maps, use of artillery and so on. Many maps allow multiple tactics as they usually allow two (sometimes even more) points to attack for a team, hence the defenders need to spread out, and attackers can decide where to focus on pushing the enemy forces. The game provides multiple classes to choose from, but the better and more important ones are limited, and interestingly not every player is equal - some get better weapons, some get worse, but also some are leaders, while others are cannon fodder. But it is fun regardless of what class you are playing (although you might have your favourite one). The game isn't about being the best in the team, it's about helping the team. It is very encouraged by the game's mechanics and affects the game in a very significant way, hence why the game doesn't play like another random multiplayer shooter #241221. It's unique in its own way. I definitely recommend it to everyone who enjoy multiplayer action games, regardless if they prefer realism or arcade, as this game is somewhere in-between (albeit inclines more towards realism than arcade). The only negative things I can say about this game is that albeit its realism, bullets do not penetrate objects (which is a serious flaw), and the fact that unlike previous games by Tripwire RO2 doesn't support anything besides Windows operating system.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												This game makes you feel rather like an insignificant infantryman. You run around, a shot cracks in the distance, and you fall over dead, often not even knowing where the shot came from.Red Orchestra 2 and Rising Storm are terrifyingly realistic. Players must account for bullet drop and taking cover is a must. Playing this game "CoD style", or running around the map shooting things, is a surefire way to kill yourself.The cover system is well implemented. Once in cover, a player can peek and fire, then duck back into hiding. Staying exposed for an extended period of time will draw the attention of a sniper you will be picked off from a distance. However, even when behind cover, there is always the fear of a stray grenade bouncing over to your location, or an artillery strike raining down over your position. You are almost never safe.The sound design in particular is superb, completely immersing you into the WWII battlefield. The crackle of gunshots, the screeching of artillery, your screaming comrades, and the shock of explosions all contribute to a pretty frightening war game.The game also has a relatively small but active multiplayer community. There are always some servers that have a few people. The rest of the spots are populated by bots. These AI are relatively decent. They do know to take cover and can usually shoot to some degree of accuracy.Gameplay itself is usually objective-based, encouraging players to play for their team rather than themselves. Killing enemies from or in an objective will earn a player more points, further discouraging people from playing "CoD style" and putting emphasis on teamwork.Overall, this game is not for the faint of heart, but people wanting a break from annually-photocopied generic FPS games will appreciate Red Orchestra 2/Rising Storm.Rating: PTSD/10

content:
Posted: January 16, 2015
												The best WWII shooter on the market, which is able to find a sweet balance between military simulations and arcade shooters. From the frozen battlefields of the eastern Front to the tropical vistas of the Pacific, RS/RO creates an immersive environment where every step and every shot are important. With a serious emphasis on teamwork, this shooter requires people to think before they act. This is no "lone wolf" type game. You may start feeling like a child who's lost its mother, but with time and experience, you may get to be an efficient killing machine. The only downside in this game must be the painful grinding for weapons. Though they are not dramatic COD like unlocks, they are quite difficult to get. The satisfying feeling of landing a head shot with a bolt action rifle on  a moving target 90 meters away will fuel many into losing themselves for hours in this game.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												Guys, this game is just amazig and awesome! U play either a german or a russian soldier in WW2. There are 3 gamemodes: 1st territory where the attackin team has to capture all of the enemys capzones; 2nd countdown where u have to capture more capzones during a given time then the enemy or 3rd firefight where you have to kill as many enemys as possible.If u are a fan of CoD or CS u probable wont like the game cuz its a bit slower and the grafic isnt so amazing as in other games. The realy good thing of the game is the atmosphere: the soldiers speak in their mothertongue, scream for help if their under fire or comment the battle. The second in my eyes good thing is the realism. here ur very often dead after one shot and if not ur health doesnt regenerate instead u have to dress ur wound before u bleed to death. the weapons are realistic too: the recoil is bigger as in other games and u have to aim carefully. hipfire should be only used when ur skilled enaugh. U also can upgrad weapons and soldierclasses (like rifleman or engineer) to get awards like bayonet for some weapons or more or bigger mags. there is a level system too wich goes from 10 to 99. After reaching 80 u can play the classes u skilled enaugh as a hero wich brings a lot of advantages (like resisting barrages longer (ur sight becomes grey if ure under barrages for longer then a few moments)). the maps are mostly very big but there are some small ones too if u like that more. if u should have played liked RO1 too u should love this game too (but I heard that a few RO1 fans dont like that game). its more dynamic and much faster. the last thing i want to tell u guys is that there is the addon Rising Storm wich plays in the Pacific theatre (USA against Japan) and brings new weapons and new features (Flamethrower/Banzaicharge) to the game. Another addon ("In Country:Vietnam") will be released in 2014. the only thing i dont like at the game are the bots. they re cannon fodder for disttances above 50 m (and waste reinforcements like this), quickscope u witch the second shot on under 50 m and are very dangerous in melee o.O All in all it just a great game and if u just have a bit of money ull have allot of multiplayer fun witch a lot of adrenalinkicks :D If u have any questions towards the game just messge me :Dhope u buy it all and cya in the game :D

												Amazing game, my top shooter for over 2 years now (look at my hours played - it says enough). This game has everything from COD-small sized maps with intense papasha slaughter (apartments) to maps featuring more "line" combat (pavlovs house, mamayev, winterwald) where the teams battle for those several meters, losing hundreds of soldiers just to get shelled by the enemy arty & have your point lost again by the defending forces, making you feel (atleast a tiny bit) how dreadfull, disgusting and annoying trench warfare/line warfare can be (hint: FLANKING). It even goes so far to very open & large maps such as mamayev kurgan, bridges of druzhina (if u don't keep your head down, you'll lose you head trust me) or barashka.Basically, for this price & if you're looking for a more realistic shooter where i've seen amazing pistol-aimed killshots from over 100 meter (which is pretty damn hard to get) to getting shot by pretty much any weapon means death, no "healthbar", i'd say buy this & buy the digital deluxe. It's only still 18 euro's/dollars (cheap compared to the next puked out COD for 60 + DLC - btw this game has FREE DLC) and you'll get the amazing AVT-40 & MkB42(z) (which is basically the prototype for the mp44) which give you quite the punch for your buck.10/10 by far, they really need to make maps as big as they got on battlefield with this game! (preferably with player controlled aircraft & MORE tanks, infantry vehicles etc...) then i'd just nerdgasm.PS: it also features class-based & squad-based gameplay with MG teams, snipers, assault teams, common rifleman, squad leaders and the team leader aswell in some cases a driveable tank (which has a hughe realistic feel to it hence u either pop your head out the tank making sweet shots for MG teams or snipers, or you look through the tiny peepholes in your tank, where a good AT soldier can shoot you through the peep hole or blow your tank up shooting at it's ammo racks under the top track a little bit to the left - resulting in a nice BANG "look at this ivan, it's christmas fireworks! MUAHAHAHAH")

content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
												Amazing game! Definitely blows COD and Battlefield out of the water! Good graphics, great gameplay, and a great sense of realism and teamwork is deffinitely required to accomplish anything, unlike most games these days. Add Rising Storm to the mix and BOOM you have the best WW2 FPS everymade! I just have one thing to say: Rifle grenades. I think they would be extremely handy and give the standard infantry a better chance against tanks. The could be an unlock for Elite Riflemen, or as and American counter to the Japanese knee-mortars in Rising Storm! Anyway, great game and by far one of my favorites!

												By far one of the most exciting, gripping and adrenalizing WW2 first person shooters! This game has so much oppertunities for tactical play and experience a whole new battlefield! Being able to charge over trenches with bayonets fixed, you don't know when you will be targeted! The machine gunner class is by far the most tense class. content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												Are you into amazing realistic World War 2 shooters ? Well this is the game for you. This game is defifnitely worth every penny, with amazing realism, gunplay, tactics, and community this is by far the best World War 2 game I have played since ArmA 2: I44.                             I reccomend the gamemodes: Realism and Campaign to be played together for the best experience of this game.Amazing Graphics, gunplay is smooth and realistic (guns also look top notch), characters are well textured.Set in the front line of Stalingrad this game opens a whole new world to realism players having the bold action of battlefield and the tactical realism of ArmA its a must buy game, very enjoyable with friends but also brilliant without. Most servers are good and you should probably add the best to your favourites, in the best servers players communicate and squad/team leaders work well together.Graphics: 8/10Realism: 9.5/10Gunplay: 10/10Emmersion: 10/10Overall Game: 10/10

Posted: March 25, 2016
												PTSD Simulator: as portrayed in these videos... 


YouTube™ Video: Red Orchestra 2 Deaths 

			Views: 29,857		

			This game covers one aspect of the the "war" simulation I've never seen done before, deaths. It's brutal at times.		




YouTube™ Video: Red Orchestra 2 - The Last Stand 

			Views: 13,306		

			*Heavily Breathing* The Russian attack on Myskova river completely failed with the red army being completely smashed to 0 tickets and 11 men remaining and with the Germans still with 80 tickets...		

Seriously though, this is the most immersive FPS I have ever played. It rewards twitch and accuracy skills as well as the ability to be in the right place at the right time.

												史上最强二战模拟游戏的续作。虽说向游戏性做出了妥协，但在许多方面还是有不小的进步的。武器模型更真实、配件更丰富，可损毁的建筑，小队指挥系统，动态提示系统，武器的多种状态切换等。另外全新成长系统，给了玩家长久玩下去的目标。现在BUG已经很少了，这么多年了，还在持续增加新地图、新模式也真不容易啊。在线战役的大坑居然也给填上了。我见过最良心的开发组。

content:
Posted: June 10, 2016
												While being on Soviet side, I see my comrade getting shot next to me. I hold tightly my rifle while hearing german words being yelled around me and ammo is getting low. German officer shows up from stairs and I yell "Friendly! Friendly! I love Germany!" and then being shot on back. I absolutely love this game. Fights can be tense sometimes and holding line is furious to last man. Building fights have caused several heartattacks on me because never can know who comes behind corner. You need to be patience tho, this is not rush and run game where you can absorb tens of bullets. One shot and you are dead. Community is quite nice, alive and decent, only met few trolls during game play. Tutorial was clumsy tho and I learned most of things by just going into fight. People are always helping new ones so dare to ask. If you love FPS and WW2, this is totally game for you. My only complain on this game is that it love to crash often. :(

content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
												When looking at games that are not as endorsed as most mainstream FPS games (Bioshock, Call of Duty, and Battlefield), this game falls short of mechanics.  The mechanics of this game are not bad, but campared to the smoothness of the mainstream games they are a little bit on the weak side. This is not a reason to not buy this game though because where the mechanics fall short, the gameplay and community are a lot better. This game takes a lot more skill than running around and shooting people. There are tactics involved in playing this online. After killing an enemy in this game, you feel like you've accomplished something campared to going 30-4 in Call of Duty. Now I am not a huge FPS person, but I do highly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												THIS GAME IS:10% luck20% SKILL15% CONCENTRATED POWER OF WILL5% PLEASURE50% PAINAND 100% REASON TO PURCHASE THE GAME.*Shamelessly ripped from another review.Anyways, this game is more than 20% skill, and certainly more than 20% luck. It is a simulator, not a game, in the same vein as ARMA II. Varying bullet velocities, ballistic drops, lack of a HUD must be taken into account at all times. Further, floating names over allies are rare, meaning that every shot could result in teamkill if the target itself isn't verified. Each game is a battle of impulse and reflex as any FPS, but also of tactics and strategy, and most importantly of teamwork and situational awareness. Every corner is meticulously checked, every seemingly empty field is avoided or scoured, every street is treated as a funnel. Think fast, act fast, or die fast. It IS that simple.

content:
Posted: April 3
												A breddy gud WWII shooter with a lot of good ideas but it's held back by some major flaws.Red Orchestra is as authentic as a multiplayer WWII shooter can get, if you can ignore the constant nazi-bolshievek arguments that keep appearing in the chatbox. In any server with more than 20 people you're going to pick up the rifleman role or any of the lesser roles, gamechanging roles like marksman, commander and machine gunner are few in numbers and the entire game can hinge on how well those players can make use of their roles. Everyone else is just cannon fodder, you go out, try pick off as many as you can but you're going to end up getting shot from someone you can't see. It sounds infuriating but it's really fun. The large numbers of soldiers, the wide open maps, the look of the game, the way it plays all lend to the immersion. When you're hold up on the second floor of a bombed-out building with artillery dropping around you while you put a few rounds into the gut of a German who entered downstairs and you hear him scream for a full 15 seconds that's when you know you're having fun.This game has some really obvious problems and they do ruin the fun. The main one being that this game just isn't fluid at all, movement is clunky and often unreliable, simple inputs like switching weapons often requires multiple attempts if you're doing anything else at the same time, it's so easy to interrupt reloads unintentionally without even realising. It doesn't feel fair if I die because I ran out of ammo and switching to my secondary took me a full ten seconds to do because moving slightly to the left is apparently too much for the game to handle. Some maps have some serious balancing issues too, although I know it was probably difficult to find a good spot between realistic and fair but it's frustrating when the 10 servers with more than 10 players are all playing the same 3 maps with those issues. The game also doesn't explain a lot, I still have no clue what value there is in levelling up weapons, I still don't know why I'm given the option to bandage an injury only to find out I've wasted 15 seconds because it was pointless and I had to watch my screen just slowly fade to black, I still don't know how to complete certain objectives and I still don't understand certain leader functions. It's one thing for a game to not hold your hand, it's another for a game to just not explain basic things.Either way it's pretty fun and is usually cheap.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												It was around noon. I was running towards the bridge with a comrade. Suddenly, we heard a yelling, and a german tank with a machine gun has started shooting at us. My comrade's body was painted fully red by his blood, and he fell down. I had no time to think. I had to continue running towards the water. That was my last chance. As a bullet hit my leg, I jumped into the muddy swamp. I had finally survived, I thought.. I crawled under the bridge, and started bandaging my leg.. I had a few minutes to rest, but I had to continue. I saw a little island with some bushes. Perfect place to launch a surprise attack. As I have approached the bushes, I saw two small holes, dug for probably the same reasons I wanted to use it for. I climbed down, put down my bandages, my ammo, and started scouting the bridge. I saw two panzers move through, and approaching my comrades. I have also saw two snipers and one machinegunner moving under the bridge. I quickly loaded my Mosin Nagant, and aimed. I thought about the chance of escaping: No, that would be appropriate for the traitors. I will never leave my comrades behind.So I took an aim and shot them. They fell one-by-one. One shot, one kill, they say. And nobody has noticed me. I sat there for a few minutes. Thinking about the chances of a surprise attack. As my comrades were rushing towards the bridge, I took my rifle and loaded it with my last magazine. I took an aim for the sniper on the german end of the bridge: His helmet flew away, and he fell off the bridge.My comrades were able to finally pass the panzers, and occupy the bridge. However, I was sure I couldn't survive for too long. Suddenly, voice of an engine started becoming louder and louder. It was surely in my vicinity. As I stood up, I saw a panzer, coming right for me. People say that the death is quick. It took approximately 0,5 seconds for the tank to crush my whole body. But, in the end, I was happy that I was able to help my team to reach victory. After all, that is what matters, right?And, guys, imagine: That was just a 10-minute-slice from a multiplayer match. Amazing game, 10/10.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2013
												A World War 2 era combat simulator, RO2 entails eastern front battles between Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union. Highly realistic gameplay mechanics leave no room for silliness on the battlefield! While the single played is a time waster, multiplayer is where the heart of the game is.Rising Storm is a reskinned addon which includes new maps and weapons based on the pacific battles between Imperial Japan and (Imperial) US. Each RO2 buyer can play on RS maps but can only play as a rifleman.It is worthy to mention that this game has been updated countless times with new weapons and maps - all of which were free.The price of this game alone is enough to justify a purchase.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2016
												The best shooter known to manThis game is unforgiving, brutal, complicated and gives you no ♥♥♥♥ing quarter at all. However its also intense af and the lads from Tripwire put a lot of detail into everything. You drop dead the second an enemy looks at you. The guns feel great and anything that fires more than 1 bullet per minute is very hard to control. The command and class system is great. With the commander really being important and not just a cheap excuse to harvest kills with artillery strikes. Maps are well designed although sadly only a small percentage is actually played. Sound design is exceptional too everyone screams 24/7 either because your♥♥♥♥♥got torched by a flamer or youre giving orders. The community is great. If you thought  youve seen everything fire this game up and enjoy the voicechat. Its either a) 20 people talking about how uncle Adolf could have won the war or b) someone playing the national anthem of the Soviet Union performerd by the choir of the Red Army and 20 people singing along. With option 2 only taking place if youre currently defending the soil of RODINA from the grasp of some fashist svoloch. A very underrated game really. Pick it up.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												This game can be pretty intimidating at first and you'll probably die a lot before you even see enemy soldiers. It's really based more on knowledge than raw skill. You don't need to have good twitch reflexes (though they can help) to be a good player. You need to know how the maps work, where your team needs you most, when to move, and how to not die. Generally one side attacks and one side defends. It is crucial to coordinate with your team, especially while attacking. There definitely seems to be a strong correlation between how many knowledgeable guys on your team are using microphones and how often your team wins. If somebody says "Everybody needs to bonzai charge the cap zone NOW!" you'll be surprised how quickly 20 or so Japanese soldiers are screaming into the smoke straight into the cap. You don't need to use a mic yourself, but you'd be wise to listen at least some of the time to your teammates advice (don't worry about the crazy guy that is screaming nonsense at his computer).Overall it's a very fun game but has it's problems. Single player is pretty much non-existent if you care about that, the movement feels a little clunky and can be awkward when a player interacts with the level geometry. They unnecessarily split up the game into "action" and "realism" modes when it's obvious this game caters to the realism audience. It lacks some polish, but it's not a $60 huge budget game so that's to be expected. There could be more maps and more vehicles, especially the latter which have been neglected since the first RO.All in all, a good game at a good price.

												Tired of having to buy extra DLC just to feel like you are getting the full expeience? Or perhaps you are tired of the enemy soaking up bullets and never actually dying.Either way this game overcomes such issues and goes beyond anyother FPS game I have seen before. The stunning attention to detail in the animations and models is a joy to see and the maps feel realistic. There is also a fear present in this game, something that most other games lack, a knowledge that you could be shot from out of nowhere or that you could have been flanked without seeing it.On top of all of that the community is fantastic and there will always be people trying to commuincate in game. So would I recommend this game?Yes whole heartedly, it is always enjoyable.

												Personally i find Rising Storm/Red Orchestra 2 as the sweet spot between simulation/realism and action game.I cant think of any other WWII game that came recently to replace RO2, it is the best WWII FPS out there and its a great game in its own category. number of helpful: 10 of 16 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 17, 2016
												I bought Rising Storm--a separate entity and was introduced to the Red Orchestra series through Rising Storm. From my experience, it's very difficult for new players to get acclimated to how this game feels because the only servers available now are Realism servers where everything is mostly one-shot kills and it's very difficul to tell where you're being shot from. Probably one of the most annoying aspects of the game is the feeling of hopelessness as you stare around, not really knowing where you need to aim and then you just get picked off. Most of the time, I spent hiding behind a wall, in bushes, and in unconventional places in order to just not get picked off. It's very frustrating when you have to wait 10-15 (sometimes even longer) seconds to respawn and as you're running into the objective, you get picked off.As in many competitive multiplayer games, the community is what makes or breaks it and this game has one of the most toxic playerbases I've ever encountered. No, not everyone I've come across was toxic but it's very demoralising when you see "None of you f---s are playing the objective!" every single time your team loses a round of Territory. New players are turned off by clunky the movement is, frustrated by flamethrowers, and upset when they voice their opinion and are immediately shot down by the veteran players for being noobs. The community is driving away the new players and is slowly dying in the process as the game ages.Because new players are being driven away, there's only a handful of servers with a big enough population to actually play on while the rest are empty or are filled with bots. These handful of servers are all in Realism mode and all of them are Territory. There's no variety, no different game types, and only a handful of classes to choose from each of which have two primaries to choose from. Despite all these negative things about the game, not everything was entirely bad. Realism mode is a double-edged sword because even though you are easily killed, so are your enemies. There's something extremely satisfying about firing a bolt-action rifle and seeing your opponents just drop immediately. The game's sound is top-notch and comparable to that of Battlefield 1. Every gun sounds meaty. The sound of a headshot is awesome. Racking your gun sounds real. I can't say enough about how good this game really sounds.Even though all you can play is Territory, it really isn't a bad game mode. I like that it's unique compared to many of the other FPS game types out there and it does a decent job of simulating realism in how reinforcements and supplies work. The two teams will get a limited number of supply points that slowly trickle down each round you play as your team takes casualties and the game ends when one side loses all of their supply points. When you're in the game, you will get spawned in waves in order to simulate reinforcements, which adds a tactical element to the game because your Team Leader (TL) can force a respawn wave in order to hopefully stop the advancing enemy enemy or to overwhelm a defending team. There is no other game out there where it's as satisfying when successfully playing the objective but that's probably because it's so damn hard to actually play the objective. No other game has managed to keep me so stressed out as I play because I'm so worried about getting shot from any direction.Although  I had fun playing this game sometimes, my final verdict for this game is -NOT RECOMMENDED for players new to the Red Orchestra franchise- mainly due to the clunky movement, dying playerbase, and high learning curve that discourages new players.

number of helpful: 10 of 16 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												This game is incredible. I haven't enjoyed playing a game this much in a long time. You can play as a Commander class which can call in recon planes, mortor bombardment, arty etc. You can be a squad leader which allows your squad to spawn on you and you can mark areas of the map for the commander to call in a bombardment. Or you can be a soldier, choose your "class", rifleman, assault, sniper, machine gunner etc. There are a good amount of weapons, the maps are large but easy to learn and they are open enough to using flanking tactics. Rising Storm as amazing. Here is just one tiny part on one map during one match that took place:I was playing as the Allies and we were fighting fiercly to take an enemy position that was heavily fortified. As we approached our Squad Leader marked the position and told the Team Leader over comms it was marked. The Team Leader confirmed, calling in a recon plane and dropped arty. Everyone took cover as we watched explosions landing just ahead. Round after round hit, dirt flying up in the air. Our next wave of reinforcements had arrived and were crossing the river to meet us on the far bank closest to the enemy. All of a sudden we hear "Arty has been cancelled, push forward" and with that everyone got off their bellies and charged into the trenches, bayonets ready, itchy triggy fingers awaiting the huge onslaught, expecting heavy losses.. and.. and... nothing. There were no enemies. None. Where were they? We quickly moved throughout the fortified position, taking positions facing outwards for any glimpse of our opponent. After taking a nice spot behind some sandbags that were stacked up with a good view hole to see into the jungle, I took a knee thinking what they could be planning.I hear movement in the jungle, then I hear screaming.. "Booonzaiiiii" I take aim and start firing. There are so many, rifles pointed our way, bayonets fixed and they are charging right at us screaming. I pop off a few rounds and take down two of them when I see an officer with a sword leading the charge. I Line up my rifle to take him out, and I die. They had surrounded us and a few of them broke through on my right flank, rushing through the trenches swords swinging and bayonets stabbing everything in their way.I respawned and the battle continued. With moments like this happening all the time, I don't know how this game isn't more widely talked about. Incredible experience that everyone should try.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
												It's my understanding that this is the review for this game (That may be utter rubbish but I saw no other reviews!) so let's make it a good one, 'eh?I absolutely love this game. As a fan of war games, FPSs, history, military and general gaming this game is sublime. It truly conveys the horrors of war to the player, which is something most FPSs avoid in order to make their games more action-packed than strategic and atmospheric. There really aren't many games which would make you want to sit in your little foxhole for a bit longer in fear of getting up and being torn apart by machine-gun fire. This is made even more amazing with the fantastic cover system, where you can cover behind almost anything effectively. 9/10 - A fantastic and sometimes terrifying war experience with amazing combat and atmosphere.

												It would be fair to say the Red Orchestra player is a niche market, however the gritty and often grimm action of the first game is faithfully enhanced; both gameplay and graphics have been improved and although the unreal engine looks good enough it may be enough to deter the pretty boy gamer. This is a shame as this game offers one of the most authentic WW2 shooter experiences ever concieved! Both tense infantry battles and epic tank engagements feature heavilly in Red Orchestra 2, on the ground the horror of war is unleashed with good visuals, sounds and plausible environments. And in the tank the player feels claustrophobic, trapped and confined although possesing some serious firepower the tank crew must work as a team to be effective. All in all an ultra realistic take on WW2 from both the Soviet and Axis perspectives, a must for 3rd person shooter multiplayer nuts...

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												Ill start this review by saying that Ive played a great deal of WWII games in my time, including franchises such as Medal of Honor, Brothers in Arms, Call of Duty, Day of Defeat, and many other small companies many people probably haven't heard of. After all of this times spent on WWII gaming (as it is a historical interest of mine as well) I had lost a bit of my interest. Red Orchestra, however, reinvigorated my passions by delivering a realistic and unique shooter. Although the single player campaign is fun to play, most gamers will find the most fun in the multiplayer. The game blends class-based skills and teamwork on detailed maps that will bring you as close as you would want to be to the Eastern Front. Sometimes you will experience weapon jams, suppressing fire, fatigue, and non-lethal wounds that you cannot simply walk away from. For example, if you are hit in the leg while sprinting from cover, you will slow down or even stop, simulating something that most franchises cannot. I will end the review with some simple advice: If you are looking for another Call of Duty, don't look here. Play Red Orchestra for the realism and the unique fun that it offers.Its also basically a PTSD simulator

content:
Posted: June 14, 2016
												While I only have a small amount of time put into this game so far, I can say that I am very, very happy with my purchase. RO2/RS has to be one of the most fun games I've played in a very long time.This game can be rage inducing...This game can be unfair at times......but, it never seems that I didn't have a chance to do better.For instance, I was playing as the Russians on a snow map where we had to push uphill to capture 12 german points in a manner similar to Rush from the battlefield series. I popped my head out, and got sniped. If I thought my plan through, I could've made my way to a hill with more trees on it that would provide cover, but I wasn't thinking as smartly as I could have been.Another thing that I like about this game that I find lacking in other games is teamwork. I don't just mean talking to your teammates and maybe executing team strategies (like in CSGO), but an unspoken teamwork. I never used my microphone, and nor did most of the other players that I played with, but we moved as a group, attacked as a group, and died as a group. Whenever someone pushed up, there were other players that instantly assisted in the push, instantly covered those pushing, and, in my case, take a bullet for a teammate (accidently, but still saved someone in a videogame. ARE YOU PROUD OF ME YET MOTHER!?).The only cons I can think of about this game are the learning curve, team-killing (which is apart of the learning curve in some way), and the optimization. This game can be brutally unforgiving. If you are looking for an arcade game that doesn't really take any skill to dominate, go play one of the recent CODs. This game has a damage model that is basically 1 bullet, 1 kill (in most everycase), but if you somehow survive being shot, you have to find cover and use one of the 2 bandages that you spawn in with everytime. Team killing plays into the learning curve because you have to be able to distinguish who is a friend and who is a foe, which can be difficult in some of the maps where both teams have similar clothing. The game also has some fps drops now and then, but that could just be my system, so take that con with a pinch of salt.Overall, I would have to say that if you are looking for an experience in between Battlefield and ArmA (like Insurgency, but a little bit more so), then this is the game that you probably are looking for. If you do get it, I recommend getting the bundle, because then you will be able to play both Red Orchestra 2 (Eastern Front | Germans and Russians) and Rising Storm (Pacific Campaign | American and Japanese) within the same game. This game is a must have for any FPS player, but take what I said (or typed) with a pinch of salt considering I have just under 3 hours played. I do not believe that my score will go down, but I have a feeling that as I play, the score may increase a bit. Oh, and this game has the best flamethrower that I've ever seen in a video game.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												Can't say I have ever played a better FPS shooter, or, at least, a shooter that has given me this much appreciation towards it. RO2 is by no means a normal FPS, it is hard, it is intense, and it is realistic. You'll find yourself mercilessly get killed if you are only just jumping in, and it doesn't take too long to realize the game requires you to play smart, calculatively, and, most of all, as a team, to do well. There is no room for those who play twitch "I shot you first I win" or lonewofl FPS players in RO2.It's hard for me to actually write a review for RO2 now what I got this far, simply because the game is just simply matching my taste in FPS, and that should actually be what it comes down to if you're trying you decide if you want to buy this game. If you think you'd enjoy a realistic, difficult, and challenging, but a rewarding, fun, and intense game with emphasis on teamplay and strategy, I want to say that you will almost certainly enjoy this game. If none of those sound like the type of game you'd enjoy, and you prefer games like BF3, COD, or CS, this game either isn't for you or will be a rough transition. content:
Posted: April 13, 2013
												I am really happy to own Red Orchestra 2. Unlike most WW2 era games, it stands out. There is a lot of depth and realism packed into an otherwise standard genre that’s been covered a hundred times before. Smart gameplay choices and a clearly dedicated group of developers have given this game more than meets the eye.Red Orchestra 2 is such a fun multiplayer game. I just want to emphasise that before I continue because I’m constantly thinking about when I can continue playing it again. It’s more than just your standard WW2 shooter that pits two teams against one another and whoever kills the most, wins. Tripwire Interactive have considered other aspects of warfare during the Second World War, to make the game feel genuine, realistic, and most important of all, unique.I’ll start with the basics. The game is built to be realistic and therefore features a minimal hud, no crosshair, different stances, and even a “scare factor” (but I’ll get into that later). As you move around the battlefield, your character pants and bobs and holds their breath before shooting at the enemy. There’s a decent ADS(aim down the sights) system that is effected depending on which stance you are in, standing, crouching, or prone. You have to manually check the amount of bullets in your weapon and manually reload when you’re dry. You can use cover to hide or peak,  and sprint while crouched to give yourself more cover whilst moving. All these basic functions add intensity to FPS multiplayer that is unmatched in all other games I’ve played.  The game has incredibly large maps to further emphasise the realism that you’re on a battlefield and there are many ways to approach the situations in front of you. You actually have to think about things tactically instead of just running in there and hoping for the best. There are good areas to run to, and bad areas to avoid.It’s a very team oriented experience. You get to rush trenches with your friends, you get to defend church towers with them, crawl in the mud with them, and a lot of the time get killed with them. The element of teamwork is key to success so if you have a bad team, you’re going to have a bad game. Depending on which team you choose, you can hear different dialogue between your friends and your own character. If you play on the Russian team, everything the German team says will be in German and vice versa if you’re on the German team. The vocal reactions between your character and your teammates is really a great little addition to the realism. They automatically let you know what’s going or express how they’re feeling about things that happen around them. It all makes for a very visceral experience. So now I will move onto the star of the show, something I like to call the “scare factor”. There’s a little bar above your stamina meter that lets you know how mentally stable your character is. As you get shot at or witness teammates getting killed, this bar will drop, your vision will blur, and your weapon will shake. Even when the artillery comes raining down on you, your characters starts shaking and you feel truly helpless. I love this, it really captures the intensity of war and makes me feel as though I’m right there with him. The graphics are incredible, utilizing an enhanced version of the Unreal 3 engine to make some of the most atmospheric battlefields I’ve ever seen.Red Orchestra 2 is not for everyone. It’s a realistic war experience, not COD. Of course there will be many who won’t like it at all, but I’m not one of them (despite the enjoyment I get from COD). If you’re looking for something different and certainly something to remember, this game is for you :)

content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												One of THE best games ever. The combat is so much better than most other FPS games I have played. I have been craving a game that allows you to blind fire since I played Killswitch on the PS2 . And this game allows you do just that! you can throw grenades around corners without exposing yourself either. Machineguns overheat and if you continue to fire the barrel warps and you have no choice but to change it. Commanders can use binoculars to spot and call in Recon which flies over head and shows where the enemy is but only on the map and the commander has access to Mortars, Artillery and Rocket Barrage to wreck havok on the battlefield.The suppression system is very well made  shoot some bullets at an enemy and his aim will be too shaken to aim back and then you can deliver the final blow. Now that is realism! The lack of vehicles for a game thats been out this long is the only thing I really hate about this game at this point. I wish they would make more, but I have heard that they are not making more as they are working on a Vietnam game can anyone confirm this as I really wanted to see a Tiger in this new Ro2. The bullet drop works well but there are few maps where you can use anything more than 400m I have only been able to use the Bullet Drop to effect on several maps. I can only really vouch for the Axis as I have only played for the Axis on the Eastern front and Allies for the Pacific Campaign. To the Pros and ConsProsTHIS IS A TEAM GAME - Blind fire System that acutally works.- If you don't use teamwork you will fail!- Tank Battles are awesome.- Leveling system is great.- Mulitple game modes - Working Bullet physics- You can yell Most Dishonorabr in Rising stormand everyone will start yelling similar things and laugh with you USUALLY- You can Nut shot people with bullets. (you can tell when you see a cracked acorn icon for a kill message)Cons-Japanese get a knee mortar that can get really annoying after you get killed multiple times.-Finding servers with ping near you is a MUST if you are to get a kill as you must aim in front of someone to compensate for the high ping if you are to kill anything if you do join a high ping server.-The grind gets really old after a while.-2 types of tanks for each side in the Eastern Front side and a 1 transport. No vehicles in Rising Storm.
