content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
												UNBELIEVABLE.Rising Storm/Red Orchestra 2: Heroes of Stalingrad is the sequel/expansion spinnoff to the original Red Orchestra.The game is a World War 2 First Person Shooter designed to be multiplayer only, with a singleplayer "campaign" against bots.If this sounds boring, it's only because this has been done SOOOO many times before.So what makes this game stand out from the masses? 2 main things:1) The painstakingly historical accuracy2) FUNRed Orchestra, while somewhat obscure, has always been reccognised by those who know about it for it's historicaly accurate portrayal of World War 2. Red Orchestra 2/Rising Storm continues this tradition to the (somewhat) extreame.This is no Call of Duty, and this is no Battlefield. The only thing "Battlefieldly" in this is the hellhole of chaos that happens on the maps. While it doesn't have the Blockbuster-like fun of World At War, and without the characters and story of Brothers In Arms, Red Orchestra 2 is more of an interesting history discussion than a movie or book. If you are someone who enjoys history discussions, then you will like this a LOT.Red Orchestra 2 is set in 1940-1942 on the Eastern Front, and portrays historical battles in it's multiplayer matches, where you play the grunts and soldiers sent into the meat grinder for the Russian/German war machine.Don't worry: it's not like it's going to be a documentary with someone from the History channel commenting on your every action: it's more of a WW2 Simulator, and not one of the bad ones.Let's get into the meat of what it has to offer: While there is the "Normal" style of play, which is very much like Call of Duty, the MAJORITY (94%) of the players are playing on the "Realism" mode (The way is was ment to, and should be, played)The game uses a minimalist HUD, with UI only popping up when neccisary. Seeing as this is so close to real life, there is no Health bar: You die in a SINGLE BULLET, to the head, chest, and groin. If hit in the arms and legs; you either use a bandage (which takes time to put on, and can only be done twice) or you bleed out to death as the screen goes dark, and everything goes quiet. The weapons are awesome. In "Realism" there is not crosshair, meaning you have to use ironsights, and blind fire is about as effective as harsh language. All weapons have accurate recoil, modeling, sound effects, damage (Rifles kill in 1 shot anywhere, machine guns are similary powerful)and animation. Like how you not only have to reload machineguns; you have to change the barrel if they overheat. Or how you can toggle the Scope or Ironsights on a sniper weapon. Or how you can't ironsight a machinegun unless they are mounted on cover.There are various classes in each team, each with different weapons and ablities, so how many weapons you have depends on your choice. Ultimatley you can carry a maximum of 2 primary weapons, 2 pistols, 2 grenades of 2 types (Smoke or Frag), and (depending on class) binoculars. You can't have every weapon in each class, so you have to find them on dead bodies.The Movemnt is nothing short of amazing: you can sprint forever, but your soldier tires out after a few seconds, so your walking speed is faster then sprinting. You can stand, croutch, go prone, and lean. Your movement depends on your weapon that you are holding, so you don't feel, like in Halfe-Life, that you are a floating orb zooming around everywhere; instead you feel like a human snotling, lugging around a heavy firearm. The game also has a First Person Cover System, where you can latch onto walls. floors, and in trenches. You can blind fire around cover, or use Ironsights to peak out, but it makes you visable and you probably will get shot. Sounds like ARMA, but plays a lot differently.The battlefield is a scary place, full of mines, barbwire, trenches, buildings, and corners for enemies to hide in. Smoke, dirt, and body parts fly up in the air, as a commander calls in an artillery strike from a radio. With this comes problems however, because the environments are ususally the same colour as the players, so it is VERY dificult to tell apart the Grey team from the Slightly Orangey-Brown team. Friendly fire is always on, so you will be seeing frequent use of "sorry" in the chats.While the game is realistic, it also means you won't be killing many people. The game wants you to make a last stand against an enemy and preform a heroic sacrifice, like the real heroes of the war, but it doesn't realise that 90% of the time, you will be behind a wall/box/cover, crying for your momy, while you soil your pants.And finally: TANKS. Not the normal tanks: FIRST PERSON TANKS.All the tanks have a first person modeled interior, with the commander, gunner, driver, loader, and radio operator, all cramped inside this steel beast, with interactable pistol-ports, and parascopes all present. As you see the loader refill your tank gun with either High Explosive or Armour Piercing rounds, you feel like Steel Batalion, and that you are really driving around a sluggish piece of metal with death able to come in an eyeblink.A very immersive and impressive experience then. Red Orchestra 2 might not be the same for veterans and purists of the original, but to newcomers, Red Orchestra 2 is a very profesional game with a high skill level and a ton of fun to play. and for $20USD, you are getting 300+ hours of experience (while I haven't reached that far myself)At the other end of the spectrum there is Rising Strom; the standalone expansion to Red Orchestra 2, and a damn good one at that.This time it's the Pacific front, with Uncle Sam going against Tojo in a head-on turkey shoot, with the Yanks and the Japs in the firing line (Americans VS Japanese)The gameplay is basically the same as Red Orchestra 2's, with the only changes being American/Jap weapons, No tanks (sad face :( ) and MUCh less of asymetrical gameplay. The American side is VASTLY overpowered with Thompsons and Flamethrowers, and can steamroll the Japs, sometimes.SOMETIMES.The Japs are more specialised, and they are able to plant booby traps-and they have Swords.Yes you weeabo nitwits: THEY HAVE KATANAS, and they can do morale sapping BANZAI!! charges against the Yanks.While not that effective, it is AWESOME when it pays off.Rising Strom is also much easier than Red Orchestra 2 for newcomers, and it isn't as... "grimdark" as the Eastern FrontBut Rising Storm is a VERY good EXPANSION PACK (not DLC) and you are getting an entire full game for half the price.To conclude: Rising Storm/Red Orchestra 2 is a VERY intense and fun game, that sinks it's teeth into you, and never lets you go, if you let it. If you ever wanted to play a game that REALLY simulates World War 2 the RIGHT way, then you have found the Holy Grail.Easily a 4.5/5[And as a side note: one of the mods for this game: "Heroes of the West" simulates the Western Front with the Americans against the Germans. It's still in progress, so it's not ready yet. but deffinatley something to look forward to if you get this game][Also: the best server for the game is Merrill's Marauders Pacifiic/Stalingrad campaign. Check them out on their website at http://www.475thrangers.com/ (Seriously it's worth it) ]

												This game is amazing!! Recently i upgraded my computer and the first game i thought i should play was RO2/RS and oh boy it treated me nice. If you love war games with a realistic touch to them, RO2/RS is the way to go.                 -PROS--Great Graphics (Maxed out for me)-Realism (I get the chills when i'm being suppressed)-So much action you can't get enough!-Easy controls (I'm a fast learner so i got attached quickly)-64 players-Good Community-Still being updated                -Cons--Alot of servers lag, (EX: Server browser says 24 ping, in game 215+ even the closest one for me *Chicago* has a ping on 150+Buy it you wont regret it if your into that realism :)

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												I'm addicted to this game. I enjoy it alot and recommend to anybody who likes action and realism.Reasons:- no 3rd person, so no everpresent jackassing known in Arma 3- HUD is hidden most of the time, improving the immersion much.- difficult to play, but very rewarding both wits & skills- TANKS that are quite realistic and enjoyable- no better multiplayer game focused on infantry and combined operations at this moment. Sorry, BF3/BF4 is fun for boys.Being addicted to RO2 doesn't mean I don't see its flaws. Quite many of them actually:- lame interface programming- lack of positional voice communications (ACRE!)- no simulation of speed of sound- Hollywood bullet whizzing instead of sonic cracks- role voting has been removed- poor network coding (in MP game!) - lots of presumably local events must be confirmed by server.- no automatic detection of possible weapon support positions- realism suffers from streamlining: people sprint unbelievably fast to increase tension; bullets fly faster than IRL to counterbalance it..- leveling leads to absurdal situations; lvl 50 machine guns can be fired with almost no penalty from hip- using meelee makes your character stop in place- cannot throw grenades away- cannot throw satchel charges away- tanks are coded awfully to say the least- only two types of tanks, no APCs, cannonsOverall: Good

content:
Posted: April 1
												------------------LETTER TO MILENKA, YEAR 1945------------------------Hello my dear Milenka:I miss you. I miss you every single day in this battlefield.I'm really scared. Scared because I don't know when I will take a bullet to my head as some of my lovely comrades did. I still can remember Pyotr, it was horrible. He was next to me, it happened so fast that I couldn't even react. We were in some building in Spartanovka, and I was shi-tting my pants in a corner when he came running to help me. Pyotr knew how to choose his words to cheer me up: "noob team we can't win. X TOY MACHIINE WHAT ARE YOU DOIN IN THE CORNER CY-KA BLY-AT. CY-KA BLY-AT IDI NA-HUI YOU FUKN IDI-OT". I was proud of him after that, he was a true alpha a true leader that would lead Russian army to the victory. But then, in half a second; bullet sounds were around us, and Pyotr was in the floor, splitting blood while his eyes stared at me. I couldn't handle my tears and I ran to him, kneel down and heard his last words: "AFK" while he passed out. I will never forget Pyotr voice. I will never forget the love I feel for you.All yours,---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

content:
Posted: August 7, 2013
												This game is fantastic. You get a vague feeling of really being on the eastern front / pacific theater. You will need both your eyes and ears when playing this game. What is even better is that the game is like a living museum in some way. Weapons sound different, depending on their kind and even their distance. After a bunch of games, you might be able to hear if there are enemies or friendlies shooting near you. Then there are the amazingly detailed tanks and buildings. Some maps can look familiar if you've seen some Stalingrad documentaries.There is a steep difficulty curve. You can't just go Rambo on everyone. Knowing your weapon and the aprox. magazine size is also vital for your survival. Give it a try at a free weekend before buying.MP40 double magazine was here; PPSH can go have intercourse with itself

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2014
												The first thing that I'm going to say in this review is that you will die in this game. A LOT. However, thats some of the fun as you learn to master covering from fire and tactics. I've got to say, after playing this game thus far, no other FPS I've ever played other than those of the ARMA franchise has come even close in terms of scale, realism, and strict reliance of teamwork. Yes, it might be a much slower paced shooter than your generic run and gun game, but the slower pace only helps to reinforce the realism of how war isn't all about just shooting the bad guys, but about tactics and teamwork. Without strong teamwork, you will almost always lose. The guns are all balanced and realistic with an interesting distance adjuster, and the way that the class system works, you always end up with a balanced team instead of a team filled with only snipers and machine gunners. The gunplay is fantastic, and the fact that there is a cover system, something sorely lacking in most modern military FPS's, was just icing on the cake for me. If you are even remotely interested in a historic military game or one based more on tactics than trigger fingers, then this is the game for you.

												This Game is a Masterpiece. I never felt so, so Sad about Soldiers being killed by either Gunshot Wounds or Explosions. This game isn't a Go Out, Guns Blazing! Nor is it an Easy Game to get through. No This is Red Orchestra: Heroes Of Stalingrad! Every Movement you make matters in this game. Every corner you turn decides your Fate. Every Descision you make determines the Fate of you and your Teammates. I highly recommend this Game. 10/10

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												I am a casual gamer and introduced to the franchise after RO2. This game started as a terrible game. Performance issues, balancing issues and all sorts of problems you can get from rushed launch. Tropwire took there sweet time to fix most of the lingering issues, but now I am saying with full confidence that this is one of the better FPS on PC. The whole experince is unique and shooting feels way more different then the likes of COD or BFs. Though community is small, but all of them are dedicated which results in faboulus gaming sessions. It has a slight learning curve and game dosent explain well the fundamentals. You need to learn it through Youtube are spending few hours in the game messing around. Basically it plays more like the RUSH mode from Battlefield series.SP and COOP portion of the game is as good as non existent. Game is regularly updated with new maps. Even a new DLC was given for free with slight restrictions. All in all I am a highly satisfied with the efforts of DEVS to improve the game.If you like FPS games with a slight learning curve and teamplay then this game is ideal for you.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												Why i Love Rising Storm!This is my favourite game of all time, Before i found rising storm i was a big strategy gamer mainly total war. Shogun 2 got me interested in the Japanese and i started having a look at its history. By early 2014 i was all the way into the Imperial Japan era and i wanted to play a game based around then. Now there really arent many games set in the pacific which is a shame since its such a interesting era and theatre of war but i managed to stumble across a game called Red Orchestra 2/Rising Storm. Now when i played this i was blown away....Not only did it not spam you with DLC it gave me both expansions for free! it was realisitic! proper bullet times and factors for each gun! each gun made in perfect detail with all its flaws and advantages as in real life, never has firing a type 38 arisaka or a kar98k been so entertaining in a game for me. even after playing all the maps hundreds of times it never gets old because the community is so fun.The team work is like no other. this isnt battlefield where everyone runs off doing their own thing people work together in this to achieve victory its simply amazing!. The native voice acting for the Germans Russians (American voices are pretty bad though) and Japanese is simply outstanding the japanese even have a Kansai dialect for added detail, its absolutely insane the gun play is awesome the push and shove of battle feels real. even when you see a flash 200m away and half a second later your dead does it not fail to impress. the realisim is done perfectly in time with the fun. Most of the few Pacific War games are rather historically innacurate without mods. But rising storm Nails everything prefectly (except for the SNLF having later date uniforms when they should have green but a mutator fixed this as well as being put on some servers) This Game to me is more immersive then a movie like saving private ryan its, i literally get excited to just jump on and play every time. I have even put 100 hours into the Steam Offline mode wih bots it never fails to entertain me.So people coming here looking for a reason to buy i guarantee you Rising Storm will not disapoint you if you want something realisitic and historically accurate. and for the fun its just so worth it.MUTATORS/MODS I RECCOMEND TO IMPROVE EXPERIANCE.Beta SNLF: This changes the Khaki SNLF skins to the correct for timeframe Green Naval Uniforms. this is literally the only gripe i have in the realisim department so i reccomend this if you want to see the Japanese Marines in the correct garb (the previous is also correct but like late 1945 not 1943)

												This is pretty much a multiplayer only game, reviewing it as such is crucial.  If you're looking for a single player experience, look elsewhere.  That being said, this game is amazing.  RO2 is a modern looking, realistic WW2 FPS.  Though it started out with more than a few bugs, it has been updated and polished quite nicely over the years.  Before I get into details, I'll also include that you will get to experience both the Eastern front as well as the island battles of the Pacific Theatre, easily one of the most unique features about this game.Gameplay is quite fluid.  Moving around the map, crouching, sprinting, all feel quite good and realistic.  Sounds, weapons, chatter, maps, and skins all create an immersive atmosphere.  The horrors of war will be on full display the minute you step into a populated server and you're going to love every second of it.Though the learning curve of RO2 is moderate to high for most, which I personally love, this is ultimately a game of realism.    You will most certainly die from one well placed shot, but you can also do alot of damage with one placed shot yourself.  Though, one man can do quite a bit of damage to the enemy if he knows what he's doing, this game stresses teamwork tactics and sticking close to your squad mates.  Getting into cap zones, and picking guys off from there is the name of the game.  Working with your teammates and coordination is key.  You won't find much in regards to Rambo'ing around the map as it simply won't work unless your an experienced veteran.Easily one of the more realistic WW2 shooters out currently.  I've played this game since launch, and over the last few years, the game has made great strides towards being very, very good.  With the most recent update, which included the release of the MG42, battles on the Eastern front feel about ten times more intense.  Worth every penny, would buy again.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												This game is the most immersive, engaging, atmospheric, and brutal WW2 shooter on the market. It's like every life you are the director of your own war movie but without the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ romance subplots. The pacing is brilliant, sometimes you will slowly moving up on the flank hearing a couple shots once in a while and a stray bullet might go over your head. Another time you will be pinned down by heavy fire in a foxhole with your friends just trying to desperately return fire. The sound design in this game is phenomenal, every bullet and gun has a brutal impact. The recoil is hefty and honest. The ragdolls are immersive especially the death screams and the way the bodies just lean against things just adds to the complete WW2 experience. Seriously addicting game. If you are a WW2 multiplayer fanatic and you haven't played this game, you are doing yourself a great dishonor.

content:
Posted: January 26
												No other game can sum up the experience of your first time logging into Red Orchestra 2. My own experience filled me with adrenaline, fear, and shock. Watching my Russian comrades screaming about the enemy tank coming down the road, getting sniped standing right next to me, and the wave of bullets that flew over head....it was amazing. This I consider to be on of the best realistic World War 2 games out there. I always play on a realism server, the action servers have less damage so putting 3 clips into a guy doesnt kill him....its crap, the only real way to exzperience this game is realism. The leveling up system for guns makes you better over time, and really makes you feel like you are a war vet slowly getting better at raging war. I would suggest this game to anyone looking for a good WW2 shooter.

number of helpful: 9 of 15 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
												I play this game on lowest graphics settings, on a laptop that is just on minimum spec for the game. It is still an immersive, exhilarating experience.The Russian uniforms are slightly more brown than grey. The German uniforms are slightly more grey than brown. They both bleed red explosively when you shoot them. They both fall suddenly with similar gurgled screams.No other game has made me feel sorry for the people I kill, whether friendly or enemy.If you like fast paced, run and gun shooters with plenty of explosions, don't get this game.If you like waiting around, watching the same patch of landscape for a few minutes, changing position, repeating these steps, hiding from artillery, and then screaming through the most intense 10 second firefight of your life, get this game.If you like quick respawns and CoD style self healing, don't get this game.If you like having to bandage your wounds (if you manage to survive a bullet wound, a rare occurrence), or having to wait for your guy to calm down after a salvo flies past his head and reduces your comrade to mush before you can see properly again, get this game.If you like hearing men cry for their mothers as they bleed to death beside you, get this game.There's ballistic drop. There's an ammo counter that only keeps track of magazines. Your MG will overheat. You will be killed from 150m away without knowing how. You will feel tense whilst playing this game. I'm still not sure I enjoy it. But I keep coming back.There is a slight problem on the odd server where people don't play the objective and that side pays the price quickly. But I don't think it's down to noob team members. Being in an objective zone is always brown trousers time. It takes courage to go in.I mostly play the Red Orchestra maps, because both sides have bolt action rifles and there's a lot more urban warfare. To me it feels grittier.There's nothing wrong with the Rising Storm maps. It's just that playing as America, any amount of Japanese charging is terrifying, especially when you thought they were part of the bushes.And playing as Japan... well, even I was screaming as I watched my hands melt in front of my eyes, cursing the flamethrower and every member of his family, past, present and future.

Posted: November 3, 2015
												An amazing game, probably my favourite multiplayer online FPS and certainly one of the best war games ever made. Experience amazing, exciting battles where teamwork is key, classes actually matter and tactics take a huge role in the matches final outcome.The graphics are still very good, the game runs quite smoothly and has been polished throughout the last few years, now being complete with the Rising Storm expansion that improves upon this already amazing game with a more versatile, action oriented gameplay without losing it's realist focus.There are stats and stat rewards to keep you going, none of them making the game unbalanced but giving you slight advantages over low level players that actually make for a very interesting, rewarding progression system.It's an amazing game, and i'd recomend it any day.9.5/10

												Really challenging and fun, you get a very realistic experience of WW2. It is a FPS with a good cover system, so you needn't worry that much, unless the part of your cover is visible. You get to use tanks or just the infantry; for infantry, you have a variety of classes: Rifleman, Squad Leader, Machinegunner, etc. Each of them has different wapons (determinant) and purposes in the battle. Overall, this game is very good, I've noticed very few flaws in this, so I recommend it.

content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												Red Orchestra 2 / Rising Storm is a must for anyone who enjoys a WWII FPS that rewards team work. The game has superb map design and makes good use of its realistic damage and ballistics models. That being said, it is certainly a steep learning curve for those coming from the likes of CoD or BF where it takes near a full magazine to get a kill; accuracy is hard to achieve and it can be hard to differentiate friend from foe. All in all, RO2/RS is a superb buy for those who are willing to put the time into getting used to it and few other games reward teamwork as much.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												My favourite WWII shooter that I have ever played, from a multiplayer perspective. The intensity and detail of the game, from the weapons, uniforms/equipment etc, more than make up for the lack of large maps and variety of vehicles that Ostfront had. RO2 itself is a pleasure to play and in my experience has a very mature community. It's always fun to jump into. Once on a good server, the combat and communication between team mates make for an intense, exhilirating and/or frustrating (Depending on who's winning) scenario. I recommend this game for anynone who likes gritty and unforgiving WWII shooters where no ammo counter or crosshair is present (Unless you play action mode), the realism mode is where this game stands out. The free aim system is a big plus, and the detail is excellent right down to the animations and weapon models, which even have adjustable iron sights. The implementation of recoil, and the suppression system work very well to reduce the effectiveness of a pinned sniper and spray and prayer types. 9.5/10 - Great Game, especially when you have a squad of friends on the go.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
												I LOVE THIS GAME As a self proclaimed expert on the Ostfront i love RO2 i find the multiplayer of the best of any game. The weapons feel and sound just as they would in real life the PPSH 41, DP 28, Mosin 91/30 all feel real and find them very enjoyable to play. You can play as a TL and call support for your team or you can SL and lead your squad to victory or just be conscript all roles are enjoyable. The uniforms are also accurate for the time the pre-Stalingrad uniforms are my favorite Soviet uniform. The Tanks are very enjoyable the F-34 Tank gun on the T-34-76 is just as it is in real life switching between positions is very fun, When playing as a tank squad with freinds it can be very enjoyable (DT 28 dishgun mounted on the hull of T-34-76 is OP). Over all i would rate this game a 10/10

content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												Cons:-Great WWII shooter in a market saturated by shooters like Call of Duty and Battlefield-The Eastern Front portion of the game is extremely well balanced with the Germans having an edge in machine guns, authomatic rifles and pistols but with the Russians having the edge in Submachineguns, tanks and the  Urah charge. -Historically accurate, rare for any shooter-Very mature community-Nonrepititive gameplay that will allow one to sink hours into it without it being bored whatsoever. -Killing is very rewarding in the game, I have no idea why. -Includes the Pacific Theatre of War-Multiple vehicle classes such as the half-track, lighttank and medium tank. -Great system of leveling up-The ability to mod-Great for cheaper systems. Cons: -Game can be a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to run sometimes, program prone to not responding-The American forces are OP compared to the Japanese, which they're always fighting unless you have mods. -Lack of servers and players. -Too many veteran ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s on the game that act like they're in charge of everything because they've been to Iraq or whatever-They didn't include Heavy tanks in the game-The maps are massive but only in one regard. For example, the map "Bridges of Druzhina" is probably 3 kilometers long but only .5 wide. Same with Red October Factory and Spartanovka. More "square" maps should have been implemented!-Too much coordination between team members needed to enjoy the game. It's pretty common to have one team stomping on the other because a new player has taken the commander slot and refuses to give it up. Same with the squad leaders who are supposed to be mobile spawn points but you always have people getting their heads blown off. 7.5/10 Could have been better, but it's a WWII shooter and I'm a massive fan of that genre so I can let it slide.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
												Litterally one of the BEST games I have ever played. If I were to try and tell you all the things that make RO2 a fantastic title, there wouldnt be enough time, so instead Ill sum it up in a few points and then conclude.-Pretty Decent Graphics(for those who care)-AMAZING gunplay and ballistics handling -More realistic Damage model compared to most shooters-Immersive atmosphere -Fantastic voice acting(The native voices that is, IE, in the game theres an option to enable German and Russian for the two factions)-Great emphasis on Teamwork, this is one of the few games where if you dont work as a team, you actually get destroyed.-Lastly, while the active community is smaller compared to some games [averages a peak of approx. 1,800 players on most days] it is a very welcoming and friendly one, and most people are pretty cool. =Warning= If you are going to be a new player, play the tutorials for each class role or read some guides made by vets, the only thing that will upset vets in this game is when newbies pick important roles such as the TL or SL and dont know what their doing =END OF WARNING=In conclusion, if you want a ww2 game with great gameplay thats pretty authentic as well as serious and fun then look no further this is definitly the game for you. I hope you decide to get the game and if you do I usually play on Merills stalingrad server, ober* server or weekend warriors. See you around and enjoy :)Generic score system : 100/10

content:
Posted: February 3, 2015
												As I cower behind my cover while me and my squad are heavily suppressed I see my squad leader turn to us and then stand out of cover to try to get a shot at the enemy only for him to take a bullet in the gut. The enemy didn't even give him the curtosey of finishing him off...they let him just bleed there holding his stomach as he screamed "I'll be okay don't worry about me just move!" and then he faded. He took one last breath as he stared out into the battlefield then dropped onto the floor...lifeless. I turn to my comrades and announce we should execute one final push. They all agree and with our bayonets ready we ran between the broken down buildings in the snowy ruins as one by one my men eat lead. I kept sprinting in for my target...my prey and managed to drive my bayonet through his eye only for the machinegunner next to him to pull out his pistol and fire a round into my temple...we lost...but fought bravely...for the honour of our squad leader...10/10 would get ptsd again

												I only played a 3 day trial, it was the most fun from a first person shooter in ages, holding off a massive assault in a well defended position makes you feel you could take on the whole army, and joining your comrades in an all out assault makes your hairs stand on end. content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
												I LOVE THIS GAME As a self proclaimed expert on the Ostfront i love RO2 i find the multiplayer of the best of any game. The weapons feel and sound just as they would in real life the PPSH 41, DP 28, Mosin 91/30 all feel real and find them very enjoyable to play. You can play as a TL and call support for your team or you can SL and lead your squad to victory or just be conscript all roles are enjoyable. The uniforms are also accurate for the time the pre-Stalingrad uniforms are my favorite Soviet uniform. The Tanks are very enjoyable the F-34 Tank gun on the T-34-76 is just as it is in real life switching between positions is very fun, When playing as a tank squad with freinds it can be very enjoyable (DT 28 dishgun mounted on the hull of T-34-76 is OP). Over all i would rate this game a 10/10

content:
Posted: May 19, 2013
												This WWII eastern front FPS will throw you right into the trenches! Awareness and allies are all you have standing between your brain and the bullets of your enemy. With enchanced gameplay during Realistic Mode play, Red Orchestra 2 offers a more authentic war atmosphere at the cost of casual gamer's sanity. Capture and hold key positions in order to advance on enemy lines while keeping on the lookout for the ever present eyes of the enemy. This game rewards teamwork, stealth tactics, weapon supremacy, and skill in various and sometimes surprising ways. WIth my little experience in the game, I have found that the learning curve is higher than that of common FPS games, but easily surmountable within a few maps. Heroes of Stalingrad also features a solo campaign for those who want some story or the chance to learn the game at their own pace.With all that said, I find it hard to locate much fault in this game. It may not be as flashy as some of the more popular war games, but Red Orchestra 2 promotes itself with soild gameplay and much honor to be bestowed to those who are willing to learn.

												Also review for Rising Storm mod.  RS and RO2 is one of the best and unique gaming experiences out there.  Especially, if you are sick of the soft, call of duty, battlefieldish type of games. This game is more realistic and teamwork orriented than the average AAA, fps on the market.  It takes some time but not a lot to get decent at it, but once you do understand the games core conspects you will enjoy yourself.  The value of Rising Storm is immense, if you buy just RS, you will also get the RO2 mp for free as well and considering it goes on sale fore $5 that's alot of entertainment to be had for the money. 												A fun, actually realistic stratergy Multiplayer shooting gameThis game offers a immense soundtrack and theme, with beautiful looking mapsOnly downside is the community, half of it is amazing and one of the best i have found, the other? Extreme racism and slander from casuals at all fronts, but finding a good reliable server to regular on solves everything. Overall 8/10, Great to see the franchise Progressing so well, without selling out!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Red Orchestra 2/Rising Storm is my all time favorite shooter. It is the only game, that makes me anxious about how long I will live. The screams, the sounds of your comrads dying, the body parts flying everywhere when a grenade explodes, the team killing...This is not a run and gun game. In this game, there is no unlimmited ammo with your primary weapon, no digital crosshairs, no healthbar, no health recharge, no medics (althought that would be fantastic) and its the best shooter out there today. If you are new to the game, which I was at first never having played RO1, its best to do the Single player IF ONLY for weapon training and to learn the basics. The single player, is worthless, and anyone will agree with me on that end. This is a very realistic game...hold the trigger to an MG to long, and youll just be spraying and praying, instead, do short controlled trigger bursts of 5-7 shots. With the exception of the assult class, most guns are single shot, non-automatic firing weapons, you shoot, you load you shoot again, no holding the trigger down. In this game, when you kill someone, they deserved to die, because they werent prone, they werent covering, or they werent paying attention...all of this will frustrate you, all the dying...and thats good, it will weed out those that will do more to hurt your team than help it. Get this game, ITS ALWAYS ON SALE! TRIPWIRE GAMES ARE ALWAYS ON SALE!

												I embarked at sunrisewith a flask of water, a samurai swordin the cockpit, a shaven headfull of powerful incantationsand enough fuel for a one-wayjourney into historybut half way there, my wife thought,recounting it later to her children,I looked far downat the little fishing boatsstrung out like buntingon a green-blue translucent seaand beneath them, arcing in swatheslike a huge flag waved first one waythen the other in a figure of eight,the dark shoals of fishesflashing silver as their belliesswivelled towards the sunand remembered how heand his brothers waiting on the shorebuilt cairns of pearl-grey pebblesto see whose withstood longestthe turbulent inrush of breakersbringing their father’s boat safe- yes, grandfather’s boat – safeto the shore, salt-sodden, awashwith cloud-marked mackerel,black crabs, feathery prawns,the loose silver of whitebait and oncea tuna, the dark prince, muscular, dangerous.And though he came backmy mother never spoke againin his presence, nor did she meet his eyesand the neighbours too, they treated himas though I no longer existed,only children still chattered and laughedtill gradually we too learnedto be silent, to live as thoughI had never returned, that thiswas no longer the father they loved.And sometimes, she said, i must have wonderedwhich had been the better way to die.later that night i crashed my lovely a6m zero in to my families village.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												Red Orchestra was one of the best games, if not the best, which i have purchased on steam. The intense realism and brutality of war in unmatched by any other game, making it a truly exciting game (or simulator?) to behold; whether its charging the American lines as a Japanese suicide charger, or crawling through the mud as a Russian sniper before taking out Jerry, this game appeals to all paces of combat.Yet the feature which most stood out, mostly, are the drivable and fully detailed interiors of the tanks and APC's. Such levels of detail just doesn't exist in other online games; looking around and seeing your crewmates in the tank (real people too) just makes it seem all that more believable, something other FPS's won't achieve.10/10 T34's driven, worth a buy!.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
												Ever wanted to feel on the front? Know what is on the mind of a WW2 frontline soldier/officer/commander on the German/Russian side? Well, here's your chance. the most realistic WW2 FPS game you can find is here, not your regular fps where you can get what you want, here, you will get what they give you, for instance, do you think the germans made enough mp-40 submachineguns for ALL their soldiers? NO! only officers could have them, so you my friend, is probably gonna get a kar98 bolt action rifle. THE REAL MAN'S RIFLE, to see if you are as skilled as a german soldier. Think of it as a real life challenge: most players have rifles that require skill to shoot, some have submachineguns, some have lightmachineguns and just a few have sniper rifles, so running may be a good idea, togheter with hiding on cover, but keep in mind that you are not alone and team tactics are the welcome, togheter with officers using microphones to tell you the strategy. You want a real man's game or a baby's fps? Make your choice.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2013
												One of the most humbling games I have ever played. If you played CoD when it was fun (CoD 1-4) and are considering buying this game, be prepared for a shock. This game takes the realism and immersion of sims like Arma, but keeps you in the action by taking out the parts in Arma where you trek for miles with no idea where the enemy or your squad is, and focuses more on the action. Remember how in CoD your character, even on veteran, could soak up bullets like a sponge, red jelly seemingly leaking out of his eyeballs, then duck behind cover and "squeeze" out the damage he had taken moments before? Forget that. Forget the crosshair in the middle of your screen. Forget when you would pick up a PPSH in CoD 2, fire off the entire magazine at the same target with nary a spot of recoil to be seen. Forget the ability of your character to sprint through an artillery barrage, dash across a field while being sprayed with MG-42 fire, and take out a tank singehandedly with nothing but your trusty TNT without even flinching. Try anything of the sort in this game, and, assuming you aren't instantly torn apart, your screen's color will drain away, your heart will be pounding, and you will find aiming immpossible. And I don't mean just in the game. Each side, Axis and Allies, has its own strengths and weaknesses (although the Wermacht has few of the latter). Playing as the Soviet Union, unless you manage to snag one of the few special classes, such as sniper or commander, quickly turns into a meat-grinder experience, just as it would have been in real life. Playing as a rifleman, for example, will give you a Moison-Nagant 1895, two grenades and a life expectancy of about 30 seconds. You will charge across a field to a capture point which appears to be empty, and moments later a machine gun you never saw will open up from a window you forgot to check, or from behind a wall you passed without waiting for your team-mates to cover, and your brief, often pointless life will be over, as your squad members are often cut down around your darkening vision. Often a game spent as one of the more aggresive classes will turn in three steps: Spawn, die, repeat. Sometimes you will die without firing a shot. This may sound dull, painful, or frustrating. In your first online match you may not get more than one kill. The learning curve in this game is quite steep, and this discourages many people. But eventually you will begin to learn the quirks, tricks, and rewards of each class. If you are patient, cautious, and lucky, just as the real veterans of the battle of Stalingrad had to be, and you will improve. Your name will move up the scoreboard, and you will begin to reap the rewards of the time you invest a hundred times over. This is when the game becomes the most fun. You will unlock bayonets, scopes, and new guns, and your player model will begin to show the wear and tear of surviving the battles, with medals, extra ammo and camo. All in all, probably my favorite shooter of all time. The community is mature, and welcoming to new players. Stay away from the single player mode, and don't try the tank combat, and you will grow to love this beautiful, grim, and challenging video game.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												Red Orchestra 2 is the best ptsd simulator I have and may ever have played. It isn’t one of the best first person shooters or multiplayer games out there, and not necessarily the best WW2 game, and its single player isn’t particularly good at all. But without a doubt, the killing, the being killed and the plenty of in-between there is in this game makes Red Orchestra 2 a terrifying but great experience.In this game, you are in one of four armies, Stalin's Russia, Hitler's Germany, Tojo's Japan or Roosevelt's Americanos. A large percentage of the time spent in this game is having your back to the wall sh*t scared. There's bullets and shrapnel flying from every direction and you've got sh*t in your pants and countless deaths already. Every corner in this game, every room, nook and cranny can and will conceal someone from the opposing team, firing at you from every possible angle imaginable. The cover system in this game isn’t necessarily great (although the blind firing is pretty nice) but it works, so I'll give it that.You've seen an enemy soldier, he's shot you or you've shot him and now he's dead. It's exactly like a million other games, but it feels nothing like any other game. the little things that make the difference, such as the sound of your own breathing when you lifted the rifle to your eye, and the way it bobbed around slightly in your hands. It's in the mark on your enemy's chest where the bullet hit, and the way his blood spurted from his back, making the mark of entry. The way they fell, with some weight to it like a real person. The way he clutches his stomach, yelling in German, the way he clutches and pulls the trigger madly firing the last ammo in his gun before departing.The developers of this game thought that if the main interaction of the game is to kill, and kill and kill. You should probably make it feel great. It's the attention to detail that turns this from a generic war shooter to a battlefield. It makes it something great, making you feel more like you're the one actually pulling the trigger. The limited hud really adds to this; and I love the fact that you have to check the ammo in your magazine rather than having a counter in the corner of your screen.The game modes are also great and fairly interesting. The most popular one is Territory, in which the offensive team is meant to capture multiple points on the map, whilst the other is to defend them. In this game each team has reinforcements which spawn every 15-20 seconds. The maps are made and designed to support 64 players. The reinforcement system works greatly because it finds a good way to deal with respawns and involve them with the setting of the game. These reinforcements allow the players to concentrate on the shifting frontline, going backwards and backwards until the offensive team has taken the map. Countdown mode has similar objectives, but players get just 1 life per round, where the teams swap sides halfway through, similar to how it works in games like competitive game modes in games like Counter Strike. Firefight, a team deathmatch variant to the game is fairly popular but feels as if it doesn’t really belong in the game. Territory is the only real active gamemode as of now.The weapons feel remarkable, and the classes that carry them are fairly familiar from other games. The assault class with an SMG, a marksman sniper class, a rifleman and an elite rifleman variant as well as a few others like the tank commander or engineer. The few inventive classes such as Commanders or Squad leaders do little to change the flow of gameplay however. Both roles have valuable abilities but the players on public servers rarely interact with one another asking for smokescreens or giving commands as the squad leader.Tanks don’t add much to the experience. They require a different set of skills to use well and have lovingly detailed interiors. They are an easily disposed of or ignored nuisance on the few maps that actually allow the players to utilize them.The many deaths you will go through in this game put you constantly on the edge of your seat. Death is so violent and sudden that you’re constantly kept on edge, an experience made suspenseful by the little pieces of information kept from you by the game.While this game was greatly enjoyable for me for the time i played it, it does not come without its flaws. RO2's bots barely funciton. The AI bots are almost blind, and will walk past and into the opposition without firing, and when they do it appears more to be in their general direction than an accurate shot. They're incredibly indecisive and will keep jumping through the same window and into the same trench repeatedly. If an AI is close enough he will quickly become a master swordsman, attempting to behead you with a katana or stick you with a bayonet like a pig; but, this can all be countered by walking backwards where he will infinitely chase you, most likely never firing.In this game I've seen a machinegunner set up a gun with their backs to the enemy. I've seen them set up on a cabinet, I've seen them set up in their own trench facing away from gunfire. The soldiers have ran in infinite circles where they're unable to navigate a corner or a hallway of a buulding; infinitely retracing their own steps. I've seen allied and enemy tanks aline drive in a figure of eight indefinetly, or stop in front of me and never fire. This lack of the Artifical intelligence's intelligence makes the single player gamemode completely worthless, as it's a carbon copy of the multiplayer with a few slideshows of historical background inbetween.RO2 is what it is. It’s a realistic World War 2 shooter that does what it does well. It’s a suspenseful and at times terrifying shooter with a unique twist to it. The game immerses you and doesn’t take you out for a while. It caused me to feel sadness upon watching a comrade of mine drop to the ground, and genuine fear when being aimed upon behind flimsy cover by a mounted gun in an apartment building.I enjoyed this game greatly, and as such will give it an 7/10. It’s a fast paced and enjoyable game but nevertheless there are bugs and flaws that lower the rating.Gg would get ptsd again

Posted: February 8, 2015
												Red Orchestra was one of the best games, if not the best, which i have purchased on steam. The intense realism and brutality of war in unmatched by any other game, making it a truly exciting game (or simulator?) to behold; whether its charging the American lines as a Japanese suicide charger, or crawling through the mud as a Russian sniper before taking out Jerry, this game appeals to all paces of combat.Yet the feature which most stood out, mostly, are the drivable and fully detailed interiors of the tanks and APC's. Such levels of detail just doesn't exist in other online games; looking around and seeing your crewmates in the tank (real people too) just makes it seem all that more believable, something other FPS's won't achieve.10/10 T34's driven, worth a buy!.

Posted: April 24, 2014
												Ever wanted to feel on the front? Know what is on the mind of a WW2 frontline soldier/officer/commander on the German/Russian side? Well, here's your chance. the most realistic WW2 FPS game you can find is here, not your regular fps where you can get what you want, here, you will get what they give you, for instance, do you think the germans made enough mp-40 submachineguns for ALL their soldiers? NO! only officers could have them, so you my friend, is probably gonna get a kar98 bolt action rifle. THE REAL MAN'S RIFLE, to see if you are as skilled as a german soldier. Think of it as a real life challenge: most players have rifles that require skill to shoot, some have submachineguns, some have lightmachineguns and just a few have sniper rifles, so running may be a good idea, togheter with hiding on cover, but keep in mind that you are not alone and team tactics are the welcome, togheter with officers using microphones to tell you the strategy. You want a real man's game or a baby's fps? Make your choice.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												Welcome to the front, Hero !. Red Orchestra 2 Heroes of Stalingrad (And it's expansion Rising Storm) is a great game. Is a realistic WWII set in the eastern front in the battle of Stalingrad (Russians vs Germans), but when I say realistic, I mean REALISTIC. You can die from 1 shot in your body, and when you start playing you may never know who shot you or where you've been shot from.  You're not alone, up to 32 players per side battle each other with vehicles like the the famous Panzer 4. The unreal engine does a magnificent job in graphics, it is a good looking game and you'll need a high end machine to run it a maximum graphics. There are a lot of weapons in this game, though you'll need to pay the Risin Storm DLC to get access to all the other american and japanese classes, so you can only use rifleman until you pay (You have full access in the Germans vs Russians) You can customize your weapons when you level up, like a bayonet for the Kar 98k or the Mosin Nagant, a silencer for a revolver, etc.Overall, Red Orchestra 2 is a good game, but it has bugs and glitches that doesn't make it a perfect game, and the campaign is very weak, the missions are only battles with very poor A.I bots.  You shouldn't get this game for a singleplayer experience, because its strenght are the multiplayer matches.I recommend this game a lot, if you like WWII shooters, or realistic shooters, you should get this game and its expansion.

Posted: February 11, 2014
												Red Orchestra 2 is the best WW2 multiplayer shooter you can get! In contrast to BF or COD, Red Orchestra has a slower pace but is more brutal in a sense. That means you can't go in a group of enemies with guns blazing. Instead, you will often do what is considered camping in other games. But while doing so, you will duck and cover in front of your screen, because the game so immersive. The sound effects are top notch, really capture the grim war athomsphere. I only wish the voice overs would be more realistic. I also like that the xp system very much encourages cooperative gameplay instead of lone wolves and snipers.

Posted: July 1, 2016
												It's the most fun way to get PTSD, guranteed. You buy the game, start it up, and join a battle. You pick the Russians if you want to use the Mosin Nagant, or you pick the Germans if you want the Mosin Nagant to be used to kill you, so you pick the Russians. You begin rushing the point like you do in any other FPS, and then some german starts unloading a belt fed MG right around you feet. You♥♥♥♥♥♥your pants, and everything seems like it its black and white. You run into the nearest snow-covered building, and then you peek your head out of the window with your Mosin. You shoot the machinegunner in the head and kill him. You cheer for 5 seconds until you walk out of the building and get an artillery strike called right on top of you. Then you get shell-shocked and want to leave and play something else, but you realize it was the most fun bout of post traumatic stress disorder anyone has ever had.Then you respawn and repeat.IGN 10/10 would get PTSD again.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2015
												Guadlcanal, August 1942After the landing i was promoted to squad leader. It was some time in the middle of the night when we heard those cans go off. We knew the Japs where coming. My squad Mike, Jackson, Billy, Jake, and Caleb set up firing positions. We waited the tensions grew i knew it was over when i heard "Banzaiii!." out of the darkness they came i was never so scared in my life. I lit them up with my Thompson. it was to let they breached our lines they were all around us. I ordered my squad to fall back to the bunker we did. They rest of the base was up and ready to fight. I asked mike to make a run to the commander. He only made it 10 feet before he was shot. we threw nades then i popped smoke and we ran to the red cross station we didn't hold out for long we fell back to the next point i only had 2 mags left. We killed Japs left, right, and centre. Jake was standing next to me when a bullet went though his head. I was down to my pistol Bill and Caleb where in the bunker behind me about 4ft away. I was about to make a run to them when 4 Japs Charged bayonets coming at me. I fired an entire mag only killing one. The Japs stuck me through and through. Bill and Caleb shot the Japs and ran over to me . It was to late i had already bleed out... Sgt BlackJack Guadlcanal 1942, August 13th9/10 would die again...

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Red Orchestra 2/Rising Storm is my all time favorite shooter. It is the only game, that makes me anxious about how long I will live. The screams, the sounds of your comrads dying, the body parts flying everywhere when a grenade explodes, the team killing...This is not a run and gun game. In this game, there is no unlimmited ammo with your primary weapon, no digital crosshairs, no healthbar, no health recharge, no medics (althought that would be fantastic) and its the best shooter out there today. If you are new to the game, which I was at first never having played RO1, its best to do the Single player IF ONLY for weapon training and to learn the basics. The single player, is worthless, and anyone will agree with me on that end. This is a very realistic game...hold the trigger to an MG to long, and youll just be spraying and praying, instead, do short controlled trigger bursts of 5-7 shots. With the exception of the assult class, most guns are single shot, non-automatic firing weapons, you shoot, you load you shoot again, no holding the trigger down. In this game, when you kill someone, they deserved to die, because they werent prone, they werent covering, or they werent paying attention...all of this will frustrate you, all the dying...and thats good, it will weed out those that will do more to hurt your team than help it. Get this game, ITS ALWAYS ON SALE! TRIPWIRE GAMES ARE ALWAYS ON SALE!

												I embarked at sunrisewith a flask of water, a samurai swordin the cockpit, a shaven headfull of powerful incantationsand enough fuel for a one-wayjourney into historybut half way there, my wife thought,recounting it later to her children,I looked far downat the little fishing boatsstrung out like buntingon a green-blue translucent seaand beneath them, arcing in swatheslike a huge flag waved first one waythen the other in a figure of eight,the dark shoals of fishesflashing silver as their belliesswivelled towards the sunand remembered how heand his brothers waiting on the shorebuilt cairns of pearl-grey pebblesto see whose withstood longestthe turbulent inrush of breakersbringing their father’s boat safe- yes, grandfather’s boat – safeto the shore, salt-sodden, awashwith cloud-marked mackerel,black crabs, feathery prawns,the loose silver of whitebait and oncea tuna, the dark prince, muscular, dangerous.And though he came backmy mother never spoke againin his presence, nor did she meet his eyesand the neighbours too, they treated himas though I no longer existed,only children still chattered and laughedtill gradually we too learnedto be silent, to live as thoughI had never returned, that thiswas no longer the father they loved.And sometimes, she said, i must have wonderedwhich had been the better way to die.later that night i crashed my lovely a6m zero in to my families village.

content:
Posted: January 13
												Joined a server, picked a side and a class. Spawned 100 meters from objective my team was to defend. After few seconds of running i got killed by a player I will never know from where. And I loved it.Red Orchestra 2 and Rising Storm are perfect examples of what could've happend if FPS industry went for  realism and difficulty rather than towards effects and grind. Where in Cods and other BFs running around can make you pro, you will die here that way. In Realism mode, one played the most often, you rarely survive a single bullet, and even if, you need to spend a few seconds to bandage the wound, otherwise you bleed out. Because after all, in most of the cases all you are is cannon fodder.Since 4 years this is only MP game, and the most played gamemode is Territory. Two teams fight for contorl over a map, fighting for every field on the regular maps, on which one side is defending and and other attacks. Each province controlled prodives team with 5 combat power, while defending costs 25 and attacking takes 75 of it. Moreover, losing tickets during fight also decreases combat power, so phyrric victories, which are quite common here, arent the best way to go. But what about game itself?Before anything else, you have to pick a class.  They differ by loadouts and role - one of them is not even supposed to fight. There are Assaults with SMGs, MGs with... come on, thats obvious, Snipers and the core: Riflemen. This class takes ~75% of the whole teams, so get accomodated. They are equipped with bolt-action rifles that are really lethal if you know how to use them. Last two classes are Squad leaders and Commander - their roles are tactical so as a newbs stay away from them, as they require proper mic and great game knowldege.So as mentioned earlier, taking over the province requires winning the map. This can be done in few ways. As attacker, you can either take all the points or make enemy team lose all the tickets. As defender, you either make enemy run out of tickets or hold a point till Lockdown timer kicks in. If they fail to take point before lockdown timer runs out, they lose.Remembering that every bullet has potential to kill, this is challenge. Team work is crucial here, and while many games say so - here you can only die alone. Rising Storm is more of the same - only difference is that instead of Europe, we fight in Asia and sides and weapons are different. There are side-excluisve classes, though. Allies have Flamethrowers and Axis has Light mortars (baisicly Riflemen with additional6-rounds mortars). Both these classes are awesome, with Flamers being slightly OP. I have no idea how to say everything that i love about this game. Putting a bayonett into the spine of the mot*******er who took half of the team with MG. Killing enemy Commander. Blowing up Flamer by shooting at his fuel tank. Hundreds of scenes that make you enjoy every minute in this game. There are also bad things: idiot teammates running in front of friendly MG, newbs taking tactical roles, AT class (Seriously - class with slowly firing AT-rifle, pistol and AT grenade, while tanks dont get slighlty damaged by these AT rifles. Great). And - why is there so much fog on every map?All these cons are tiny problems, which shouldn't really take fun - that is, if you manage to get to understand the game and forget about carelessly running into the MG - because here it is a bad idea.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
												Red Orchestra 2: Heroes of Stalingrad / Rising Storm GOTYPros:- Immersion, immersion, immersion- No biased point of view ( A rare thing in WWII games )- Good gameplay- Good AIMany people have commented on this game being a "PTSD Simulator". This claim is far from unjustified. This game is super-immersive ( Even more so when using the Immersion Overhaul Simulator - http://steamcommunity.com/groups/IOMMODplayers ). Realistic graphics, along with good ballistics, suppression affects and an amazing atmosphere of constant danger give this game an edge over other WWII games of the genre.No biased Point of View is another big tick for me. No more evil Germans or unbalanced mechanics that impact how the Germans play. This is a big step forward and a great way of seeing how the front was ACTUALLY LIKE. No more of the lies made up about the Germans by the victors.Gameplay strives to be as realistic as possible, while also catering to beginners. Most weapons take one shot to kill, but are balanced by accuracy and weapon sway, etc. Tank gameplay is extremely impressive with full internal views and great combat elements.The AI are not easy to say the least. They are only slightly less competent than a human player. There are also always servers with lots of bots to practice with.Cons:- Flamethrowers...- Banned From SessionFlamethrowers on this game are fairly unbalaced - and only one nation, the US, gets them. They can be taken out from range, but will take down several people before dying. Not the biggest issue, but definitely something to look out for.There is a possibility that you will be banned from a server for the rest of a session (battle) for having high ping. There is no proper way of fixing this, just join servers with good connection unless you want to take your chances on other servers.*P.S: I play on Oceania ( servers and setups may vary )

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												RO2 raises the bar in multiplayer-based shooter realism. There will be no bunny hopping, 360 no scope headshots in this game, ever! It is an exercise in patience, a WW2 simulation where full auto weapons are in short supply, and bolt action rifles make up the bulk of the armaments. Iron sights are almost a requirement for accurate shooting, but a single shot can and often does make a kill. Realistic damage modeling rewards careful marksmanship, and treats a shot in the heart the same as a head shot... an instant kill. However, the effects of limb damage aren't made quite clear, and seem to serve no other purpose than a means to implement the self-applied battlefield bandaging feature.  RO2 is a PC-only shooter, and gives the arcadey big name console ports a run for their money. The standard gameplay mode is tug-of-war style where teams must grab control points in sequence. Each control point is captured via a "King of the Hill" style mini-tug-of-war by the team who can maintain a higher player count within the "hill's" borders. Thus, contrary to arena multiplayer shooters, the most important task for the player is SURVIVING as opposed to simply killing. Surviving and killing alike require a certain level of teamwork, since the game can be punishing for those who prefer to run and gun. This standard game formula is further broken down into pure Tug of War (where the map control starts with neutral center capture points and the control can go in either direction) and Assault/Defence (where one team attemps to capture the points accross a map while the other team must defend said points).  These modes are hardwired into the maps they are played on, meaning that some maps are soley Assault maps, while others are soley Tug of War maps. There are other game modes available, but I have not tinkered around with them much since I greatly enjoy the standard game as it is. Vehicular combat is a sore spot for me. Straight up, it sucks, for many reasons. Vehicle gameplay wasn't implemented in the normal fasion seen in most games. For example, you must commit to vehicular classes, and once spawned you actually start in the vehicle and cannot exit. Nor can other players enter your spawned vehicle. And there are other annoyances. It's just.... bad. Another gripe of mine is the spawn system: it's clunky and counter-intuitive. For example, if you are attempting to spawn on a squad leader, but the commander forces a respawn before you can finish the selection, you will spawn at a random spawn site that is most definately NOT your squad leader and more than likely much further from the front lines than you would like. Again, there are other annoyances with RO2s spawn system. All in all it is one of the premeire shooting experiences available. Highly recommended!

content:
Posted: June 8, 2013
												One of the most humbling games I have ever played. If you played CoD when it was fun (CoD 1-4) and are considering buying this game, be prepared for a shock. This game takes the realism and immersion of sims like Arma, but keeps you in the action by taking out the parts in Arma where you trek for miles with no idea where the enemy or your squad is, and focuses more on the action. Remember how in CoD your character, even on veteran, could soak up bullets like a sponge, red jelly seemingly leaking out of his eyeballs, then duck behind cover and "squeeze" out the damage he had taken moments before? Forget that. Forget the crosshair in the middle of your screen. Forget when you would pick up a PPSH in CoD 2, fire off the entire magazine at the same target with nary a spot of recoil to be seen. Forget the ability of your character to sprint through an artillery barrage, dash across a field while being sprayed with MG-42 fire, and take out a tank singehandedly with nothing but your trusty TNT without even flinching. Try anything of the sort in this game, and, assuming you aren't instantly torn apart, your screen's color will drain away, your heart will be pounding, and you will find aiming immpossible. And I don't mean just in the game. Each side, Axis and Allies, has its own strengths and weaknesses (although the Wermacht has few of the latter). Playing as the Soviet Union, unless you manage to snag one of the few special classes, such as sniper or commander, quickly turns into a meat-grinder experience, just as it would have been in real life. Playing as a rifleman, for example, will give you a Moison-Nagant 1895, two grenades and a life expectancy of about 30 seconds. You will charge across a field to a capture point which appears to be empty, and moments later a machine gun you never saw will open up from a window you forgot to check, or from behind a wall you passed without waiting for your team-mates to cover, and your brief, often pointless life will be over, as your squad members are often cut down around your darkening vision. Often a game spent as one of the more aggresive classes will turn in three steps: Spawn, die, repeat. Sometimes you will die without firing a shot. This may sound dull, painful, or frustrating. In your first online match you may not get more than one kill. The learning curve in this game is quite steep, and this discourages many people. But eventually you will begin to learn the quirks, tricks, and rewards of each class. If you are patient, cautious, and lucky, just as the real veterans of the battle of Stalingrad had to be, and you will improve. Your name will move up the scoreboard, and you will begin to reap the rewards of the time you invest a hundred times over. This is when the game becomes the most fun. You will unlock bayonets, scopes, and new guns, and your player model will begin to show the wear and tear of surviving the battles, with medals, extra ammo and camo. All in all, probably my favorite shooter of all time. The community is mature, and welcoming to new players. Stay away from the single player mode, and don't try the tank combat, and you will grow to love this beautiful, grim, and challenging video game.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												Welcome to the front, Hero !. Red Orchestra 2 Heroes of Stalingrad (And it's expansion Rising Storm) is a great game. Is a realistic WWII set in the eastern front in the battle of Stalingrad (Russians vs Germans), but when I say realistic, I mean REALISTIC. You can die from 1 shot in your body, and when you start playing you may never know who shot you or where you've been shot from.  You're not alone, up to 32 players per side battle each other with vehicles like the the famous Panzer 4. The unreal engine does a magnificent job in graphics, it is a good looking game and you'll need a high end machine to run it a maximum graphics. There are a lot of weapons in this game, though you'll need to pay the Risin Storm DLC to get access to all the other american and japanese classes, so you can only use rifleman until you pay (You have full access in the Germans vs Russians) You can customize your weapons when you level up, like a bayonet for the Kar 98k or the Mosin Nagant, a silencer for a revolver, etc.Overall, Red Orchestra 2 is a good game, but it has bugs and glitches that doesn't make it a perfect game, and the campaign is very weak, the missions are only battles with very poor A.I bots.  You shouldn't get this game for a singleplayer experience, because its strenght are the multiplayer matches.I recommend this game a lot, if you like WWII shooters, or realistic shooters, you should get this game and its expansion.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												This is another World War 2 First Person Shooter, but with a few key differences: it's set in the Eastern European Theatre, and you're not the badass mobile sentry you're regarded as in other FPS games.You don't hide behind cover, waiting for your Eagle-headed God to provide technical long-term immunity from lead poisoning. You don't just walk into the battlefield, explosions left and right, and expect everything to be sweet. You don't even have convenient vision overlays to tell you how many more steps to take until you win.Combat is vicious, it's the real deal. One bullet will either drop you on the spot or cause you a world of trouble before giving in to shock and blood loss. The level of detail is astonishing: projectiles are affected by ballistics and require both leading the target and sighting in/aiming higher.There are multiple classes available to play, each suited to specific roles: the Sharpshooter is given a scoped rifle to pick off high value targets like Commanders, who can send in airstrikes and lead teams, and Squad Leaders, who can use smoke grenades for covering their advance and work as mobile spawn points. You even have Tanks, but not in the revolutionary "One-Crew" format: you start with a Tank Commander, a Driver, a Cannon operator and a Loader. All are necessary for the tank to work well, otherwise you'll have to constantly switch seats, which takes time. Tank shells have believable physics as well, and can either punch through side/rear/top armor or deflect harmlessly.But all classes are heavily restricted, usually no more than 4 of them on most maps. The only general exception, the Rifleman, is both the cannon fodder and the most important asset of the team, much like Chess.Despite looking fairly drab and brown most of the time, the game looks very pretty - Scenery Gorn runs amok in the heavily bombed areas of Stalingrad. With a hellish warzone as this, what would you expect?The audio is amazingly immersive, for both good and bad. Native voice acting compliments this, in addition to giving you a good chance to not understand most of the chatter.Finally, your (many) inevitable deaths at the hands of other human players will be accompanied by gurgling of vital fluids, breathless gasps for one more lungful of air, or heart breaking cries from your stricken soldier to see their loved ones before expiring in a dirty trench. That is, if you're lucky enough not to get killed by an explosion, which tears off your limbs and leaves you a bloody mess screaming in pain.Stalingrad wasn't a victory for one side and defeat for the other.Stalingrad was a complete massacre for both sides. Thankfully, Heroes of Stalingrad is a very, very good multiplayer first person shooter set in the Eastern European Front of the Second World War.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												This is another World War 2 First Person Shooter, but with a few key differences: it's set in the Eastern European Theatre, and you're not the badass mobile sentry you're regarded as in other FPS games.You don't hide behind cover, waiting for your Eagle-headed God to provide technical long-term immunity from lead poisoning. You don't just walk into the battlefield, explosions left and right, and expect everything to be sweet. You don't even have convenient vision overlays to tell you how many more steps to take until you win.Combat is vicious, it's the real deal. One bullet will either drop you on the spot or cause you a world of trouble before giving in to shock and blood loss. The level of detail is astonishing: projectiles are affected by ballistics and require both leading the target and sighting in/aiming higher.There are multiple classes available to play, each suited to specific roles: the Sharpshooter is given a scoped rifle to pick off high value targets like Commanders, who can send in airstrikes and lead teams, and Squad Leaders, who can use smoke grenades for covering their advance and work as mobile spawn points. You even have Tanks, but not in the revolutionary "One-Crew" format: you start with a Tank Commander, a Driver, a Cannon operator and a Loader. All are necessary for the tank to work well, otherwise you'll have to constantly switch seats, which takes time. Tank shells have believable physics as well, and can either punch through side/rear/top armor or deflect harmlessly.But all classes are heavily restricted, usually no more than 4 of them on most maps. The only general exception, the Rifleman, is both the cannon fodder and the most important asset of the team, much like Chess.Despite looking fairly drab and brown most of the time, the game looks very pretty - Scenery Gorn runs amok in the heavily bombed areas of Stalingrad. With a hellish warzone as this, what would you expect?The audio is amazingly immersive, for both good and bad. Native voice acting compliments this, in addition to giving you a good chance to not understand most of the chatter.Finally, your (many) inevitable deaths at the hands of other human players will be accompanied by gurgling of vital fluids, breathless gasps for one more lungful of air, or heart breaking cries from your stricken soldier to see their loved ones before expiring in a dirty trench. That is, if you're lucky enough not to get killed by an explosion, which tears off your limbs and leaves you a bloody mess screaming in pain.Stalingrad wasn't a victory for one side and defeat for the other.Stalingrad was a complete massacre for both sides. Thankfully, Heroes of Stalingrad is a very, very good multiplayer first person shooter set in the Eastern European Front of the Second World War.
