number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												RO2 raises the bar in multiplayer-based shooter realism. There will be no bunny hopping, 360 no scope headshots in this game, ever! It is an exercise in patience, a WW2 simulation where full auto weapons are in short supply, and bolt action rifles make up the bulk of the armaments. Iron sights are almost a requirement for accurate shooting, but a single shot can and often does make a kill. Realistic damage modeling rewards careful marksmanship, and treats a shot in the heart the same as a head shot... an instant kill. However, the effects of limb damage aren't made quite clear, and seem to serve no other purpose than a means to implement the self-applied battlefield bandaging feature.  RO2 is a PC-only shooter, and gives the arcadey big name console ports a run for their money. The standard gameplay mode is tug-of-war style where teams must grab control points in sequence. Each control point is captured via a "King of the Hill" style mini-tug-of-war by the team who can maintain a higher player count within the "hill's" borders. Thus, contrary to arena multiplayer shooters, the most important task for the player is SURVIVING as opposed to simply killing. Surviving and killing alike require a certain level of teamwork, since the game can be punishing for those who prefer to run and gun. This standard game formula is further broken down into pure Tug of War (where the map control starts with neutral center capture points and the control can go in either direction) and Assault/Defence (where one team attemps to capture the points accross a map while the other team must defend said points).  These modes are hardwired into the maps they are played on, meaning that some maps are soley Assault maps, while others are soley Tug of War maps. There are other game modes available, but I have not tinkered around with them much since I greatly enjoy the standard game as it is. Vehicular combat is a sore spot for me. Straight up, it sucks, for many reasons. Vehicle gameplay wasn't implemented in the normal fasion seen in most games. For example, you must commit to vehicular classes, and once spawned you actually start in the vehicle and cannot exit. Nor can other players enter your spawned vehicle. And there are other annoyances. It's just.... bad. Another gripe of mine is the spawn system: it's clunky and counter-intuitive. For example, if you are attempting to spawn on a squad leader, but the commander forces a respawn before you can finish the selection, you will spawn at a random spawn site that is most definately NOT your squad leader and more than likely much further from the front lines than you would like. Again, there are other annoyances with RO2s spawn system. All in all it is one of the premeire shooting experiences available. Highly recommended!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												TL;DR The best tactical and WW2 FPS on the market. Realistic weapons, wide variety of maps, harsh and unforgiving, and the most authentic experience of the horrors of war in a video game.The main game (Red Orchestra 2), is set on the eastern front, and the expansion (Rising Storm), is set in the pacific theater. Weapons depend on which of these you play, but weapons can range from rifles like the M1 garand and Kar98k, to the M12 shotgun, to MGs like the mg42, to the BAR, and even to flamethowers, all made with precise detail of the original weapons. The main game, territory, consists of one attacking and defending team. Attackers cap points by getting men into different capzones, and defenders try to stop them. Reinforcements are simulated with respawns and each team has a limited amount of tickets (lives), and there is a time limit in each round. The maps can be huge, and they are very varied, requiring the use of flanking, smoke grenades, artillery, tank support, and aerial recons to play well enough to win. This game is very unforgiving, and you'll die alot at first, espicially if you play on the realistic, the recommended mode.There are various roles in the game, rifleman being your basic infantrymen, to roles like machine gunner and engineer, up to squad leaders and a commander, who issues out artillery and recons from a radio. All of these have their own details, so it's best to read up on how to play them, though riflemen is a good starting role. There are also vehicles, such as tanks and infantry trucks, available on some maps, these being the more larger maps. The damage model is harsh, one rifle shot to the chest usually being a one hit kill. The gunplay mechanics are very satisfying, there being bullet drop and different parts of the body that can be damaged. There are no special skins or perks here, nearly all weapons using the good old ironsights. Gameplay is usually slow, as rushing into a point will just get you killed, even if you have an smg at hand. Careful waves of attack, and setting up a good defence are crucial.One thing done really well in this game is to show the horrors of war. This game is very gory, including dismemberment from things like explosives. Heavy fire or artillery will make your game shake and go grey, as if suppressed. There are the screams of pain from your fellow soldiers, wishing to be somewhere else. There are some pretty harsh and even racist taunts that can be spoken, adding to the realism of the game. This game is really good at showing both sides as human, instead of the usual bad guys vs good guys, this being army vs army, nothing more.  The community itself is generally of a good level whilst playing, and it's easy enough playing in a squad on your own if friends aren't available. I've had my fair share of interesting occasions, like someone spamming Rick Astley's "Never gonna give you up", people "roleplaying" as soldiers of their respective teams, and a hacker who somehow kicked every singe person from a server, but instead of being shown a kick message, it said that you were banned. Of course, I wasn't banned, and this person did not do this again, at least not to me.One thing this game does well is keep you playing. I've played more than 50 hours, and I feel like I've only scratched the surface of this game in terms of roles and tactics. This game will take a very long time to become truly good at it, or even master it.Overall, one of the best Tactical FPS out there, and a must buy.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2013
												This game is just masterpiece to me, over 100 hours played i can say i know this game pretty well. At first Red Orchestra/Rising storm isnť arcade shooter like Battlefield or Call of Duty so donť even try to compare it! This game is very realistic like bullet drops, so you must aim higher...Hitbox system is very good also. To sound...its great..When you hear bullets fizzling near your head + artillery around you it is very depressing and it feels like you are actually in the trenches with you squad.The core of the game though is teamwork (you can use voice commands or VOIP), with a good server and good players you move in squads, coordinate flanking assaults with artillery strikes and charge through your squad leaders smoke cover to overwhelm the opposition! Maps are very well designed and realistic. You can choose from many different classes to play like Engineer, Rifle man, Squad leader and more...Iam not huge fan of Unreal Engine 3 so graphic is little negative for me...So as bugs are and you will find many of them, but they donť destroy gameplay so much and you can actually enjoy the game.The combat is fierce and filled with mayhem. What's amazing is that for all the chaos of the battlefield the game remains cogent, balanced and the deep strategical gameplay remains intact. Game contains different mods to play..and also different 	difficulty - Classic, Arcade, Realistic so for new players in this genre is great way how to learn something about this game. Did i mention there is Steam Workshop for this game? Yeah awesome, now there are pretty cool addons, mod and maps from commuity..Shoutout to them :)I rate 8/10.See you on battlefield comrades!

content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												Red Orchestra 2: Heroes of Stalingrad with the paid DLC Rising Storm.  If you like World War 2 themed PVP first person shooter simulations, this is a good game to get.  This game is slightly less realistic than the original Red Orchestra, but the graphics and the gameplay is whole lot better.  The single player is WW2 combat like the original Call of Duty and Medal of Honor games.  Comes with a separate Singleplayer campaign game.You can play as infantry or tanker only.  The tank combat here is better than the original Red Orchestra, because the tank crew bots listen to your detailed comands that you can give, and you have more viewports to use.  The tanks models looks limited to the Panzer 4 and T-34 in the few original tank using maps.  As Commander, you can issue useful commands to your teammates. Server Maps can have AI bots filling out the team roster.  You can command the bots squads to take objectives, defend objectives, or go to locations but not give artillery targets.  The bots are slightly more smarter, and have better shooting skills but still no substitute for real players.   RO2 multiplayer servers are German vs Russian maps.  With the Rising Storm DLC you have access to Japan vs American maps, (Using the Flamethrower is fun).  Has great multiplayer maps and a single person campaign.  A lot of multiplayer servers have bots filling in for real players.The single player campaigns are German vs Russian or Russian vs German, it is a separate game bundled with your purchase.  The single player game is sort of buggy and cheats.  You can also use console comands in the single player game to complete the achievements there.Has Steam Achievements with badge trading cards. Has Steam Workshop with modding community making new maps using the included Level Editor.for more info:

content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
												Call Of Cuty is a game for children. This is a game for men. COD kids get out.This is my favorite WW2 game by far. This a great and realistic game with a lot of depth.Here is a quick overview:You will play as a soldier of either the Red Army, the Wehrmacht, The U.S. Marines, or the Imperial Japanese Army. The game is set in two theaters of war, The Pacific (U.S. Vs Japs), and the Eastern front (Russians Vs Germans). In each army, there are different classes such as rifleman, assault, marksman, and so on. As you progress in the game, your weapons will level up and get attachments/upgrades, and look like they are in better condition. The class you are playing itself can be leveled up to give you more weapon/sidearm choices. Finally, you can level up your account with "Honor". The higher that level is, the more battle hardened your soldier is and the more things overall you can choose from. I recommend you play the training missions, and I partially put that here so I wouldn't have to type anymore stuff...In any case, I rate this game 10/10.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												Ah, Red Orchestra. Where do I even begin? If I run from cover to cover, I get shredded by machinegun fire. If I peek my head to get a clear field of view, a sniper somewhere hears angels chanting and pierces my brains, splattering the wall behind me. This game is hard, nerve-wracking, and not for the faint of heart or anyone who is used to 1337 720ºNoscopesnipah kills.This game encourages camping.This game is like a severe parent punishing your every mistake.This game is absolutely, bloody good. Get it if you can. Play it if you have the time. I know I only clocked around 20 hours on it, but I would play the hell out of it if I could.So, let us get serious. Hardcore shooter with cover mechanics. Somewhat glitchy, too, but I don't find it unplayable by any means. Servers are typically 32 vs 32, with bots usually filling any slots left (which gives both teams an impressive amount of cannon fodder), so you know the battles are going to be big. Weapons lack variety, which is to be expected considering it aims to be a realistic, historically-accurate game. And, bear with me here, said weapons are unbalanced. Remember COD 2? A semi-auto rifle will never, or hardly ever, one-hit kill, which is understandable for gameplay reasons. Cue Red Orchestra's Elite Rifleman class, armed with a semi-auto rifle: it has the same power as the humble breech-loading basic rifles, but is semi-auto and holds more ammo. Then again, it's limited to, say, 3 per team. Same happens with the LMG, with astonishing firepower, or the SMGs, which can make mincemeat of anything at close to medium ranges. However, this not only means that there are, naturally, players better equipped. Those same players have responsibilities: take a marksman rifle and go lone wolf scoring random kills? Wrong. Use it to clear the way for a capture point, to find the machine gunner who is tearing your team apart. Squad leader? Stay alive to allow respawning on you, make judicious use of your smoke grenades. So on and so on. Teamplay is king. Armies win wars. The cover system works well. You can sprint crouched. Grenades can be gently dropped instead of having to throw them at the ceiling hoping they stay in the damned room. Gunplay is smooth, graphics are really good, sound and effects immersive as it gets. What more is there to ask for?Ah, yes. Satisfaction. The satisfaction of out-aiming an enemy 120 metres away. Looking at the top right corner, those seconds lying in wait, thinking "Did I get him?". Then you see it. You hit him spot on, you got the kill. You may get pistol-whipped to death a second after, but getting a kill in Red Orchestra is as satisfying as it gets in a shooter. Of course, there are shortcomings. Optimization is poor. Some glitches can get a bit annoying. As I said, weapon variety is low and you may get relegated to basic Rifleman for rounds on end. You will get frustrated. The game is punishingly hard. But in the end, this is a top-notch shooter. Go get it. Go get 'em.

												A solid World War II experience with many realistic aspects such as bullet range calibration for different firearms and vehicles, bleeding out unless bandaged, and a large bundle of war-torn maps as one would expect from when the war was at it's worst. A great multiplayer system, hosting is simple and joining is simpler than it was in the first game, maps support up to 64 players total, allowing for 32 players on each side playing as either the Axis or Allied forces.Overall, this game gets a score of 8/10 due to a somewhat flonky controll system and the occational framerate and bug issues. Some aspects in the game should've been more polished such as the cover mechanics and bullet damage. (The hardcore mode fixes this to some extent, although it still lingers with some firearms).

content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												This game is like a ragged teddy bear for me. It's not off the shelf new, it has its bugs, its TKrs, hackers on the private servers and so on. But you know what? I really love this game. I've probably rewrote this review 3 or 4 times by now trying to say exactly why. I think, this time, I've figured it out; It's the moments.     To explain what I mean, I'll give some examples and then you're going to buy this game, make your own experiences, and understand the feeling I get remembering each of these. Experience 1: I was a rifleman in squad two, German side and attacking. We were holding out in a barn, surrounded by swirling snow and the crack of bullets going supersonic as they whistled towards us from seemingly everywhere. It was hectic, but we were holding. All of a sudden, something flew in the window where the Squad Leader and two others were standing. I looked, saw and bellyflopped on the grenade. After a split second, I heard a whump and I died. However, the others were unharmed and held the area until the rest of us mopped up and began covering them.Experience 2: We were on the beaches. I was in command of the American attack and we were getting slaughtered 30 seconds in due to the entire enemy team digging in at the center trenches overlooking our spawn. I considered the situation and ordered Squad Leaders 2 and 3 to get me spotted marks on those trenches. Number 3 was shot but 2 managed to get a perfect mark, ordering his squad forward to provide him just enough cover. That was all I needed, I ordered everyone to make ready just outside the trenches and called in hell. Three salvos of molten lead from the sky later, and all but two of the enemy team were dead and I ordered the advance. They charged in through the smoke, myself with them. Spraying fire and death, we repeated this all the way to the end, never giving them enough time to settle and hold.Experience 3: My Comrades and I were running down a muddy track, rushing to get to the front. The Fritz were attacking us on our hill position and those bunkers are pretty much our only cover. Machine gunner? I don't know but one of us just hit the dirt and he isn't moving. Two more dead. My vision just went gray and blurred. There's a ringing in my ears. Grenade, Three more dead. That's okay I think, we still have five more of us. Yes, we made it, bunker, safety. I'm catching my breath and three explosions go off in the bunker, stunning me. I can't see much, the last thing I had clear sight of was the guy nearest me flying. My vision is clear, oh no. Blood everywhere, bodies, limbs. Everyone is dead. I can hear the Nazis shouting orders and egging each other on. Can I make it out the door and retreat to the line? Too late, they saw me I raise my rifle and all goes black as I get shot in the back by another one of them.There are very few games where I can get stories such as these and many more. The learning curve is tight. You will die many, many, many, many times. It's worth it, without a doubt in my mind. The last thing that I reccomend is playing this game in realism mode. It's not 100 percent realism, however it's enough to actually feel the tension instead of a more arcade, Call of Duty/ Battlefield level of gameplay. After reading all of this, you think you have the patience to get what I get, and maybe even more, out of Red Orchestra 2, I have only one question. Why are you still reading this?

												This game is like a ragged teddy bear for me. It's not off the shelf new, it has its bugs, its TKrs, hackers on the private servers and so on. But you know what? I really love this game. I've probably rewrote this review 3 or 4 times by now trying to say exactly why. I think, this time, I've figured it out; It's the moments.     To explain what I mean, I'll give some examples and then you're going to buy this game, make your own experiences, and understand the feeling I get remembering each of these. Experience 1: I was a rifleman in squad two, German side and attacking. We were holding out in a barn, surrounded by swirling snow and the crack of bullets going supersonic as they whistled towards us from seemingly everywhere. It was hectic, but we were holding. All of a sudden, something flew in the window where the Squad Leader and two others were standing. I looked, saw and bellyflopped on the grenade. After a split second, I heard a whump and I died. However, the others were unharmed and held the area until the rest of us mopped up and began covering them.Experience 2: We were on the beaches. And then it's all over in one M1 shot to the head.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												Where do I start with Red Orchestra 2? When I first got this game, I had no idea what I was in for. I loaded up a match, chose my class and charged headlong into the fight, just like I would any other fps. That was a horrible mistake. I was shot once and bled out about five feet from the spawn. My first few matches went a lot like this one. Eventually, I learned how to survive long enough to get to the objectives and that's when I discovered how truly brutal this game can be. There's nothing more intense than being trapped on the second floor of a bombed out building with german troops rushing in and all you have is a bolt-action rifle that's low on ammo so you're forced to hide and beat them to death one by one. This and many other moments are what make this game one of my all time favorites. Nothing else compares. Play it and see for yourself.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2012
												The most realistic first person shooter I've ever played. Quite the learning curve I find but once you get the hang of it, this can be one awesome game. Gravity has effect on the bullets, but you can adjust sights to compensate for distance, you can rest your rifle against a window sill or door ledge to stable your firearm for accuracy, controls inside the tanks are in view, and there's effects for when you're under suppressive fire. You can also level up classes and firearms to become more efficient. Not terribly unlike real life, after all you can condition yourself to have better stamina, get more in tune with the firearms you own, and you can also get attachments/modifications for some. Hoping that in Red Orchestra 3, they incorporate the possibility of jams. In real life however, if you maintain your firearms, malfunctions will be few and far between. No gun is 100% reliable, though. Not even AKs or Glocks.June 23, 2014 - Since an update they made in April, I have been unable to play the game, and many others have also been unable to join servers. Do not waste your money on RO2 or RS until it starts working again, it will only give you headaches.Nov 24, 2014 - The issue seems to have been resolved, the game is running well again. Enjoy the WWII realism!

content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												I gotta say, im not even through training and I can assure as far as amazing realism goes, this game has it. 4 people are needed to drive a tank, not 1, tanks have ammoYou can check gun clips, all reload types are accurate to period guns, you have to change the barrels on mg42's the same way the krauts did, you can blind fire. You can modify the range on scopes and iron sights, bullets have drop. You can use Anti Tank rifles though you have to, as they did in reality, aim for weak spots. The "Commander" class is an actual soldier in a bunker who uses a radio to call in strikes, and can look outside to mark targetsThis game gives you much more freedom than other FPS games, this is where the game stops holding your hand, meaning you are going to have to grow up and learn to take cover, learn to use your senses and some common sense, and learn to work as a team if you want to stay alive.but on the flipside, this extra responsibility comes with so damn much freedom..Alot of the reviews that seem to list battles out are a bit fluffed, but not by much. Getting hit in certain parts does affect your soldier in different ways, you can melee charge with everyone (Except the US I think) You can look out the hatch of a tank if you dont mind getting your head blown off by a sniper, you can shell buildings into dust. You can kill your team mates, i dont think theres anywhere FF is not on.This is a grown ups First person shooter, another of those "War simulator" games that are setting a trend taking us away from call of duty and battlefield. Hero's in red orchestra are people who stay with the team, take care of their men, and stay alive, not that moron who is running across an open field with his pistol and gets shot through the chest, falling to his knees and slowly bleeding out as he asks why the stupid♥♥♥♥♥♥he used in all the other FPS games isnt working here.EDIT:Finally had my first battle, and the truth is, alot of those epica moments people list? they happen. Hell, i went on a bot server for my first since i didnt want to drag down the team as the new guy, and even then I came out with a war story. Please note, im not adding much flourish at all and this did happen within an hour of starting normal gameplay WITH BOTS. Also, listen to it in Artyom's voice from metro! The Nazis were fighting in the lower floor of the grain silo, i hee-ad been snai-ping (Gotta get that Russian Accent in there) on the therd floore, when i heard the screams of my comrahds bee-lowh. I took my trusty nagant revolver, and despite being a snai-per I ran to their aid. Upon coming in I saw my position and entry were foolish, 3 nazis, 2 with rif-els and one with a macheen-gun stood looking at me, i quickly took cover by a pill-are and aimed, firing immediately, I heard the metallic think of a peer-ced helmet, and the first nazi fell, staring at the hole in his head. I quickly turned the corner on my pill-ar and took a shot at the gunner, heering the same metallic Thood, he too fell to the ground, the last one stood, as if in shock at my markshmanship, and i then took his life, the shot hitting him in the throat, he fell over and gurgled slowly to death on his own blood. I sat, shocked by my own survival for a moment, before returning to reality and picking up the german's macheengun, the enemy was not finished with me, i mounted the heavy gun on the sandbags facing the entrance to the silo and prepared myself...Many more germans had to go to hell on this day, and I was just getting started

content:
Posted: July 15, 2013
												Red Orchestra and Rising Storm are truly amazing WW2 tactical shooters. Very realistic and challenging gameplay with no room for silly mistakes. Player can take a role of one of few different infantry classes (like rifleman, team leader, sniper, tank hunter etc. ) and also can be a part of a tank crew. German Panzer IV and soviet T-34 are very good addition in the game and both are very well modelled and detailed. Weapons behaviour is very realistic and weapon ballistics/accurace is also well executed. Rising Storm will take the player to the Pacific Ocean theatre of WW2.US Army and Imperial Army are extremely well done. Using US superior firepower to take stategic locations in places like Iwo Jima or Saipan is a great experience.In my opinion the thing that makes this game so great is definitely the Japanesse Imperial Army. They do not posses such good equipment as US forces, but they rely on their unmatched feriocity and fanatical determination to fight to the last man. Booby traps, ambushes and other treacherous tactics are in common use. Watching an entire squad rushing into enemy position with swords/bayonets/grenades and fanatical screams is something that could not be forgot - Banzai Charge is an unique gameplay mechanic of the Imperial Army.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												So, after playing the multiplayer of both Rising Storm & Red Orchestra 2 for about 170+ hours and reaching max level on Rising Storm while also reaching a decently high level on Red Orchestra 2, I can say that this game is excellent.The game is extremely unforgiving, you often die in pretty much 1 or 2 hits. If you are hit anywhere but your limbs, you'll probably die instantly. The only times you really have a chance to survive is if a bullet hits your arm or leg. If you somehow don't die instantly and you're wounded, you can use one of the 2 bandages you are given every spawn to patch yourself up. If you do not bandage up in time, you might bleed out depending on where you got shot. It is very important to move carefully by going from cover to cover and checking your corners.I really like the fact that there's a max player limit per class, for example, there are only allowed to be a set amount of "Assault class" players, same goes for machine gunner, marksman, squad leader etc... The only class that is really never full is rifleman. Which makes sense, obviously.It feels extremely satisfying to fire a round into someone, the enemies often drops quite realistically which makes for an immersive experience, the suppression is also done just right in my opinion. It fits the game perfectly. It really starts to mess with your aim when you're supressed, your aim will be completely thrown off if you are suppressed by full auto fire of an MG.The game requires a great amount of teamwork, if you want to succeed you are going to have to work together with your squad leaders and your commander. It is very important for squad leaders to stay alive as they serve as spawn points for other players within their squad. Squad leaders also have to mark locations for artillery, and they are also equipped with smoke grenades which are good for helping your team push up. The commander has the most important role in the team, he or she must give orders to the other squad leaders and fireteams and is also capable of calling in artillery on the locations marked by the squad leaders.  Communication is very important in this game, if you have an important role at least.The graphics are also pretty good for a 2011 game, it runs on Unreal Engine 3 and the art style overall is fairly appealing. The gun models look great and the first person animations are nicely done. Texture work is mostly good, models look really nice, effects (like smoke, fire) look very good, too.I must warn you though, this game has an insanely big learning curve. If you are not used to these types of games I can almost guarantee you it'll be very difficult for you to do well. It took me quite some time to get good at the game.Framerate wise, it varies. Some maps are better optimized than others, though overall performance does seem good.All in all, if you want a fairly realistic and unforgiving world war 2 shooter, then this is for you.Oh and one more thing, don't play the singleplayer campaign. Just don't.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
												Red Orchestra 2 is an FPS game set during World War II and more precisely during the conquer of Stalingrad by the German army: during the single player campaign we will play first as a German soldier on the attacking side and then as a Russian soldier and his team who has to defend various location in Stalingrad from the German attack. Overall the story and the story-telling are good, but the low performance optimization, the bad A.I. and a bunch of bugs really make the singleplayer experience worse than it should be.On the multiplayer side this game really shines, all the problems of the singleplayer were fixed, good graphics and performance, less bugs and good A.I. The tactical and realistic style that this game has is really hard to find in other videogames, i can only compare it to a mix of Arma and BattleField mechanics: lots of different classes with actually different roles, vehicles, covers, medium/large-sized maps (but smaller then Arma or BF), character and weapons experience levels and a realistic game mode in which you die with a single rifle shot or a small assault rifle burst.At the beginning the game can look hard and not appealing but once you get to know the basics and the mechanics you will start to love it: for this i suggest everyone to play the campaign first, even if it's the worse part of the game, that will help you enjoy the multiplayer.In less words, BUY IT.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2012
												The most realistic first person shooter I've ever played. Quite the learning curve I find but once you get the hang of it, this can be one awesome game. Gravity has effect on the bullets, but you can adjust sights to compensate for distance, you can rest your rifle against a window sill or door ledge to stable your firearm for accuracy, controls inside the tanks are in view, and there's effects for when you're under suppressive fire. You can also level up classes and firearms to become more efficient. Not terribly unlike real life, after all you can condition yourself to have better stamina, get more in tune with the firearms you own, and you can also get attachments/modifications for some. Hoping that in Red Orchestra 3, they incorporate the possibility of jams. In real life however, if you maintain your firearms, malfunctions will be few and far between. No gun is 100% reliable, though. Not even AKs or Glocks.June 23, 2014 - Since an update they made in April, I have been unable to play the game, and many others have also been unable to join servers. Do not waste your money on RO2 or RS until it starts working again, it will only give you headaches.Nov 24, 2014 - The issue seems to have been resolved, the game is running well again. Enjoy the WWII realism!

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												So, after playing the multiplayer of both Rising Storm & Red Orchestra 2 for about 170+ hours and reaching max level on Rising Storm while also reaching a decently high level on Red Orchestra 2, I can say that this game is excellent.The game is extremely unforgiving, you often die in pretty much 1 or 2 hits. If you are hit anywhere but your limbs, you'll probably die instantly. The only times you really have a chance to survive is if a bullet hits your arm or leg. If you somehow don't die instantly and you're wounded, you can use one of the 2 bandages you are given every spawn to patch yourself up. If you do not bandage up in time, you might bleed out depending on where you got shot. It is very important to move carefully by going from cover to cover and checking your corners.I really like the fact that there's a max player limit per class, for example, there are only allowed to be a set amount of "Assault class" players, same goes for machine gunner, marksman, squad leader etc... The only class that is really never full is rifleman. Which makes sense, obviously.It feels extremely satisfying to fire a round into someone, the enemies often drops quite realistically which makes for an immersive experience, the suppression is also done just right in my opinion. It fits the game perfectly. It really starts to mess with your aim when you're supressed, your aim will be completely thrown off if you are suppressed by full auto fire of an MG.The game requires a great amount of teamwork, if you want to succeed you are going to have to work together with your squad leaders and your commander. It is very important for squad leaders to stay alive as they serve as spawn points for other players within their squad. Squad leaders also have to mark locations for artillery, and they are also equipped with smoke grenades which are good for helping your team push up. The commander has the most important role in the team, he or she must give orders to the other squad leaders and fireteams and is also capable of calling in artillery on the locations marked by the squad leaders.  Communication is very important in this game, if you have an important role at least.The graphics are also pretty good for a 2011 game, it runs on Unreal Engine 3 and the art style overall is fairly appealing. The gun models look great and the first person animations are nicely done. Texture work is mostly good, models look really nice, effects (like smoke, fire) look very good, too.I must warn you though, this game has an insanely big learning curve. If you are not used to these types of games I can almost guarantee you it'll be very difficult for you to do well. It took me quite some time to get good at the game.Framerate wise, it varies. Some maps are better optimized than others, though overall performance does seem good.All in all, if you want a fairly realistic and unforgiving world war 2 shooter, then this is for you.Oh and one more thing, don't play the singleplayer campaign. Just don't.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												DayZ indoctrinated me to the realistic shooters out there. Red Orchestra 2, while not as robust as the ArmA series, has nailed so many aspects of the gritty, unprejudiced realities of war that these soldiers had gone through. Machine guns prey on on potentially dozens of enemies if caught unaware. The sheer imbalance of close quarters and the impractibility of being in the open for even short amounts of time prove how fragile your life is. Squad tactics become important and smoke grenades, explosives, and covering fire become essential when taking objectives. Artillery can wipe out nearly all the members of a team in just once strike and seeminly good cover can prove fatal when a stray bullet pierces your helmet. When one life is so meaningless you cherish it for some reason, nobody wants to be the one to cross the machine gun nest's field of vision, or the sniper that is watching for your slightest mistake. Your life becomes valuable despite it seemingly not being so. Your participation in capturing objectives can make or break a game, however. Teamwork and leadership wins the majority of games through good squad leaders and a good team leader. Red Orchestra 2 is a realism shooter for the hardcore, but is accessible to anyone just looking for an intense, but good time. Its not perfect. Certain angles with the prone system are abused, but this is very, very rare. Sometimes the cover system in the game messes with your ability to bandage yourself (they share a key) and you die a needless death. This is slightly less rare, but it doesn't happen often. Also against players the cover system is rarely worth it. Exiting cover in the system to shoot is often a sure way to die quickly as you expose an awful lot of your body while doing so. Melee combat is often not perfect and for some reason servers that display 50 ping in the browser sometimes gives everyone 200 ping in game. These are all very minor, however, and do not affect the game much. Its certainly less annoying than certain things in Call of Duty, Battlefield, and ArmA. Counter Strike Source (or GO) is much more polished but that is a very different game so I wouldn't compare the two.Rising Storm, the standalone expansion (you dont need the base game to play) is like a whole new game. The large, open areas and bombed out ruins of the Eastern Front are replaced with the dense jungle of the Pacific Isles and despite some similar sized maps, the battles are closer and even more intense. It becomes even more brutal despite the absence of tanks as it becomes very clear, very quickly, the Japanese forces are at a disadvantage. The force multiplier the Allies rely on are provided by larger machine gun belts, semi-automatic rifles, powerful sub-machine guns and support weapons, and flamethrowers that can take out entire squads with a bursting swath of fiery death. This forces Japanese to abuse their mechanics of knee-mortars and banzai charges or overwhelmingly lose any given match. Often, banzai charges make the difference between a win and a loss in a match and melee combat is a much more common occurance than in RO2:HoS, further amplifying the brutality of the close quarters, unfair, Pacific Front.Together you have two amazing takes on war that doesn't feed on its own ridiculousness or cheesy one-off matches of quick entertainment. The campaign system gives some meaning to playing on your favorite servers with your favorite communities and following the lead of a good squad leader (while contributing) is a sure way to make some fast friends. The community is very mature as kids tend to avoid the difficult learning curve of the game but once you get into it, learn the maps, the guns, and the basics of realism, it will really grow on you. Listen to the veterans and you'll stay alive.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												-Excellent gameplay if you enjoy realism and team cooperation in a WWII FPS-One bullet is enough to kill you on most parts of the body, otherwise you're probably going to need to bandage your wounds. Bandages are scarce.-Good cover system, similar to Call of Juarez's allowing you to aim where you wish over or around cover. I don't use it too much honestly.-Suppression system: If you keep fire on an enemy position (even just firing over them, not necessarily hitting them) they will not be able to move or fire back.-Slightly annoying-to-use squad/command system, which is neglected by players a lot unfortunately-Very good acoustics(?) on the weapons. As you move to or from a source of gunfire you can hear the change in sound. At a distance of a few hundred metres it sounds as though it could just be ambient (non-player controlled) noise recorded at a shooting range, which is nice.-Great voice acting, unfortunately there are only two different voices per team. That isn't much of a problem anyway, they don't get stale.-Decent music, although it's only ambient.-Extremely good tank gameplay, especially if you're coordinating with a friend(s). I haven't used the Soviet T-34s, but there are 4 positions in the Panzer IV which can either be operated all by one person, or as a group with other players. There's only one tank-only map I've played so far, which I thought there should be more of.-Lastly, due to a combination of a few previously mentioned things (acoustics, music, gameplay, voice-acting), the environment is one of the things I like most aside from gameplay. On most maps it's very gloomy and dark, with massive barrages of artillery and dog-fights overhead. This combined with the dreary layout of the map (abandoned buildings, train-lines, trenches, etc.), ambient music and constant gunshots makes Stalingrad feel like Stalingrad.-Rising Storm is mediocre, not many people playing it in Australia either.Not a whole lot of negatives to the game, movement and some other actions can feel a bit clunky at times. There is a losing bias to the Axis I've noticed recently, I have a win/loss ratio of 0.08 (~80 wins, ~900 losses), yet a kill/death ratio of 1.1 (not implying that's a good ratio, just that it's not terribly [game-losingly] bad). I'm not sure whether this is due to the Axis being inherently underpowered, or veteran players always choosing to play as the Allies. I'd therefore recommend sticking to the Allies if you're new.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												Best WW2 First Person Tactical Shooter i have ever played.Its Very Realistic.You die after an or a few hits and if you lucky and survive a shot you need to care about the wound quick.You only have a HUD if you display it with an key,it shows your tacital game information,such as actual targets and how far away it is and where the next supplly crate or radio is.Friendly Player names go away after an distance from like 20 meters which force you need to look before shoot.You have no ammunition display about your current ammo in the mag,you know how many mags you have left and if you want to check how much is left in the mag you need to check it for real which makes you defenseless for some seconds.Limited numbers of specific soldiers like sniper or mg gunner per team so you havent an sniper spam for example.Tank crews can get the actual full crew of players which need to work as an team.Its giving the unique moments which you have like "Only in Battlefield" in BF3 and BF4.Many More Unique and Realistic Features!You need to like this sort of games to enjoy it fully.I Recommend it to everyone who likes realistic games,ww2 games and games which you need to get into.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2014
												Most realistic FPS I've ever played.  Weapons have weight, you don't recover health when you get shot (If you get shot in shot in the hand, there is a bullet wound in that hand until you die or you win), most detailed Panzer IV/T-34s I've ever seen in games, bullet travel time, half the guns are one or two-hit kills, supression mechanics, most combat (Except urban combat) takes place at 50-150 meters, so you have to have some kind of accuracy to survive and conquer, the combat tends to be realistically short and terrifying, you have an extremely minimalist HuD, you have no ammo counter, no crosshairs, your guns sway from side to side as you walk/run with them... I could go on for pages, but I'll stop here. Highly recommended if you want a realistic experience.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												The one thing this game goes for is Realism. They go for that out the gate, and they go for it hard. most people play on Realism, and what this does is mean... you take a rifle shot to the chest, you die. Do not go into this game thinking it'll be like Call of Duty. Do not go into this game thinking it'll be like Battlefield. You play smart. You use cover. You do NOT run out into the open cause as I said, 1-2 bullets... you will die. It feels like real battles. Sounds fill the battlefield making it come alive. Boots on floorboards. Whistles of artillery. And the soldiers, man do they talk! Every little detail, even randomly asking the guy next to you you're waiting with if he's doing alright. The one of two drawbacks though, is with realism, some matches tend to have nametags of any kind turned off. This goes for allies. So the first thing you'll become frustrated with is trying to figure out who's friend or foe. You will shoot allies. You will get shot by allies. It happens, it's annoying. Some games however, have nametags turned on for allies when you look in their direction. This, helps, A LOT! The other major drawback, is after a few rounds... it gets repeatative. You'll find yourself playing against bots more often then players just so you can grind Honor levels and weapon ranks since you get the same experience killing bots then you do players.It's a cheap buy, and if you want more realism in your shooters, then check the game out.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
												Great game, I love how Tripwire have kept a realistic feel without comprimising on fun, hectic largescale battles.MULTIPLAYER:At first the game can seem quite overwhelming and the ranking system is hard to grasp.There are three types of ranking in the game: honour, class and weapon. Just by playing the game you will recieve XP and you will rank up in the traditional way of gaining enough XP, then increasing in level. Then there is class ranking; the more you play a particular class, the class will gain ranks (there are three class ranks). Each rank in a particular class may give you a new weapon, but will make the character look more 'battle hardened'. Then there is weapon ranking, at level 0 your weapon will have no attachments, no perks and will be completely stock in terms of upgrades. When you reach level 25 just by playing with it, you may(or may not) gain an attachement for your weapon e.g. a bayonet. Also your weapon handling will increase, which means your reload, bolting action and ADS will be faster. Your weapon will also get a more 'looked after finish ' to it. Upon reaching level 50 you may get an attachement, you handling will increase again and you weapon will  have a shiny polished finish.I have taken my time to explain the ranking system as many people have asked me about it ingame.Realism mode for multiplayer seems to be very popular, unlike the classic mode. Realism is the 'hardcore' mode of the game. It is by far the best mode and obviously the more realistic. Bullet damage is increased and there is no aiming dead-zone (as you pivot the direction the bullet will go isn't locked to the center of the screen, if you don't understand you will when you play it). As for servers go they are all very stable, with barely any dedicated Tripwire servers there will always be a server for you. There are usually about 5 or six servers up at any one moment.CAMPAIGN: It has a good campaign which is a good length, split into two parts, the Russian campaign and the German Campaign.I have one problem though; the campaign missions are styled like the multiplayer missions, you will need to capture areas just like you do in the multiplayer and you will play on exactly the same maps and instead of live players you play with AI.I must commend Tripwire for including this as not many modern games are styled in this way, but it just fails to keep you playing, with no interesting plot I feel the game is weakened by the campaign. RISING STORM:The Rising Storm standalone game/DLC features the RO2 multiplayer but set in the pacific with the Japanese and the Americans. I feel that Rising Storm is a much more refined game and stamps out most of the bugs seen in RO2 multiplayer. RS does not have a campaign.Campaign = 6/10RO2 Multiplayer = 8.5/10Rising Storm = 9.5/10NOTE!::: IF YOU WANT THE RED ORCHESTRA 2 MULTIPLAYER, BUY RISING STORM, BOTH MULTIPLAYERS ARE PART OF THE RISING STORM DLC. IF YOU WANT THE RO2 CAMPAIGN JUST BUY THE BASE GAME. I DON'T THINK YOU GET RO2 MULTIPLAYER WITH RO2 ANYMORE.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												Ok, So here is the review for Red Orchestra 2 with free Rising sun. I know the whole world has been eagerly waiting my next review. Don't worry you can stop holding your breath now it's here!The graphics are alot better than they appear in the trailer let it be noted. Although it automatically sets them to lowest setting for graphics so to first timers It will look like a rubbish graphical experience. But if you change them in options it is perfect. I can run on second highest out of about 8 options of graphics settings and still have some of the highest ping I have ever seen (My PC is not the best for gaming, I will say that much ;)Red Orchestra 2 (including Rising Storm) Is probably the most realistic combat simulator since Arma 2, And 5 times the fun.For the first 5 hours you will find it damn near impossible to do anything right, Unless you are an MLG pro like me (add me on club penguin at [BlazeItMichael]_Xxx_B*tchesOnMyD*ck_Xxxv). Although it is definitley worth sticking with, as after the nooby period you will become Adept (Much Like Skyrim) And be able to run, duck, survive and pull off some pretty amazing if not entertaining as hell kills. Especially as a Japanese banzia charger. To clarify there are vehicles (Not as many as Heroes and Generals but still enough.) There aren't ships or planes as I suspect that would almost ruin the game. You have enough weapons to start with and all of them are useful for different playstyles. Going rambo with a flamethrower was my initial favourite.... Until I realised my whole team was Laughing at me :(The game no matter what PC you have runs smoother than a very smooth and shiny rock (I didnt want to talk about Baby's bottoms because the NSA could be listening!) and the lowest I have seen my Ping being 80 no matter what server I'm on. Aswell the servers are up 24/7 and there is a constant dedicated fanbase of players online and with a perfect 32 a side on most servers there is no shortage of people to play with. There are also mod/community map and weapon and vehicle and texture supports including a workshop page.I haven't had the game long. But I am now enjoying it and find it hard to put it down for five minutes. The time it took to write this review was torture enough without being able to snipe some soviet pigs!There are 4 factions available Russia vs Germany and Japan vs US although more may be added through mods/updates.And when you become a pro you will have the best time ever pulling off headshots from 300 meters with a rusty 70 year old soviet revolver.Wow steam... The fact that you even dare to ask me wether I want to recommend this game or not is shocking....P.S Has all the gore and laughs of Chivalry (Yes including a bit of teamkilling.) But runs ten times smoother and don't have to put up with as many hackers.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												I woke up to see this game in the steam store, I quickly downloaded it to see what the hype was all about, as soon as it was downloaded I was about to click the play button when all of a sudden I got a knock at the door, I was startled at first so I jumped up to check the peep hole, and whoever it was on the other side had their finger over it so I got suspicious an grabbed my gun, I yelled "who's there!?" No reply so I asked once more... I got the same silence so after contemplating for the next several minutes I decided to open the door.My initial reaction was to shoot....BANG...BANG...BANG... I stood in shock as I found out it was my american stepbrother.I was in tears, he was dead, all three of my rounds had entered his heart...but then I looked down he had his laptop in his hands...with this exact game running. He had come over to see if I had bought and downloaded it because this game is so awesome. So I played Red Orchestra 2 on his laptop for many hours, over his cold dead body...8/10 Would shoot again.

												Te gusta morir? Te gusta que tus compañeros te peguen tiros o te despedacen a base de granadas "lanzadas accidentalmente sobre tu cogote" y que ademas se metan contigo por haberte puesto en medio? Te gusta tener un ratio de Kill/Death de 0,1? lo que se traduce en matar a 1 por cada 100 balazos en tu precioso cogote y de vez en cuando en tus partes sensibles (no pongo la palabra literal porque sino me la censuran)? Quieres sentir como un nivel 99 que tiene mas de 1000 horas jugadas te vuela la cabeza tan rapido que mueres en muchas dimensiones al mismo tiempo y lo mejor de todo esque nunca sabes por donde te van a caer las ostias? Te gusta gastar cargadores enteros sobre tus amigos y mejor todavia, te gusta gastar cargadores y cargadores enteros de balas y que todas ellas no den absolutamente a nada y a nadie? Te gustan los ascensores? entonces te encantara Grain Elevator. Te gusta el fuego? entonces te encantara el fuego a 30 metros que es a donde llega el lanzallamas. Te gustan los Lideres de Escuadrón (Squad Lider que ofrecen puntos de respawn) que estan siempre muertos y que no hacen mas que joder y tocar las bolas con el humo? Te gustan los Comandantes inteligentes y estrategas que se dedican a utilizar la genial y prodigiosa estrategia mortal de lanzar artilleria sobre las pobres y desamparadas cabezas de sus propios hombres? Te gusta ser Fusilero (Rifleman) que solo tiene un fusil que como no hayas jugado mucho fallaras mas que una escopeta de feria? pues mejor para ti porque la mayoria de veces sera lo unico a lo que juegues porque como en España el internet esta como esta y  la mayoria del mundo civilizado de se conecta como 20 segundos antes que tu lo habran cojido TODO, excpeto rifleman porque? pues porque es la tipica clase que no coje ni tu abuela. Te gusta el MicSpawn? pues mejor para ti porque podras disfrutar de gente discutiendo en idiomas queno entiende ni el tato y ademas sobre temas que no vienen a cuento como por ejemplo, ir perdiendo la partida y en vez de hablar sobre com darle la vuelta ponerse a hablar sobre la Revolucion Francesa algo muy normal. AVISO: es muy raro no encontrarse grupos asi, quedais advertidos. Eres suicida y te gusta correr con una granada en las manos y luego hacer volar a un monton de amigos porque no has llegado a tu enemigo? entonces te aconsejo que seas Japones, ya que son unos flipados de la vida con una katana ( eso si no todas las clases la llevan, lo siento por si os pensabais que habian samurais o algo) y van corriendo como locos con mucho amor y ademas dopados (si dopados porque cuando hacen eso tienen bonificacion de resistencia y de daño, es decir que se colocan en modo OP). Si no te gusta ni la mitad de las cosas entonces no te recomiendo que lo juegues porque cada hora que juegas aumentaran tus posibilidades de desarrollar un intenso sentimiento de frustracion que haran que acabes como el niño aleman loco ( si ese niño que aporreaba el teclado y dejo el ordeador echo papilla).NOTA: este juego tambien se le conoce como Red Frustration 2

content:
Posted: May 15, 2014
												The very first Communists were early Slavic tribes who owned so little they had to share everything. They were renowned warriors, whose battle tactics consisted of getting as drunk as mortally possible, then drink twice as much more and charge at the enemy wielding a hammer in one hand and a sickle in the other. Even in these early times they were called the Red Army for their red faces (esp. noses). A Communist Warrior was terrible to behold in battle, bashing, slicing, and breathing alcoholic fumes at his enemies. Mortally wounded, he would merely fall asleep at the field of battle, only to wake up the next morning with regenerated limbs, healed wounds and a severe headache.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												Do you want PTSD lite?If the answer is yes, then this game is for you!  This game is somewhere on the realism spectrum between a generic shooter, and an Arma game (And it leans closer to the Arma side).  The game has a very short time to kill, usually one or two bullets will finish the job pretty well, although if you can disengage,  minor injuries can sometimes be bandaged before you bleed out (and you can bleed out).  The real delight of the game is its scale and visuals.  it's best played on 64 player servers, with as many players as possible, which can make the game fairly chaotic.  Visually, the game is not the most beautiful, although it is by no means ugly, but it does a good job at portraying sone of the more horrible aspects of war, limbs can come off, although blood is not overdone, like in some games, and the game is filled with lots of little thing that catch your eye.Anyway, I think I will end with a story from my time in game:         I was in the gunnery seat of a panzer IV, when a T-34 roles onto the street directly ahead.  I sight the gun to my estimated range and fire.  The shell shattered on impact, dealing little to no damage.  I hear a pinging noise on the right side of the tank, probably machine gun fire, I think to myself.  I  adjust my sights and wait for my loader to finish loading the shell.  After waiting some time for confirmation that the shell is loaded, I try firing anyway.  Click.  There's no shell in the barrel.  The T-34 fires, their shell bounces off the side of the tank.  I take the momentary break to take a look at the crew compartment of my Panzer IV.  Everyone in the tank is dead, and there are several holes on the right side that appear to have come from anti tank rifles.  Only my loader is still alive, and he's missing both his legs, cradling a shell and crying for his mother.  There's nothing left for me in this tank, and I evacuate out of the Hatch on the left side. Right as I have just exited, the anti tank rifles start peppering the sides again, as I'm climbing down from the tank a round penetrates and impacts the ammunition racks.  The tank explodes violently and I'm cast several feet from the vehicle, slowly bleeding out on the ground.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2014
												Absolutely reccomend to fans of the WW2 FPS Genre, but specifically if you're into tactical gameplay. While not overly complex it takes both map knowledge and role knowledge in order for the player to be a sucessful member of the team and be able to enjoy your experience in Red Orchestra 2. A highly detailed game when it comes to battlefield mechanics, cover, suppression and co-ordinated movements are the centerpieces of the gameplay. Visiuals and audio are incredibly raw and immersive, playing realism mode (reccomended) will place you straight on the frontlines of an absolute slaughter in which every inch you fight for is a hard earned and a glorious victory. The environment is as detailed and important as the weapon in your hands, excellent map design makes the Territory playstyle a sandbox in which to learn, hone skills and dominate the opposistion. Wonderful game with a steep learning curve but nothing out of the oridinary, basic tips are to slow down and listen to your team leaders who most often have mics to inform the team of their decisions and calls. Play the training levels, roll rifleman, and read the below guide in order to familiarize yourself with what your prioirities are as a newbie and work your way up fro there. :Posistives:+ Immersion + Detailed period weaponry/world+ Teamwork oriented + Multiple playstyles & recent Rising Storm Expansion + Operator as fuark:Negatives:- Steep learning curve- Cover system is finnecky and shouldn't be used over Cover/Concealment http://www.americanrifleman.org/articles/cover-and-concealment/- PTSD:Intro to playing Red orchestra 2: 


So, you wanna be an Operator like me? 
A Guide for Rising Storm/Red Orchestra 2 Multiplayer
By: Goalie

content:
Posted: June 17, 2014
												I've played some FPS so far, but I think, none is better than Red Orchestra/Rising Storm. Why is this? It has some really good tactic element which are placed together with a good leader system. The whole team is sepparated into squads, each with an own Squadleader, whilst the commander issues the over-all-orders. Also this system is quite easy to handle and allows tactical playing with total strangers quite easy.Also the setting in World War II and the use of authentic weapons gives you a complete different feeling like in games like Call of Duty. With many team members just having bolt action or semi automatic rifles there's no chance for rushing. You have to take care for everyone of your steps. Especially in realism mode which I really like.The graphics on the other hand aren't that good. Still nice to view, but there are shooters with better graphics. But those shooters going for the graphics and the always same quite dull gaming experience (I'm looking at you CoD series and BF series!) can't compare to this one in the gameplay.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												I´ve been playing RO2 since it came out and I have to say that reguarding my all-time multiplayer experiance, this game is the undoubted number one. This is a game that, in my experiance, sometimes has more immersion in multiplayer than some singleplayer games have to offer. It just "drags" you into it when you sit in your ruin with your rifle in hand, hear artillery shells and russian officers shouting right around the corner. What I have to say though is, that I´am pretty sure that this is not a game for everyone. You can not expect a fast and rewarding game like BF3, where level ups and unlocks are easy to achieve. Especially for beginners it can and will get very, very frustrating since you have to actually focus on what and how you shoot. It´s a realistic game and I personally love it for that. positive: -Most realistic shooter I know-detailed uniforms, weapons and animations-a lot of maps-immersion even in multiplayer-weapon unlocksNegatives: -Unreal theree engine isn´t the particular newest and best looking one, but it does it´s job and you don´t have much time to look around anyway. -frustrating at the beginning-single player is obsolete (you just play the mp maps against bots)-only two vehicles

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												The most realistic, unforgiving WW2 game out there. No crosshairs, no "Killcam", and no ammo counter. You have to physically open the rifle bolt or handgun slide to roughly check how many bullets are left. There is bullet drop and bullets will penetrate through objects and walls. You can manually select between automatic and semi auto fire. You can also adjust iron sights for distance and the iron sights actually move. If you get shot you have to stop and bandage or you will bleed out and die. Most of the time though one bullet is all it takes for you to die instantly. You hear your player breathing when you aim down your sights and the sights go up and down slightly in sync with your breathing, until you hold your breath. Some servers also do not show teammates names above their heads so you have to visualy make sure it is an enemy by their clothing. All servers always have friendly fire on. This game is not for people who get frustrated with realistic fps games. This game relies very very heavily on teamwork, so much more than in say any of the Battlefield games. If you love realistic WW2 games though then this is the game for you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2011
												If you are lucky enough to not suffer bugs with this beast of a shooter, its probably going to be one of the best games youve played in a long long time. This is oldskool skill and determination coupled with the best first-person cover system ive ever seen. The guns feel awesome; theres bullet drop, adjustable ironsights, manual clip-checking, fully crewed tanks and an impressive bleeding mechanic. When the game works (admittedly its a buggy piece of crap) you realise its just... perfect :DIf you call yourself a fps player, and are bored of CoD style empty gameplay gimmicks (in my book they are mutually exclusive, harsh ;p) get this game before they fix all the bugs :D

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												I recommend this game for those who want a realistic warfare game. I find this game to be the a good hybrid between Arma operation Arrowhead and Battlefield 3. Though this game does have its cons. First of all the singleplayer campaign is nothing more than capture or defend the flag with some cutscenes. The AI is noticeabley bad and is very unresponsive to commands given, though the game in itself is based around the intense multiplayer. I would recommend this game for people with higher quality pcs as it does have stability issues. WIthout the stability issues this game would get a 9 out of 10, but because it is glitchy in some aspects this game only recieves an 8. I would not recommend this game for people who are seaking action and instant gratification. This game requires slow and tactical thinking as well as strong teamwork. The player base is quite forgiving and with some practice is pretty easy to get used to

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												Why the bloody hell not? It's a logical alternative when you are tired of the usual run-and-gun games like the Call of Duty Franchise. It puts you right at the heart of WW2's most bloodiest theatres, the Eastern Front (known as the Great Patriotic War for our Russian friends). Once more, why the hell not? There's no storyline, no cinematics. Just war being squeezed into a PC game in the most advanced, realistic way possible. That's not enough? Try Multiplayer. You'll actually feel what its like to be tactical, that your descisions affect the outcome of every engagement. Perhaps bringing your Springfield to the jungles of Guadalcanal might not be the most optimal choice, nor is running around whilst firing from the hip with your MP40 at a T-34 during Operation Barashka. The only flaw I found so far about RO2 is the AI, which is often dull, deaf, or daft. Other than that, good game. Buy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												By far my favorite FPS. I've played lots of them, and I'm a huge fan in the FPS genre. From Medal of Honor back in the day, to Call of Duty, Battlefield series, Halo, Killzone, you name it I've played it. But I just love the tactical nature of RO2, the team work really feels like you are a part of an army battling for supremacy. The realistic nature took me awhile to get use to as I died hundreds of times when I blindly would run straight into battle. But learning the value of life, and just how close you are to death really makes this game thrilling. You can die at anytime from anywhere! Now this might sound terrible, but it's so satisfying when you get the jump on your opponent. It's a great great game, great challenge loads of fun. I hope they release British troops, and US vs German maps soon.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
												The game is absolutely fabolous. The atmosphere is Top-Notch, and at the same time this is very cheap compared to AAA games. I can not however call this game flawless, as much as i love it. The game has a lot of bugs and weird glitches, noone game-breaking however.Gameplay - The gameplay is absolutely Top-Tier, however, you DO want to go to realism servers everytime, as the game is NO fun without it. The game encourages the use of cover and terrain, instead of just bum-rushing into a flamethrower. The game also incorporates a morale sort of system, the only system to date that allows suppresing fire to be effective, by making your character♥♥♥♥♥♥their pants when large amounts of bullets or mortar shells fly past them. Looking at a dying comrade will also make your character react negatively.Sound - As an essential part of the atmosphere, the sound is very good, so you definetly do want to get a good headset before playing this, to get the full experience. When hiding in your hole or trench you will be able to hear the bullets whistling over you, as well as the sound of the machineguns firing in the distance.Graphics - Due to being run on the Unreal Engine, the game has decent graphics, but nothing to write home about. The textures are pretty ugly, but as long as you dont specifically look for texture flaws, you wont notice at all. The game is beatifull, as the maps are very well designed with flora and terrain.All in all this game is a must-have for players who want a great game with a higher focus on realism than their average CoD.8 out of 10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												I may have only played two hours of this game,but I only needed 20 minutes to know this is the best WW2 game on steam.In my first 10 minutes of gameplay I was actually laughing at how much fun I was having,it is not only fun but immersive,well optimised,tactical and pretty darn accurate to the time period.I'll tell you one of my experiences.I was a American sniper on the frontline attempting to reatake a beach held by Japanese,my team was fighting fiercely but it was to almost no avail,it seemed the Japanese reinforcements were almost endless. As the clock was winding down, someone called in artillery on the enemy snipers wiping them out and giving our infantry a chance to move up,the automatic riflemen stormed the jap trenches and a vicious gun battle ensues but once more the Japanese manage to fight off our attack, I decide it is time to make my move. I leave my sniper nest and push the left flank with 3 riflemen, we were in a prime attack position, we get into cover and open fire I take out ten soldiers and the two riflemen with me do the same but the enemy eventually worked out our position and launched a small counter attack that caught us by suprise.We managed to fight off this attack but had lost sight of 1 of the attackers,time is very low and we need to push into the trenches,just as we are about to storm the trenches I see the missing attacker sneaking up behind one of my riflemen, I ready my gun and take my shot, it blows the sneaky jap's head off and my character yells out,"That was for Pearl Harbour",We then storm the trench from left side and take out the remaining resistance,I jump a on mounted mg and hold off the enemy until my team arrived, once they did we took back the beach back and won the battle.Hoorah!If you want a brilliant WW2 shooter,actually scratch that,if you want a brilliant game,then this is for you.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												Personal Experience:I was a russian soldier lucky enough to received a mosin rifle. We were assembeld to recapture the bridges of druzhina.After a short but inspireing speech of our commander we charged towards the enemy lines with a resounding UHHRRRAAAAA. Then little dots started up flickering at the horizon. Multiple machine guns and rifles opened up on us. Two, three, ten of us were cut down instantly the rest crawling forward. Artillary is shattering the lines and our approach now. Between the shells landing we darted forward as long as the enemy is still suppressed. I barely reached the first objective to capture. Everywhere smoke, men shouting, cursing, dying, shooting. I take my hand grenades and throw them towards the trenches of the german machine gun nest. I kill two of them, then charging with my mosin and the fixed bayonetts towards the trench. On my left my squadleader spraying with his ppsh as if he would hit something while running. Then I reach the trench bayonetting one more german. But there is a second. I engage him but he raises his mp40 first. I feel burst on my chests. Knowing it's over I turn my rifle at him but only just. Fire one last round from the hip to kill him before blacking out....Only to be respawned and charge again. UUUUURRAAAAAAHAHAHAA.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
												The best multiplayer PC FPS of the past 10 years. Marred by a very rocky start (multiple bugs, some of which are still around), broken promises (to this day the game has a risible dearth of vehicles of all kinds, especially compared to its predecessor) and horrible developer PR, Red Orchestra 2 is the definitive proof that first impressions do matter. It is nonetheless one of the most authentic and thrilling infantry simulations I have ever played, while still retaining a good deal of smooth movement and playability. It feels largely like a proper FPS, unlike something like ArmA, though most of its maps can still be played in a similar fashion (with deliberate pacing and lots of caution). The engagement distances are decidedly shorter than the average milsim's (you're not going to be fighting anyone much further than 250m away), but it really does feels proper to the mostly urban Stalingrad setting. The closest equivalent in scope and execution I can think of is the Project Reality mod.But what of the game? A class-based affair in multiple gametypes, with most Russian and German WW2 mainstays very faithfully represented. The game oozes ambition and sports a plethora of small innovations (It takes playing it so you can believe just how organic, polished and "right" the always-on free aim system feels - do yourself a favor and play the game on Realism servers), most of which directly enable the game's very tense and kinetic infantry engagements. If you have any interest and appreciation for the FPS genre at all, it will be impossible to play this game and not bear witness to its constant displays of genius and obvious evidence of superior design and workmanship. If you constantly complain about the "fact" that every FPS "wants to be COD" nowadays, put your money where your mouth is and delve deep into RO2. You won't regret it - Tripwire gave the gaming world a diamond in the rough, and has mostly polished it into a shining gem of a FPS - An accomplished example of what PC gaming is all about.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												Never have I experienced war like this before. This is a great break from Call of Duty, Battlefield and really just any other shooters. Being a soilder stuck in a trench as the Japaness are Banzi charging is amazing! I would recommend buying Rising Storm and Red Orchestra 2. Rising storm is American V. Japanes and Red Orchestra is German V. Russians. All have unique guns and maps. Rising Storm has a little bit better graphics than Red Orchestra. But Rising Storm on some maps don't get that awsome feel like Red Orchestra. I mean like running up a hill attacking the japanes is cool in all but when you running down a street and a russian gets on a DP and starts raining hell on you in a city warfare fight is just plane badass. Rising Strom has more of a jungle/damged island kind of map style when Red Orchestra 2 has more of a city/forest/country map. Rising storm there is more auto guns and semi guns and bolt action. Red Orchestra offers mostly bolt action and if you are lucky you can get a SMG or semi auto sniper or LMG you will mostly be playing with bolt action rifles. Rising storm is not for the players who like to rush like in Call of Duty. This game means you have to work together as a tea to fight the enemy. There is no man for his self in the game. You need to work together. This game has some of the most amazing moment of all games. My most favorite games of all is Rising Storm/Red Orchestra 2. Gameplay 10/10 Players 9/10 graphics 9/10 guns 10/10. This is a buy if you ask me!

content:
Posted: September 17, 2011
												Lovely game and frustrating as hell, but that's what makes it good. I'm glad I got it. Tripwire has never let me down.As of this recommendation, the game is bugridden and you got CoD/TF2 Deathmatchers just camping and not following orders. In a few months everything should be about fixed and the kiddies should have left already due to being too frustrated to continue playing so you'll have the hardcore/team oriented players still left.Plus the price might be down as well.The "realism" in this game is wonderful. If you get shot, you bleed and you have a few seconds to patch up before you die. You can dial in your range for your guns and weapon placements and everything just seems so authentic.The class limits help even out the game as well. You've got 1 Commander about 4 Squad leaders, Numerous riflemen, 1 - 2 Marksmen as well as others. Maps are large and expansive. You'll get shot at from distance a lot while traversing the battlefield.Buy it once it's cheaper.

												Great game, Puts you right in the action on entering the battlefield, Maps are great size! full of cover to cover action wheather sitting back Sniping the enemy, Calling in airstrikes and Recon planes or Mowing  down groups with the LMG. ofcourse there are more classes then that, they stepped up there game using Unreal engine to get you duck for shooting through War rubbled buildings fighting for control in the battlefront style gamplay. it keeps you entertained as a Massivley multiplayer FPS for Ages, always having plenty to do.
