number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												Heroes Of Stalingrad is a realistic experience of WW2 unlike any other games i have played. I love WW2 games and this game gives a realistic feel that deepens the experience. I love the features like having to mentally track your ammo consumption and having to dial your sights over longer ranges. Rising Storm gives a fresh feel as it takes you out of the forests of Europe and into the ragged jungles of the Pacific islands. The asymmetrical gameplay allows you to understand the strengths and weaknesses of both nations.Red Orchestra 2 helps you to understand what it was really like in WW2. The damage is realistic with a rifle being a one shot kill to the head or torso, making the game a difficult yet exciting experience.Before i came across this game, the closest game I had were the earlier Call Of Duty games. And they felt too arcadey. I didnt like how it took 10 shots to kill and that the weapons all felt the same.But RO2 is an outstanding experience that rewards you on experience, while Heroes and Generals rewards you with in game currency.RO2 is great, please feel free to read the various guides and manuals that have been created by players in the community and on the web to see the many factors, features and gamplay that i hadnt the time to mention have fun all new players

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												Red Orchestra 2 , the game full of death, chynic, bullets, hate and mercyless! It is you or the enemy!Personally I like the realism and challence of this game. A hard game for hardcore gamers who seek for real fight, not for CoD arcade or CS bunnyhop. HUD is minimal, moving is challencing, shooting through iron sights (no crosshair), the damage... well, you usually die from one shot or two, instantly or after short bleedout while crying for help. You really fight for you own survival and even a tiny mistake at critical moment could (and will) be fatal. The tactic is everything, it does not make any sense to run stright to next objective (you will find out very soon why). In this game you will be a nameless hero of stalingrad who fights for his comrades, for victory and simply for staying alive.IMO the very best WW2 game EVER made!!1!PS: Mkb42 (H) rules!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												I found this game very enjoyable and exciting. Along with the constant fear of death looming over my shoulder(Which is realistically scary and easy), I've had some of the most intense survival scenerios fighting off endless waves of soldiers, in one desperate attmept to stay alive. Also this game has got to be one of the most realistic First Person World War II games to date; from the actual dates of historic battles, to even the fact of not having access to certain weapons during a time when they weren't yet in service.  Although you will occasionally find an NPC doing a number on a wall, and some simply standing at the deployment with no idea what to do, the NPCs can actually fight for a change, instead of the norm of having the players be the only ones to get any kills. As far as the visuals go, the team behind the game did an excellent job at depicting the weapons from the war. For example; In the Rising Storm version, the United States soldiers have access to the Colt M1911A1, which in very detailed texturing shows the realistic patents and inscription on the slide of the handgun. Overall I'd give this game an 8.5/10, seeing as my few complaints have to do with the PvP aspect of the game.Conclusion; If you enjoy a good FPS game with lots of gunfire and guys running towards you with a katana, buy this game!

content:
Posted: November 21, 2014
												I was charging a state-house with ten of my comrades when fascist artillery whistled down. A big red ball of fire and shards of metal formed thirty feet in front of me. Body parts went terminal velocity and connected with other comrades, killing them. I was blown back with injured legs, bleeding gallons per minute. I was able to bandage myself up and find cover. I took note of the blast area. Five unrecognizable bodies were in a pile, four other bodies were strewn about. One of the limbless husks were still screaming in pain, only to be drown out by incoming machinegun fire. Out of ten chargers, I was the sole survivor. The images still haunt me when I take my annual sail from Murmansk... PPsH 41/10, would break legs and watch men with organs tossed about die again...

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												Red Orchestra 2 might have been a game that I knew nothing about a few months ago. I got it when it was free. Usually, those type of games don't pique my interest for very long; this game was an exception. I played this game so much, dying non-stop, knowning nothing about the tactics involved and the tactical incetivised community. When I learned these things, I came to appreciate this game which offers some of the most fun and hard fought victories i've had in any FPS. Its fun, i'd recommend it to anyone who tries their hardest to win. Its a brutal world war 2 game, and it has enough depth and complexity to keep me comihg back to it again and again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												This game is for those who enjoy realistic shooters. It is a WW2 shooter with seperate Germany vs Russia and US vs Japan modes. This game requires team effort to win. I highly recommend this game.Pros-Player can be instantly killed if shot in vital area.-Player can bandage themself if shot in non-vital area before they bleed to death.-Realistic weapons with bullet drop, overheating, and individual mags that each keep track of how full they are.-Matches can have tanks, which are highly realistic.Cons-Some maps encourage one side to spawn kill until they win.-Servers can have bots, which are very dumb and very susceptible to lag.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												Red Orchestra 2 / RIsing Storm is currently the best WW2 simulation shooter on pc. It features large amounts of maps, lots of content including being able to play on community made maps. This game has a steep learning curve however, and lacks a competent tutorial that explains the game other than the basic controls. 90% of servers available are playing on realism mode which is IMO the best mode but to newer players might be extremely fustrating. Overall a fantastic game with great features as long as you get past the learning curve.TL:DR- Best WW2 simulator- Lots of maps + content- Community maps- Steep learning curve, extremely basic tutorial- Most servers are on "realism" or essentially hardcore mode

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												So I bought this during the Steam summer sale and I have to say they have made good progress since releasing RO 2 for those that had original left them a bad taste I think they have made up for it with this and considering you get access to all features from both RO2 and Risingstorm MP it was a great deal.  Now atmosphere and experience in this game I have to say this is the most tense exilerating WWII MP FPS i've played in resent memory.  It's not your COD of FPS's either you need to coordinate attacks not run & gun setup ambush emplacements, etc... lot's of strategic depth for an FPS on how you approach your objective.  The commander mode soo much fun in it's own right it reminds me a little of commander mode in BF2.  Visually the game is gritty.  Nothing more chillin then watching your teamate in front of you explode into body parts because he ran into a well placed boobie trap by the enemy to the point you tell yourself "Damn that could of been me".  It's gritty that when I torch players in this game I almost have a pang of sympathy for my enemy as he does a death curling scream.  My score is a 8.9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												Really fun shooter. Has a similar addictive quality to Call of Duty. However the style of play is a lot more like a simulation of warfare from the period of WW2. Graphics are better than the original and some of the maps are really fun and don't get old quickly as they can be approached in different ways strategically. Realistic and not an easy game, you have to focus to do well. But great fun and usually has a mature and often amusing community. The authenticity of the weapons, uniforms, in some cases locations really adds to the fun fps war gaming. Only thing this lacks is perhaps some confusing GUI and would also be nice to see more of the user maps being used on the larger servers, any fan of simulation fps or WW2 nostalgia should definately have a go at this.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 5, 2012
												This game is absolutely brilliant. The only things that drag it down are the technical issues, and given time, even those may be completely gone in a few months. Sure, this game isn't for everyone, but if you play it like it was intended - with collaboration - you will find one of the deepest shooter experiences around on the current market. Don't throw it away the instant you get killed fifteen times in a row… treat it as what it is - an intense, brutal, unforgiving (yet unforgettable) and realistic shooter with more than a few technical issues. Get back up, pick up your rifle and practice a new tactic. But even if you do learn the layout of certain maps, be prepared to have your most trusted strategies become useless when pitted against a good team.To make things even better, a huge & free patch (carrying a hefty 5 GBs of new content) that was promised to the fans has been released by the developers. It separates the whole multiplayer experience into three main modes: realism mode (the game as it was before, with some expected fixes), action mode (or in other words: an attempt to appeal to CoD fanboys, which adds many unrealistic features to the game and feels like it detracts from the core game and what it stands for) and classic mode (which is exactly what veterans from the first game have been waiting for - the return of many realistic features from RO1, and probably the most powerful of the three modes).Red Orchestra 2 is played best on realism and classic modes. If you want to experience something truly amazing, just ignore servers playing on action mode. Mind you, this action mode is still more realistic than many other shooters out there - but overall its existence is uncalled for. Among other new things included in this update are native language packs (that's right, no more English with foreign accents - you can now choose to play the game with Russian and German only audio) and the game seems to be even more optimized for better fps.Finally, the "Rising Storm" expansion pack (originally a mod, but later supported by Tripwire Interactive throughout its development to become official additional content for the game) has been released. For a reasonable price, it gives us plenty of exciting new maps - each set in the Pacific theatre of World War II. The two new playable factions are the soldiers of the USA and Japan. These different playable troops come with tons of new content in the form of weapons, special abilities and tactics. The new factions and maps feel fresh & exciting enough to enhance the Red Orchestra formula, whilst staying true to the series' realistic and atmospheric core.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
												The best multiplayer PC FPS of the past 10 years. Marred by a very rocky start (multiple bugs, some of which are still around), broken promises (to this day the game has a risible dearth of vehicles of all kinds, especially compared to its predecessor) and horrible developer PR, Red Orchestra 2 is the definitive proof that first impressions do matter. It is nonetheless one of the most authentic and thrilling infantry simulations I have ever played, while still retaining a good deal of smooth movement and playability. It feels largely like a proper FPS, unlike something like ArmA, though most of its maps can still be played in a similar fashion (with deliberate pacing and lots of caution). The engagement distances are decidedly shorter than the average milsim's (you're not going to be fighting anyone much further than 250m away), but it really does feels proper to the mostly urban Stalingrad setting. The closest equivalent in scope and execution I can think of is the Project Reality mod.But what of the game? A class-based affair in multiple gametypes, with most Russian and German WW2 mainstays very faithfully represented. The game oozes ambition and sports a plethora of small innovations (It takes playing it so you can believe just how organic, polished and "right" the always-on free aim system feels - do yourself a favor and play the game on Realism servers), most of which directly enable the game's very tense and kinetic infantry engagements. If you have any interest and appreciation for the FPS genre at all, it will be impossible to play this game and not bear witness to its constant displays of genius and obvious evidence of superior design and workmanship. If you constantly complain about the "fact" that every FPS "wants to be COD" nowadays, put your money where your mouth is and delve deep into RO2. You won't regret it - Tripwire gave the gaming world a diamond in the rough, and has mostly polished it into a shining gem of a FPS - An accomplished example of what PC gaming is all about.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												Best WW2 game hands down! This isn't some typical run and gun your way to victory type game, this game can only be won with teamwork, blood, sweat, and tears. But the reason I love this game so much is how much it immerses you into a battle. You hear screams of pain as fellow soldiers fall to the ground dead, you watch as enemies get mowed down by MG fire, you watch your screen go black while you slowly bleed to death, and then you realize this is a video game. The game is about what soldiers in this dark period in history had to see and do. No side is demonized whether you're on the Russian, German, American, or Japanese side. You are a soldier fighting for his country, his brothers in arms, and his own life. So pick up your mosin, kar, garand, or arisaka and get ready for war!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2013
												Red Orchestra 2 manages to straddle that fine line between semi-realism and gameplay. This is one of those rare and excellent Second World War shooters to play. It is highly thrilling, tense and satisfying. Weapons and bullet drop are represented impressively and the sense of accomplishment from survival and completing objectives make it worthwhile.An authentic level of vulnerability, tension and stress makes the game harrowing. It is rare to find a game that almost captures the brutality and intensity, but I find that Red Orchestra 2 comes quite close.Athough not perfect, with several awkward flaws (weapons unlock and casual modes) and rough implementation (campaign mode), for someone like myself not inclined to shooters I cannot seem to figure out how Red Orchestra suceeds. Teamwork matters between the commander and squads while caution and bravado occasionally nets results. I am not sure I will find another game in the future as compelling as this, in an age of shooters too afraid to offer tactical depth at the expense of accessibility

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												Rising Storm/Red Orchestra 2 is best experienced in multiplayer. There is offline play with bots but they're abit wonky and need improvements..They'll run randomly in aimless directions sometimes.Aside from that, Multiplayer experience is awesome as you really need to work with your team to hold/capture the objective. It is much more intense than the offline play with bots. You'll find that supressing fire works really effectively in providing support. Artillery strikes are also incredibly useful in halting an enemy advance and can totally decimate an entire squad in the area. Smoke grenades are a great for flanking or doing a charge.Great multiplayer experience (+)There are alot of maps available to choose from (+)Multiple classes to choose (+)Numerous gamemodes (+)Realism (+)Bots in offline play need improvements (-)Weapon variety is a little lacking (-)

content:
Posted: October 1, 2013
												Okay, so you are tired of those futuristic or modern military shooters? Your best choice is Red Orchestra 2. This game is so realistic, that in right server it feels almost like you're in real war. All this pressure builds up, when you're in a ditch and Soviet pigs are surrounding you. That feel when you have last few bullets and your last choice is to grab that old Kar98 and use bayonette to protect your position. This game is most definetly the best WWII game out there and it builds up so much pressure in the right server, that after the first map you most likely will be exhausted. Oh and since it's complete realism, then even a single bullet to your knee might kill you, if you won't stop the bleeding fast enough. You can call it ditch simulator if you want, because it aint some CS:GO/CoD/BF or some♥♥♥♥♥♥

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Best all around WW2 game for realism and challenging multiplayer team play.Love the gameplay mechanics, attention to detail (regarding mechanics, sounds, graphics/environment)...had hours of good times on this game. Used it to keep me up when keeping my girlfriend company during late night study sessions, the fast pace but long games were great at keeping me awake and constantly occupied.Drawbacks are there is no air combat, the vehicle combat is limited at this time, and the devs seem to be moving very slowly at completing the things they intended to put into this game. Note that while this is a great game in and of itself, of you look at the first Red Orchestra, you can see the potential the devs can do with this one, and you might feel a bit impatient that they hop on that, too. Also, kinda tough to start, but once you learn how to play, nobody will be mad at you anymore. Just make sure you communicate with your team and you should be okay. Terrible single player, but you buy this game for single player like you get Team Fortress 2 for single player: you just don't. In summary: AWESOME game for WW2 and realism shooter fans. WORTH IT. Excellent multiplayer. Don't get this for single player. If you played the first game, you might feel it's got half the vehicles and half the map sizes, but the gameplay is so different that this is not a detraction, just a bar for potential.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25, 2014
												Let me start off by saying I am a huge Call of Duty and Battlefield fan. Now that being said I am also a big Arma fan and I own the original Red Orchestra. If you are a Call of Duty fan, you may want to rethink your battle tactics when it comes to fighting with your team. The biggest thing in this game that makes it fun to play is TEAM WORK! I mean, you can be a long wolf like a marksman or machine gunner, but if you want to get the full potential of the game, play with friends( if you don't have any on steam, make some, yeah I'm talking to you COD players). This game is a huge improvement over the original Red Orchestra, I'm going to name only a few fixes they have made. First, and most importantly, graphics. The graphics in this game are a huge improvement over the original, if you don't believe me go see an eye doctor. Second, the shooting mechanics. I don't know why but the shooting just seems better in this game maybe it's just me. Third, cover and mantling. Finally, A FPS that lets you actually take cover behind nearly any object, building, obstacle, and vehicle in the game. The mantiling in the game is amazing compared to the original in that YOU DON'T RUN OUT OF BREATHE JUMPING OVER A FENCE! Oh, and by the way, you can jump in this game(yeah I'm talking to both of you COD and Battlefield fans). Now let me say this, YOU WILL DIE ALOT(and I mean alot)IF YOU DON'T WORK WITH YOUR TEAM AND DON'T MOVE FROM COVER TO COVER! Stay out of the open and keep your heads down. Now there is one thing I forgot to mention to COD and Battlefield fans(if they made it this far into the review) that I think will make them want to get this game. YOU CAN CAMP THE ENTIRE GAME AND NOBODY(and I mean nobody) WILL EVER GET MAD AT YOU FOR CAMPING. In fact, if you hold a position down, you'll get a high five from the commander saying "good job", Because in this game(especially if your defending) camping is what happens. Overall this game is awesome and you should buy it(especially now since it's on sale, but go buy rising storm instead, it includes this game as well). I'd give this game an 8.5/10 and is definitly my second favorite WW2 shooter of all time(World at War still has that special place in my library).

content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
Product received for free
												''Red Orchestra 2: Heroes of Stalingrad and Rising Storm, I only had a guest pass for multiplayer, Writing a reveiw for the guest pass multiplayer''  With very little I had to play, I would say this seems a very polished  FPS WW game. It was very much like Heros and Generals. Choosing a server ( witch you can pick through for map type and mods and ping wise that best suite you) you get to choose Axis or Allies. That is German, Japanese or USA...and as guest pass I was only able to be a riflemen in witch ever side I choose with the weapon rifleman layout of that side. From what I could gather and deduce... I would say playing games with certain weapons and soldier type you gain experaince to make those ''said'' weapons and soldier types to advance to gain better ones or traits and whatnot. The usual ''it gets better the more notches in your belt you got'' kinda thing. With advancements of Rank also im sure to unlock such traits and weapons also. I was not privy to any saving of my games and kills and such so I couldnt see how this worked out really. SO after choosing a side OR you could click auto if it doesnt matter to you and it will throw you on the side that you're needed on. With a simple rifle, sidearm and gernades you go through objectives and do what you can for that game type to win the game. Gametypes seemed to be a territory capture objectives or destroy them and being the defender or assualt(er) in thus gametype. Simple enough. Maps and game type are voted on during lobby matchmaking between whom is there. I usually went with the flow. Kindly I was able to complete the tuturial missions in this game even on guest pass multiplayer and greatly enjoyed the play by play teach style. You are a German in the tuturial being brought up to speed for the war. This game seems to have lots of hotkeyes to control little things like breathing while taking the shot, or stance or blind firing over cover. LOTS to learn so do the tuturials. What I really loved about this game, was the real, true respect and coverage of languages during the game to their sides countries and even music ethnicity vibe during the main screen to actual match playing.  It makes the atmosphere real and that the whole point of these WW games is to experience those cultures and war right???  Well if you want to spend the money on a game that is a step up and polished the Heros and Generals or other WW games Id definantly say get this one.

												Want to feel like you're in the midst of a deadly warzone, set in world war 2, FPS style? Then this is the current best, realism based world war 2 shooter there is. Absolutely accessable to both the casual gamer and the hardcore nut alike. It truely has the scope and grand scale required to immerse you in world war 2 mayhem. Other than that, the large array of weapons, and intense action, bombardment and chaos make this game a classic world war 2 shooter for years to come.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												The most realistic, unforgiving WW2 game out there. No crosshairs, no "Killcam", and no ammo counter. You have to physically open the rifle bolt or handgun slide to roughly check how many bullets are left. There is bullet drop and bullets will penetrate through objects and walls. You can manually select between automatic and semi auto fire. You can also adjust iron sights for distance and the iron sights actually move. If you get shot you have to stop and bandage or you will bleed out and die. Most of the time though one bullet is all it takes for you to die instantly. You hear your player breathing when you aim down your sights and the sights go up and down slightly in sync with your breathing, until you hold your breath. Some servers also do not show teammates names above their heads so you have to visualy make sure it is an enemy by their clothing. All servers always have friendly fire on. This game is not for people who get frustrated with realistic fps games. This game relies very very heavily on teamwork, so much more than in say any of the Battlefield games. If you love realistic WW2 games though then this is the game for you.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												Never have I experienced war like this before. This is a great break from Call of Duty, Battlefield and really just any other shooters. Being a soilder stuck in a trench as the Japaness are Banzi charging is amazing! I would recommend buying Rising Storm and Red Orchestra 2. Rising storm is American V. Japanes and Red Orchestra is German V. Russians. All have unique guns and maps. Rising Storm has a little bit better graphics than Red Orchestra. But Rising Storm on some maps don't get that awsome feel like Red Orchestra. I mean like running up a hill attacking the japanes is cool in all but when you running down a street and a russian gets on a DP and starts raining hell on you in a city warfare fight is just plane badass. Rising Strom has more of a jungle/damged island kind of map style when Red Orchestra 2 has more of a city/forest/country map. Rising storm there is more auto guns and semi guns and bolt action. Red Orchestra offers mostly bolt action and if you are lucky you can get a SMG or semi auto sniper or LMG you will mostly be playing with bolt action rifles. Rising storm is not for the players who like to rush like in Call of Duty. This game means you have to work together as a tea to fight the enemy. There is no man for his self in the game. You need to work together. This game has some of the most amazing moment of all games. My most favorite games of all is Rising Storm/Red Orchestra 2. Gameplay 10/10 Players 9/10 graphics 9/10 guns 10/10. This is a buy if you ask me!

content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												Best WW2 game I have ever played.  I love WW2, and I am always looking for good WW2 games.  I started with Medal of Honor: Rising Sun on my Gamecube.  I can remeber always getting scared when a Jap with a Katana came out of the trenches running at me and I would either waste 2 rounds of an M1 Grand into them or half the clip of a Tommy gun.  I Remember that one US soilder that got attack by a croc, and wondered why the Japs never were attacked when in the water.  I also remember the stupid tanks and how hard they could be to destory.  I played it for 4 years with friends and thats what got me into WW2.  Later when I moved on from being a consel pleb and got my first PC,  I saw that BattleField 1942 was for free on orgin.  I played that for about a year and although it was really old it was kinda fun, and funny :D.  I played it many times with friends and we would mess around on it most of the times, but sometimes there was a time when we played it like it was real.  We would alway end up running at tanks with land mines either way and killing our selfs.  Then the day came.  The day when I saw this game, and I can say this. There is no WW2 game thats better then this.  I have played at least 4 good one, which 2 of I only remember the name of.  THis game make you feel like your there.  Your a US soilder charging up a beach into the heart of the Japanese defence, or a German soilder defending the father land form the Ivan scum of Russia.  It's like an amazing first person movie.  So real and if you have a good PC you can make it look amazing too.  Running to cover from the enamys MGs,  firing your gun like a crazy man after seeing there is a enamy around the corner or in the ditch you just jumped into.  You struggle as you try to get away from the bombardment of artillery.  You are always thinking should I pop my head out to take a shot or stay down and wait for the SGT to pop smoke so we can get out of here.  This game brings a live and imersive feeling to WW2.  You buy this game and you will be a raw recruit that gets 2 kill and dies 25 times, but after a few games you get better, and every game makes you a better soilder.  You will rise through the ranks of the class you choose and what ever nation you pick.  You will help lead them to victory.  Buy this game.   20/10

content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												If you like highly realistic shooters, then you should definitely check this game out. There's singleplayer and multiplayer, but multiplayer is where the game really shines. The bot AI in this game is really bad, so if you are looking for a singleplayer experience, i can't really recommend this game fot you. If you want to play online, then i suggest watching a couple of reviews and gameplays of the game, because the realism might not appeal to everyone. it's a really unforgiving game, especially in hardcore mode servers. You die from 1-2 bullets, you get no kill cam, you have no crosshair, your soldier gets tired from running really fast, your vision gets blurred from explosions and supression fire very easily and snipers will kill you very often if you are not careful. There are many more things that make this game difficult and realistic, but i'll let you discover them. The game is meant to be played on hardcore mode, so i recomment atleast trying a few matches. It can be extremely fun and satisfying when you are winning, but it can also be very frustrating if you are losing. In order to win a match, a team must play together and have a good communication. It's also very important to have good and experienced player in key roles (commander, squad leader, Machine gunner, etc.) If a team fails to do these things, it is destined to lose, except if the enemy team is even worse in that regard. I also must point out that if you are planning on acting like Rambo- not using any cover, rushing and gunning down everyone, you will be killed countless times by snipers and you won't even get close to the enemy. All in all, I definitely recomment this game, but before you purchase it, again I suggest watching gameplays and read better and more professional reviews than mine. This is game that many people might not like.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
												The best multiplayer PC FPS of the past 10 years. Marred by a very rocky start (multiple bugs, some of which are still around), broken promises (to this day the game has a risible dearth of vehicles of all kinds, especially compared to its predecessor) and horrible developer PR, Red Orchestra 2 is the definitive proof that first impressions do matter. It is nonetheless one of the most authentic and thrilling infantry simulations I have ever played, while still retaining a good deal of smooth movement and playability. It feels largely like a proper FPS, unlike something like ArmA, though most of its maps can still be played in a similar fashion (with deliberate pacing and lots of caution). The engagement distances are decidedly shorter than the average milsim's (you're not going to be fighting anyone much further than 250m away), but it really does feels proper to the mostly urban Stalingrad setting. The closest equivalent in scope and execution I can think of is the Project Reality mod.But what of the game? A class-based affair in multiple gametypes, with most Russian and German WW2 mainstays very faithfully represented. The game oozes ambition and sports a plethora of small innovations (It takes playing it so you can believe just how organic, polished and "right" the always-on free aim system feels - do yourself a favor and play the game on Realism servers), most of which directly enable the game's very tense and kinetic infantry engagements. If you have any interest and appreciation for the FPS genre at all, it will be impossible to play this game and not bear witness to its constant displays of genius and obvious evidence of superior design and workmanship. If you constantly complain about the "fact" that every FPS "wants to be COD" nowadays, put your money where your mouth is and delve deep into RO2. You won't regret it - Tripwire gave the gaming world a diamond in the rough, and has mostly polished it into a shining gem of a FPS - An accomplished example of what PC gaming is all about.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
 Best realistic multiplayer game ever!!!!!!  SINGLEPLAYER If you're thinking about buying this just for single player, well you shouldn't because AI are horrible and its really easy to finish both German and Russian campaign in one day because of the easy dumb AI & how short the story is. MULTIPLAYER Multiplayer online may be hard in the beginning because how diffecult and skilled everyone are. Once you keep on playing, you'll be wanting more and more and starting to figure out how to play the game just like everyone else.At first, you'll<Run and gun<Die<Rage<Still mad about how to use the controls<Not focusing on the objective<Lose match<Rage about the spawn time<Leave your squad to get killsBUT,later on when you get the hang of it,you'll start to<Get comfortable with the controls<Getting more kills than before by being patience by defending the objective OR  attacking the objective<Communicate with teammates<Check map once in awhile esepcially on communicating<Not running and gunning<Taking your time on reaching the objective<Die less than before<Focusing on the objective<Sticking close with your squad and not leaving them behindThis game is all about TEAMWORK and PAITENCE, not just RUNNING AND GUNNING.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
												This game is AMAZING. Let me get that out of the way. It's ultra realistic gameplay-wise, and has great graphics. Did I mention it's well optimized? Most systems can run it on high at a buttery smooth 60 FPS.Taking one shot in the wrong place can mean instant or slow and painful death. There is a small diagram in the lower left hand corner that shows where you are injured. Yellow is minor, orange is moderate, and red is severe. Like, if you have red highlighted injuries, you gonna die.The game takes a page out of Battlefield's book (or did Battlefield take a page out of theirs?) with the supression effect. When being shot at or around explosions and gunfire, your screen will become distorted and your aim will become worse. Makes sense. I mean, I'm being shot at. I'd have bad aim too.Only a fool would advocate the importance of K/D ratio in this game. You'll die more times than a white girl says "like" in her lifetime.Pros:Extreme realismGreat graphicsGood voice acting for Native Russian, Japanese, and German voices.Realistic weaponsRealistic damageExcelent control schemeCons:American voices just sound stupid. "DON'T GET SHOT BAH TOJO BOYS" "FLANK EM WHILE HES DOWN" "THAT WAS FOR PEARL HARBOR" Ugh. Please change it.German english voice acting is GOD AWFUL. That stupid high pitched voice you sometimes get makes me want to shoot myself in the mouth. "IVAN! ZER! ZER!"Pacific campaign needs a little work. It's great, but feels less fleshed out.No European Theater.9.8/10. Buy this game now, you filthy Bolshevik.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2015
												No multiplayer combat game has sparked so much fear, danger, and emotion before.The tanks are highly detailed with interiors unrivaled by anything I've seen save for Steal Beast.The combat is quick and unexpected. Who ever fires first wins and this is one of the few games where semi-auto and full-auto guns are not weaker than bolt-actions. This serves to make elite riflemen with fast firing rifles a huge threat. Cover and smoke mixed with company tactics are a must and each class has a purpose.The maps are amazingly well done. This is kinda where I get the emotional part from. The amazing sound track mixed with you and your squad climbing through the ruins of Stalingrad or the tattered outskirts of Tula as you avoid sniper fire and shelling really helps give the sense of loss that the Soviets faced. With once great cities being nothing more but shells.The Pacific front is also pretty fun but I personally feel the Eastern Front is the stronger of the two gameplay and balance wise.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2016
												By far the most realistic fps, and maybe even the most realistic game, I've ever played. Unlike COD or Battlefield you feel constantly under threat, knowing that at any moment a stray bullet or hidden marksman could kill you instantly before you even realise what happened. There are next to no indications of who is friend or foe apart from the clothes you wear and what side of the battlefield you are on, with occasional hints at enemy postion on the map when recon is available. This neverending vulnerability forces you to act carefully and calculate every move. Simply running straight at the enemy as you would in other games will inevitably result in your death. Teamwork is key and is much more important than individual success. However, when it all comes together, the satisfaction is hard to match. In short, buy this game if you're looking for something brutally realistic but rewarding.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2015
												Honestly, RO2 and RS are some of the most intense World War 2 games I have ever played, if not THE most intense. The sounds and visuals do their job perfectly, immersing you in the gritty battles of the German Wehrmacht versus the Soviet Union, or the Imperial Japanese Army versus the United States Marine Corps. Even though the gameplay can be pretty clunky, it never fails to be insanely immersive at times.+Pros:+Awesome sounds and pretty good visuals.+Huge maps, enough to support the 64 player battles.+Plenty of variety with different roles.+Fairly realistic damage. One shot to the chest and you're down, no hitmarker BS.+Huge battles that can last upwards of 30 minutes.+Tanks require crews to be operated.+Cover system.+Mod support.+Showing community love by adding in player-made maps.+Commanders co-ordinate with squad leaders, and squad leaders co-ordinate with their squad.-Cons.-The controls. Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥-Whoever optimized this game needs to be fired.-NOT an easy game to run. AT ALL.-Some people tend to take this game WAY to seriously and end up making an♥♥♥♥♥of themselves.-Crashes. Alot.-Your weapon free-moves on the screen like an arcade game, which is annoying as hell.-Selling RO2 and RS seperately, but as the same EXE is idiotic. I.E. Buy RO2 and it shows the RS main menu.Was called Nazi scum by a Russian team member. Swapped teams to Russians and he swapped to Axis. Called me Bolshevik scum shortly after.TL;DR If you get it, be ready for a pretty unstable game, but alot of fun. Especially with friends so you can cease the means of production, or slaughter the Bolshevik scum together in harmony.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2013
												Absolutely stellar tactical multiplayer gameplay that shouldn't disappoint.In Red Orchestra 2, including Rising Storm, being a lone wolf doesn't really have any true advantage -- unless you're coordinating with your team by pulling some sort of solo flanking maneuver to catch the enemy off guard -- and even then it's best to bring a couple of squad mates with you.But that's just it. The multiplayer is entirely meant to be self sacrificing. Work with your team for your team. Use strategy and tactics to coordinate a highly effective assault on the enemy's defensive positions. Orchestrate the perfect defense against the brutal offensive attacks of your opposition and drive them from your territory.And if you want realism, well, this has realism. From the sounds of the environment, the background and from your weapon comes sheer excellence and real quality. When you take out a flamethrower and burn the living ♥♥♥♥ out of a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, you find that you are quite pleased to hear the screams of anguish and unrivaled pain from your enemy. Pros:-There's no 360 no-scope CoD retardation in this. -This is a gritty, tactical war game that depends on team work for success. -You can't throw a grenade across the map in this game. -You have to compensate for bullet drop by zeroing in your sniper scope. -You have to play smart by using the cover system to it's fullest. -You can't just run around like a mentally deficient derp and knife everyone. -Being suppressed really does something (not like Battlefield suppression where it's a screen blur and some dumb effect that makes your bullets shoot out at angles and miss.) -Weapons 'feel' proper and they have the right sounds. Cons:-Like all games that go off of maps, this needs more maps. Now, don't get me wrong, this game has a lot of GREAT maps, I just want like 200.-This is on the fence for me, but I've always liked the Battlefield spotting system. The spotting system in this doesn't display an arrow above the enemy soldier's head. Instead, it tells you the general direction the enemy is located.TL;DR -- This game creates the most perfect atmosphere that you immediately immerse yourself in. Every little feature from the sound of explosions to the screams of your fellow soldiers makes for an unbelievable, hair raising experience.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2014
												I've played some FPS so far, but I think, none is better than Red Orchestra/Rising Storm. Why is this? It has some really good tactic element which are placed together with a good leader system. The whole team is sepparated into squads, each with an own Squadleader, whilst the commander issues the over-all-orders. Also this system is quite easy to handle and allows tactical playing with total strangers quite easy.Also the setting in World War II and the use of authentic weapons gives you a complete different feeling like in games like Call of Duty. With many team members just having bolt action or semi automatic rifles there's no chance for rushing. You have to take care for everyone of your steps. Especially in realism mode which I really like.The graphics on the other hand aren't that good. Still nice to view, but there are shooters with better graphics. But those shooters going for the graphics and the always same quite dull gaming experience (I'm looking at you CoD series and BF series!) can't compare to this one in the gameplay.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
												Red Orchestra 2 is what you'd call an authentic shooter: almost everything in this game can and will kill you. You can't run around soaking bullets like Mr. Clean's Magic Eraser, no no, one bullet can and will kill you. Your life expectancy is short and more often than not you'll be killed by someone you never even saw. Your commanders will force you to run to objectives like cannon fodder while you evade mortar fire and artillery rounds as you wonder why you're throwing your life away. Snipers will pick your friends off like sport if grenades don't get them first and your tanks will most likely drive over you as they try to take that bridge.You might wonder where the fun is in all that and the truth is that you would have to try it yourself. The sound design is fantastic, from the franctic shooting to the laments of dying men. The gunplay is tight with different classes to add diversity and the community is great. But the best thing, the best thing of it all is the sense of tension that not many first person shooters in the market can give you, not anymore.Good luck soldier, you'll learn to love your rifle and sweet, sweet cover.

content:
Posted: March 26
The Good Stuff++Realistic World War 2 gameplay+Two games in one! Rising Storm (USA and Japan) and Red Orchestra 2 (Soviet Union and Germany)+Similar to Heroes & Generals, but no Pay-to-Win or cosmetic crap+Battles have up to 64 players+Squad system, spawning in and reinforcements (Faction's lives remaining) are unique aspects of this game+Maps range from being very small to being massive, same goes for time, 5-10 minutes to upwards of an hour for each match+Multiple class types, depending on the map (Riflemen, Sniper, Assault, Tank Crew, etc.)+Realism Play style (See "The Ok Stuff") eliminates the usual HUD for FPS games, has accurate recoil for weapons, bullet drop, sounds, and bleeding/healing +No spawn camping allowed, if you're in an enemy spawn, you get a warning to run away or you'll dieThe Ok Stuff=Basically every server runs the realism play style, thus you need a good PC to play this game. However, it's not a mod and is completely safe to run=It's either USA and Japan OR the Soviet Union and Germany, no other factions or combinations of those factions=Smoke grenades are held by squad leaders only, and they will either really help or really screw you overThe Bad Stuff-Only one game mode really, basically one team defends points and the other captures themThe Truthful Hard FactsAcquirement MethodSteam StorePrice Paid$4.99Multiplayer Match Time10-60 minutesCommunity500-1,000 players dailyThe Elaborate and Perplexing Scoring System10. Overdraw your bank account if needed9. Buy this at your next earliest convenience8. Shirley you won't be disappointed, and don't call me surely7. The dictionary definition of "Good"6. A good worthwhile purchase that you should give a chance5. You may like it bro, you may not like it bro4. Probably should pass on this swiftly3. Not a complete waste of my time thankfully2. This was more of a waste of time than my ex the 3rd time1. Press F to Pay RespectsThanks for reading! number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2013
												I have continuously played this game since the original release of RO2. This game definetly resides somewhere in my top 1-3 favorite games of all time. Hands down the best WW2 FPS game that i would consider "current" although it is several years old. Prepare to be killed quite often and depending on your nature prepare to feel major frustration as well!! As you adjust to the game and release your self from the" CoD / Battlefield franchise grip" and into the mechanics of this game, with time it becomes quite rewarding!! You should begin as a rifleman and play this position for at least a couple of months to get the basic jist of game play and learn to aim and shoot in game.  And while your new and learning the game  your deaths arent as costly such as they would be playing a Squad Leader or better yet a Team Leader. Being that this game revolves around team work at the squad level in order to accomplish goals as a whole, it is wise to learn each position well before jumping onto an established server. The community tends to grumble when a sub par skilled player is leading the team to a Lose.  which brings me to the only frown i really have with this game..  The gaming community while having many great people who are very helpful in it , is full of people who talk alot of trash over the Voip system. it can get annoying at times. Thankfully there is the capability to mute players . I see this as a set back in a team based tactical FPS... but humans will be humans unfortunately and there isnt much you can do to change that other than running a private server. I suppose that is the case with most online gaming communities these days. I would definetly recommend this game. The more time you spend playing the more rewarding it becomes as you learn the maps and how to stay alive longer between each respawn. The gaming community is alive and strong . It is rare at any time of the day for me to be unable to find a populated server worthy of playing! So come on!! , Join the rest of us  and get in the war!! We got some territory to take!!!!  A few gaming  tips while you are a noob...1) dont throw nades til you actually know how to throw them,,,, all you will do is kill teammates. 2) learn to  differentiate between team uniforms and the way they hold their weapons when running. each team is different intentionally to help you . 3) look at your map often!! 4) Dont run into falling arty.... you are just wasting precious tickets!!  See ya in game!!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												The most realistic, unforgiving WW2 game out there. No crosshairs, no "Killcam", and no ammo counter. You have to physically open the rifle bolt or handgun slide to roughly check how many bullets are left. There is bullet drop and bullets will penetrate through objects and walls. You can manually select between automatic and semi auto fire. You can also adjust iron sights for distance and the iron sights actually move. If you get shot you have to stop and bandage or you will bleed out and die. Most of the time though one bullet is all it takes for you to die instantly. You hear your player breathing when you aim down your sights and the sights go up and down slightly in sync with your breathing, until you hold your breath. Some servers also do not show teammates names above their heads so you have to visualy make sure it is an enemy by their clothing. All servers always have friendly fire on. This game is not for people who get frustrated with realistic fps games. This game relies very very heavily on teamwork, so much more than in say any of the Battlefield games. If you love realistic WW2 games though then this is the game for you.

But Rising Storm on some maps don't get that awsome feel like Red Orchestra. I mean like running up a hill attacking the japanes is cool in all but when you running down a street and a russian gets on a DP and starts raining hell on you in a city warfare fight is just plane badass. Rising Strom has more of a jungle/damged island kind of map style when Red Orchestra 2 has more of a city/forest/country map. Rising storm there is more auto guns and semi guns and bolt action. Red Orchestra offers mostly bolt action and if you are lucky you can get a SMG or semi auto sniper or LMG you will mostly be playing with bolt action rifles. Rising storm is not for the players who like to rush like in Call of Duty. This game means you have to work together as a tea to fight the enemy. There is no man for his self in the game. You need to work together. This game has some of the most amazing moment of all games. My most favorite games of all is Rising Storm/Red Orchestra 2. Gameplay 10/10 Players 9/10 graphics 9/10 guns 10/10. This is a buy if you ask me!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2016
												By far the most realistic fps, and maybe even the most realistic game, I've ever played. Unlike COD or Battlefield you feel constantly under threat, knowing that at any moment a stray bullet or hidden marksman could kill you instantly before you even realise what happened. There are next to no indications of who is friend or foe apart from the clothes you wear and what side of the battlefield you are on, with occasional hints at enemy postion on the map when recon is available. This neverending vulnerability forces you to act carefully and calculate every move. Simply running straight at the enemy as you would in other games will inevitably result in your death. Teamwork is key and is much more important than individual success. However, when it all comes together, the satisfaction is hard to match. In short, buy this game if you're looking for something brutally realistic but rewarding.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2011
												Lovely game and frustrating as hell, but that's what makes it good. I'm glad I got it. Tripwire has never let me down.As of this recommendation, the game is bugridden and you got CoD/TF2 Deathmatchers just camping and not following orders. In a few months everything should be about fixed and the kiddies should have left already due to being too frustrated to continue playing so you'll have the hardcore/team oriented players still left.Plus the price might be down as well.The "realism" in this game is wonderful. If you get shot, you bleed and you have a few seconds to patch up before you die. You can dial in your range for your guns and weapon placements and everything just seems so authentic.The class limits help even out the game as well. You've got 1 Commander about 4 Squad leaders, Numerous riflemen, 1 - 2 Marksmen as well as others. Maps are large and expansive. You'll get shot at from distance a lot while traversing the battlefield.Buy it once it's cheaper.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
												This game is for those that are tired of "run and gun" Call of Dutys and want some hardcore realistic action. This game doesn't go as far as the ARMA series in terms of realism, but instead does it perfectly, combining realism and fun. Ontop of the exellent stature the game has, the community is amazing, where people actually play the game for it's realism instead of "run and gunning it". What makes this game different, is that you have to take cover. No other game will you find people actually taking cover, because of the realistic bullet dammage. For crying out loud, you even get PTSD and shake when you're under fire for too long. There is unrealistic game modes, but the game's main focus is realism.Did I mention free maps and guns dlc from the devs every year... This is my all time favorite multiplayer game. Buy it for the experience of playing an actually good FPS.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
												The game is absolutely fabolous. The atmosphere is Top-Notch, and at the same time this is very cheap compared to AAA games. I can not however call this game flawless, as much as i love it. The game has a lot of bugs and weird glitches, noone game-breaking however.Gameplay - The gameplay is absolutely Top-Tier, however, you DO want to go to realism servers everytime, as the game is NO fun without it. The game encourages the use of cover and terrain, instead of just bum-rushing into a flamethrower. The game also incorporates a morale sort of system, the only system to date that allows suppresing fire to be effective, by making your character♥♥♥♥♥♥their pants when large amounts of bullets or mortar shells fly past them. Looking at a dying comrade will also make your character react negatively.Sound - As an essential part of the atmosphere, the sound is very good, so you definetly do want to get a good headset before playing this, to get the full experience. When hiding in your hole or trench you will be able to hear the bullets whistling over you, as well as the sound of the machineguns firing in the distance.Graphics - Due to being run on the Unreal Engine, the game has decent graphics, but nothing to write home about. The textures are pretty ugly, but as long as you dont specifically look for texture flaws, you wont notice at all. The game is beatifull, as the maps are very well designed with flora and terrain.All in all this game is a must-have for players who want a great game with a higher focus on realism than their average CoD.8 out of 10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2013
												Red Orchestra 2 manages to straddle that fine line between semi-realism and gameplay. This is one of those rare and excellent Second World War shooters to play. It is highly thrilling, tense and satisfying. Weapons and bullet drop are represented impressively and the sense of accomplishment from survival and completing objectives make it worthwhile.An authentic level of vulnerability, tension and stress makes the game harrowing. It is rare to find a game that almost captures the brutality and intensity, but I find that Red Orchestra 2 comes quite close.Athough not perfect, with several awkward flaws (weapons unlock and casual modes) and rough implementation (campaign mode), for someone like myself not inclined to shooters I cannot seem to figure out how Red Orchestra suceeds. Teamwork matters between the commander and squads while caution and bravado occasionally nets results. I am not sure I will find another game in the future as compelling as this, in an age of shooters too afraid to offer tactical depth at the expense of accessibility

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												Rising Storm/Red Orchestra 2 is best experienced in multiplayer. There is offline play with bots but they're abit wonky and need improvements..They'll run randomly in aimless directions sometimes.Aside from that, Multiplayer experience is awesome as you really need to work with your team to hold/capture the objective. It is much more intense than the offline play with bots. You'll find that supressing fire works really effectively in providing support. Artillery strikes are also incredibly useful in halting an enemy advance and can totally decimate an entire squad in the area. Smoke grenades are a great for flanking or doing a charge.Great multiplayer experience (+)There are alot of maps available to choose from (+)Multiple classes to choose (+)Numerous gamemodes (+)Realism (+)Bots in offline play need improvements (-)Weapon variety is a little lacking (-)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2012
												Red Orchestra 2: Heroes of Stalingrad. A hidden jewel amongst the vast array of FPS out there.Where to start? The game either has you play as German or Soviet during Operation Barbarossa: the German invasion of the Soviet Union during WWII.Multiplayer is the vital component. While there is a singleplayer part I have yet to get to it, mostly because the multiplayer is the very epithome of fun, balance and technical brilliance. The latest patch added a beautiful netcoding tweak: player side hit detection. You can play with 220 ping and it does feel as if you have 20-40.BEAR THIS IN MIND, THOUGH: This game IS HARD. You are not meant to withstand an insane ammount of punch, nor are you able to survive against truly insurmountable odds. Expect realistic bullet trajectories, realistic sound effects, realistic hit detection and thus realistic healing.To sum up, it is a hard but deeply rewarding MP experience, one you should not pass up.COD & BF killer. Get it. 5/5.REVIEW UPDATE: The Rising Storm expansion is neat, arguably the best WWII Pacific Theatre FPS out there. Get it too, for it is a refreshing change of scenery and gameplay. The free Island Assault update added a brand new map to said expansion and some other changes, worth checking out.REVIEW UPDATE 2: The April 21st 2014 update unleashed tons of free content, including new vehicles, a brand new map for the Rising Storm expansion as well as tons of changes, among which optimisation and various balance tweaks shine. The sheer love the devs keep pouring into this game, constantly expanding the experience, is paramount in making this game the very best FPS MP experience out there.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
												Can't say I have ever played a better FPS shooter, or, at least, a shooter that has given me this much appreciation towards it. RO2 is by no means a normal FPS, it is hard, it is intense, and it is realistic. You'll find yourself mercilessly get killed if you are only just jumping in, and it doesn't take too long to realize the game requires you to play smart, calculatively, and, most of all, as a team, to do well. There is no room for those who play twitch "I shot you first I win" or lonewofl FPS players in RO2.It's hard for me to actually write a review for RO2 now what I got this far, simply because the game is just simply matching my taste in FPS, and that should actually be what it comes down to if you're trying you decide if you want to buy this game. If you think you'd enjoy a realistic, difficult, and challenging, but a rewarding, fun, and intense game with emphasis on teamplay and strategy, I want to say that you will almost certainly enjoy this game. If none of those sound like the type of game you'd enjoy, and you prefer games like BF3, COD, or CS, this game either isn't for you or will be a rough transition.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2012
												On release the game was a disaster and extremely disapointing.But now it is the game it should have been on released. It is always great and challenging with large player amounts and some of the maps are brilliant as well.Depending on your play style, there is a role for you. The most numerous one are rifleman which are very efficent to use. Nothing is better then outshooting a LMG or a Assualt trooper with a bolt action.Rising Storm is also strongly recommended since you take part in the Pacific theatre one area that has pretty much mostly been ignored by the big dev's. Flame Throwers and Mortar men are incredibly annoying, but due to that using them makes a sense to get rid of them as soon as possible. My fav gun / upgrade on RS is the BAR with the Foregrip as it makes it a incredibly great gun for all ranges.The Unlock system on both parts is annoying and was not a fan of when first released, but now it is growing on me, due to have most of the stuff for the weapons unlocked now.Custom Maps are a must play for the game, as nearly all of them are great fun to play and better then the standard ones. Sadly though for maps Apartments (More or less Danzig from RO:OST) and Fallen Fighters appear to be very popular on vote servers, these are the two maps i dislike the most. The latter since it just allows easy camping. For Fallen Fighters try the map Streets of Stalingrad, since it is basicly a better version of it.I recommend this game strongly. If you are unsure about the play style. Get it when it is on sale, Be prepared to be annoyed to begin with, you will get used to it and take care, since it is not a run and gun game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
												This game tries to be as realistic as possible in a war type situation. That means the soldiers will be screaming, dismembered, yelling racist comments, crying and bleeding to death while choking on their own blood. It gives you a taste of the horrors in war. If you get hit by a bullet in the head or heart you will die, if it's anywere else you'll either die or start bleeding out, so a lot of this game you'll be dieing and eventually through patience, accuracy and quick thinking the tables will turn. This game is set in world war 2 with fantastic terrain, the AI aren't perfect (bad reaction time but great accuracy). I've had lot of great memorable experiences with this game, many people would feel a sense of greatness in things they do or victories they've won. My favorite moment was when I had flanked an enemy machine gun post but if I started shooting I would be found and killed (plus I was already injured and would die next hit), so as the japanese I would die honourably. I decided to charged them from the flank with a grenade, I then dropped the granade at my feet as I was shot, my vision went blury as my character laughed faintly and bled to death, the grenade exploded killing 5 people and it was glorious!7.5/10

SINGLEPLAYER If you're thinking about buying this just for single player, well you shouldn't because AI are horrible and its really easy to finish both German and Russian campaign in one day because of the easy dumb AI & how short the story is. MULTIPLAYER Multiplayer online may be hard in the beginning because how diffecult and skilled everyone are. Once you keep on playing, you'll be wanting more and more and starting to figure out how to play the game just like everyone else.At first, you'll<Run and gun<Die<Rage<Still mad about how to use the controls<Not focusing on the objective<Lose match<Rage about the spawn time<Leave your squad to get killsBUT,later on when you get the hang of it,you'll start to<Get comfortable with the controls<Getting more kills than before by being patience by defending the objective OR  attacking the objective<Communicate with teammates<Check map once in awhile esepcially on communicating<Not running and gunning<Taking your time on reaching the objective<Die less than before<Focusing on the objective<Sticking close with your squad and not leaving them behindThis game is all about TEAMWORK and PAITENCE, not just RUNNING AND GUNNING.

												Red Orchestra 2 is a very impressive game that manages to capture what war is about while still staying away from ultra-realism. It has a small but good community, and the developers are pretty communicative as well. What started out as a rough clump, is turning out to be a polished diamond. Servers with bots(A.I. controlled players) on them are a bit too frequent though.

Graphically not bad running on a unreal engine my low spec pc is capable of running this game aroundpotato (lowest as possible including resolution)min: 22avrage: 28 - 32max: 39 - 40awesome builded pc (maxed out)min: 64avrage: 75max: 80 - 85ganmeplay: One shot, one kill that is the type of game that its taking, i have trouble survivng by myself and when i do i've only killed one person while the rest of his teammate started riddling me with mg and bolt action round XD sooooo lone wolf is not a safe bet THIS IS NOT COD NOR BATTLEFIELD THIS IS GODD@NM WORLD WAR WE'RE TALKING ABOUT WORLD WAAAR! the movement is clunky but you'll get used to it anyway because it's part of the game, it's trying to be as realistic as it can get.
